story:
My name is Anna. I have graduated from the Stockholm School of Economics in Riga as a Bachelor of Economics and Business Administration and have worked in advertising industry for several years. After that I have been engaged in several independent projects and have successfully established my own business. Since that I have also worked as a VJ and electronic music video director.

I have come up with an idea to publish a book of flyers when I was sorting old things, like books, notebooks etc., out  and found a collection of flyers for electronic music events that took place in Latvia. All of them had a very distinct design and reminded of the events they were created for. At that moment I have realised that flyers were playing inalienable part in every electronic music event and now are a great example of graphic design of the 90s - 00s. They also serve as a reference to Latvian electronic music culture of that period.

Flyers are not as widespread as were at those days now. They have been mainly substituted by electronic "flyers". The collections of people who have given their paper flyers for scanning amount to about 1000 pieces. All of them have been scanned by now.

The goal of this, second, fundraising campaign is to collect 900 Euro for the digital preparation of material for design and designing the book. This second step of the project assumes the work with the graphic designer, who will be in charge of the final look of the book.

For each contribution of 30 Euro (delivery worldwide, postal expenses included)  or 18 Euro (book is to be picked up in Riga) you will get a great book of flyers.

No strict deadlines — the project can take up to about 1 year. The publication date very much depends on your participation and you can always check the project status at: https://www.facebook.com/FlyerCollectionBook

Sincerely, and hope for your support, Anna.

story:
NOTE:  Charms have been ordered!  I'd love to hit that goal though so I get back the extra fees and earn a profit!

Welcome to my Indiegogo!  I'm a stay at home mom/illustrator who does a lot of comics.  (If you've already read through this, scroll to the bottom for MORE charm selections of charms I've already made!)

 It's been awhile since I made a charm run due to the company I was using closing and being unsure about new offerings, but I've decided to make a go at it RIGHT NOW!  (Because Backerkit is running a special and so is Zap, which I'll be able to take advantage of if I get the funds by January 2nd.)

I'm plotting to do a run of charms with a different company, Zap Creatives in the UK this time.  (I have a second company I'll try out next time here in Texas.)  They offer a wide variety of charm types and I'm taking advantage of it.

Each charm will be printed on thick acrylic, like my prior ones, but unlike prior ones, I'm opting for metallic gold, so a few of them will show through, #1, #2, #3, and #4.  They'll all be printed on the same background, but it won't have any effect on the printing itself, just on any open spots.  I was going to print #5 and #6 on the same background, but then noticed the option for clear acrylic, so I'm going to go with that so they are all ICY!

Charms 1 through 3 are pending until Monday or Tuesday. 

Charm #4 is Vas from Shivae! Located at shivae.net/vas  The first time I've done a Shivae! Charm!

Charms #5 and #6 are from The Cyantian Chronicles, located at cyantian.net

(( Charm #5 is available at 1.5" and a test of 3".  If it's popular, I'll make #6, and #4 available as well.)

These are not all the charm choices.  I will add more, so let me know which characters you would like to see and if I get a few requests for the same character, I'll make more.

Please tell me which charms you want so I can track the numbers.  Any charms not wanted will be replaced after a week up.

Charms will come with your choice of attachment, key chain loop, cellphone strap, cellphone headphone adapter, rings, etc.  I have switched to a lightweight colorful aluminum ring that is easier to deal with than the prior rings I used and sturdier.

International orders will need to add $1 to orders.  Thankfully charms do not cost much to send.  Otherwise, shipping is included.

I've done charms before, so the only problems will be whatever happens with a new company.  The designs are all done and ready to be sent in.

Funds will be used to purchase enough charms to fill the orders, mailing supplies, postage, and taxes.  Profits will be going into the: Tiff's Shivae Need a House Fund. :D


December 29th Update!  I'm adding charms from prior runs.  You can order from any of these on top of the others.  I'm trying to get enough earned to make an order on December 31st.  I have a 15% off coupon and need to be at $150 to place the order!

story:
PRAXES Center for Contemporary Art

[Deutsche Fassung siehe unten]

PRAXES Center for Contemporary Art is a not-for-profit venue for international contemporary art and research presenting half-year cycles of consecutive exhibition modules, texts, and live activities revolving around two unassociated artistic practices. Founded in 2013, PRAXES aims to slow down the tempo and carefully unfold each artistic practice—its history and its contexts—over six months, always in close collaboration with the artist, writers, researchers, and the communities around us.

In CYCLE 1 (Fall 2013), we made three exhibitions with JUTTA KOETHER and five with GERARD BYRNE. In CYCLE 2 (Spring 2014), audiences were invited to five different installations by FALKE PISANO and four displays by JUDITH HOPF. Admission at PRAXES is always free, including all events, as is our publication series, PRAXES Papers, which can be downloaded here. We have become a popular destination for international universities, art academies, design schools, and regional and touring educational communities. Each Cycle has received about 6000 visitors, many of whom are local audiences loyally following the unfolding investigations.


CYCLE 3  |  August - December 2014

For CYCLE 3, we intend to push this collaborative experiment further, bringing in more exciting art and artists, new and hybrid exhibition and event formats, and an extended, careful selection of writers and speakers. To this end, we are asking for contributions from everyone who values our approach to experiencing art today.

When you contribute to CYCLE 3, you support:

  • In-depth, collective, & well-documented research in art of today
  • A fresh take on a not-for-profit institution in Berlin, still in the making
  • The building of new communities around art experiences
  • Tailor-made formats for cutting-edge contemporary art
  • High-intensity programs of talks, performances, and film screenings
  • Carefully edited and designed publications by international writers
  • Lectures and workshops for schools, academies, and universities
  • Professional installations with proper equipment and facilities
  • International artwork loans and insured transportation


Donate to CYCLE 3 today and enjoy the perks! * 

All contributions count, big or small! If you can't donate now, please share this campaign to help make this happen. Check back frequently, great perks will be added during the campaign! 

PRAXES does not receive any support from the German state or the city of Berlin; we rely solely on grants from foundations, national funding bodies, and private support. Please note that we are not fundraising for salaries. Your contribution goes straight to the program activities and facilities at PRAXES.

If you came to PRAXES in the past year, we would like to thank you for your interest and involvement thus far. Also to those of you who followed our activities from afar through our PRAXES Papers or documentation online, thanks for your comments and shout-outs of support!


*Please note, all perks must be collected at PRAXES during CYCLE 3.

www.praxes.de

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

PRAXES Center for Contemporary Art

PRAXES ist eine nicht-kommerzielle Institution für internationale Gegenwartskunst und Recherche. Über ein halbes Jahr (einem „CYCLE“) präsentiert PRAXES in wechselnden Ausstellungsmodulen, Texten und Veranstaltungen jeweils zwei unterschiedliche Künstler. PRAXES, 2013 gegründet, beabsichtigt das oft hohe Tempo der Kunstwelt zu verlangsamen, um die künstlerische Praxis - ihre jeweiligen Kontexte und ihre Genealogie – über einen Zeitraum von sechs Monaten sorgfältig zu entfalten. Dieser Prozess ist immer in enger Zusammenarbeit mit den Künstlern, mit Kritikern, Autoren, Wissenschaftlern und nicht zuletzt mit dem Publikum gestaltet.

Im Herbst 2013 (CYCLE 1) wurden drei Ausstellungen von JUTTA KOETHER gezeigt und künstlerische Arbeiten von GERARD BYRNE in insgesamt fünf Modulen vorgestellt. Im Frühjahr 2014 (CYCLE 2) war das Publikum zu fünf unterschiedlichen Installationen von FALKE PISANO und zu vier Präsentationen von JUDITH HOPF eingeladen. Der Eintritt zu den Ausstellungen und zu allen Veranstaltungen von PRAXES ist frei. Auch die Publikationsserie PRAXES Papers steht komplett als Gratis-Download auf der Webseite zur Verfügung. PRAXES ist schnell zu einer beliebten Anlaufstelle für internationale Universitäten, Kunsthochschulen, Designakademien und andere Forschungseinrichtungen geworden. Jeder CYCLE hat rund 6.000 Besucher angezogen, viele von ihnen folgen den einzelnen Modulen Schritt für Schritt und besuchen die Institution immer wieder, um den Ausstellungsprozess in seiner Gänze mitzuerleben. 


CYCLE 3 | August – Dezember 2014

Für den CYCLE 3, der im August 2014 eröffnen wird, wird das gemeinschaftliche Experiment PRAXES ausgebaut und weitergedacht, indem wiederum aktuelle Kunst präsentiert wird und KünstlerInnen sowie DenkerInnen und Vortragende dazu eingeladen werden, neue hybride Programmformate auszutesten. Bitte helfen Sie uns, dieses gemeinschaftliche Experiment im Bereich von Kunst und künstlerischer Forschung weiterzuführen.

Ihr Beitrag zum CYCLE 3 fließt direkt in:

  • Tiefgehende, gemeinschaftliche und gut dokumentierte Forschung im Bereich der zeitgenössischen Kunst.
  • Eine neue nicht-kommerzielle Kunstinstitution in Berlin, die sich noch in der Gestaltungsphase befindet. 
  • Den Aufbau und die Stärkung neuer Öffentlichkeiten im Berich der Gegenwartskunst. 
  • Maßgeschneiderte Formate für zeitgenössische Kunstproduktion.
  • Ein lebendiges Veranstaltungsprogramm (Gespräche, Performances und Filmvorführungen).
  • Sorgfältig redigierte und gestaltete Publikationen international renommierter Autoren.
  • Vorträge und Workshops für Schulen, Hochschulen und Universitäten.
  • Professionell eingerichtete Ausstellungen mitadäquater Infrastruktur.
  • Internationale Leihgaben und versicherte Transporte der künstlerischen Arbeiten.


Bitte unterstützen Sie noch heute den CYCLE 3!

Ob klein oder groß – jeder Beitrag zählt. Falls Sie selbst nicht spenden können, teilen Sie bitte diese Kampagne mit anderen und helfen Sie uns, unser Vorhaben zu verwirklichen. Besuchen Sie unsere Seite, unsere "Perks"—unser Dank für Ihre Unterstützung—wechseln!

PRAXES erhält keine Fördergelder durch Fördermittel des Bundes oder der Stadt Berlin, sondern ist auf die Unterstützung von Stiftungen, Länderinstituten oder privaten Sponsoren angewiesen. Die über das Fundraising eingeworbenen Mittel werden nicht für Gehälter verwendet, sondern unterstützen direkt das inhaltliche Programm von PRAXES. 

Bei allen, die PRAXES im letzten Jahr besucht haben, möchten wir uns sehr herzlich für das bisherige Interesse und ihr Engagement bedanken. Dank gilt auch all jenen, die unsere Aktivitäten durch unsere Veröffentlichungen und Online-Dokumentationen aus der Ferne begleiten. Vielen Dank für alle Kommentare, Anregungen und die Unterstützung unseres Programms bis heute!


*Alle Perks müssen während des CYCLE 3 bei PRAXES eingelöst werden.

www.praxes.de

story:
I'm Joe Holliday, an installation artist and fabricator. For the past three years I have been living at The Cube, an artspace and venue in Downtown Los Angeles. In that span of time we’ve collectively produced and hosted a number of art and music shows. We very rarely have made anything close to a profit on this for ourselves; we do this because we support the bands and artists.

Recently we were forced to cancel the lease on our home and artspace of 3 years. Without warning, I found myself faced with the problem of transporting two large installation artworks from our house to a new location. Luckily, these large-scale, original works of art have been offered a permanent home at the East Jesus art compound in Slab City California. East Jesus is an artist compound started by the late Charles Russell, and from my conversations with him, it was intended to provide a home for this sort of work in this sort of situation.  East Jesus is home to an outdoor sculpture garden, open to the public 365 days a year and would be the best place to exhibit the work for the fact that it is a secure and established space. More information on East Jesus can be found at eastjesus.org

Failing to transport this work means that it would have to be destroyed at the end of the month. 

The two works to be transported are both reclaimed wooden structures. One is a collaborative architectural collage between myself and fellow artist Mirabelle Jones, titled Hole and Corner. The other installation is titled Tesseract, and has been the structure that I have inhabited for the past 3 years. It would be reworked to be site specific and allow for artistic contributions by visitors.  Both installations took countless hours to assemble and gather materials for, and have been a labor of love.  Both installations are also free standing and I can safely say that they would survive the harsh desert environment. To have to throw these away would be devastating.

More information on Hole and Corner can be found here:

http://www.mirabellejones.com/hole-and-corner/

Previously, I moved three large scale artworks to East Jesus at my own expense and am aware of the labor and costs that will inevitable go into the endeavor. The quote that I received for to rent a 24 foot stake bed truck needed is 119 dollars per day with an additional fee of 59 cents per mile. My expected round trip is 440 miles in 2 days, meaning the cost for the rental would be around $500 plus an approximate $150 dollars for gasoline. I’ll also need to purchase several pounds of screws and other hardware (approximately $150 worth) to ensure that it can be rebuilt on site. With any space left on the truck I’m planning to transport a half dozen 55 gallon drums full of compost for the garden and a multitude of other building materials to the site. For your donations I’ll be offering original artworks and printed materials. Also, Mirabelle Jones will compose  a personal theme song using the power of MIDI technology for all contributors! Check out the perks list for other details!

Here’s a list of the costs:

Truck rental for two days: $238
Mileage for 440 miles:  $259.60
Gasoline costs: $150
Fasteners, screws, etc: $150
55 gallon drums x6: $36
Compost: Free
Additional Building Materials (Pallets, found lumber): Free

This will be a very cost effective project for the amount of new installations and materials that East Jesus will be receiving. With the large stake bed truck we’ll easily be able to fit all of this, and the hydraulic lift gate will save us a significant amount of labor.


I’m hoping to raise 1000 dollars to have a slight contingency over the expected costs after all the fees get assessed, though any funds not used on transportation and reassembly costs will go into other building materials for East Jesus as well as the operations budget. Things that are in constant demand out there include portland cement and mortar, caulk, screws, lumber, diesel fuel and water.

If you’re not able to help with costs I definitely need help with loading, unloading, and rebuilding the installations. Also, as I’ll have a very large truck, additional materials could be transported to the site, so if you have materials to contribute that would also be a huge benefit! Another way to help would be to spread the message.

It’s been a great three years at The Cube, and I’m really happy that folks have worked as hard as they have to keep East Jesus alive after Charlie passed. For all of that I am extremely thankful. This project is the end of a chapter, but with your contribution it can be the continuation of another. For that, I thank you!

DO BIG FUN!
MAKE GOOD THING!

garden, open to the public 365 days a year and would be the best place to
exhibit the work for the fact that it is a secure and established space. More
information on East Jesus can be found at eastjesus.org
Failing to transport this work means that it would have to be destroyed at the
end of the month. 
The two works to be
transported are both reclaimed wooden structures. One is a collaborative
architectural collage between myself and fellow artist Mirabelle Jones, titled
Hole and Corner. The other installation is titled Tesseract, and has been the structure that I have inhabited for the past 3 years. It would be reworked to be site specific and allow for artistic contributions by visitors.  Both installations took countless hours to
assemble and gather materials for, and have been a labor of love.  Both installations are also free standing and
I can safely say that they would survive the harsh desert environment. To have
to throw these away would be devastating.More information on Hole and Corner can be found here:http://www.mirabellejones.com/hole-and-corner/
Previously, I moved
three large scale artworks to East Jesus at my own expense and am aware of the
labor and costs that will inevitable go into the endeavor. The quote that I
received for to rent a 24 foot stake bed truck needed is 119 dollars per day
with an additional fee of 59 cents per mile. My expected round trip is 440
miles in 2 days, meaning the cost for the rental would be around $500 plus an
approximate $150 dollars for gasoline. I’ll also need to purchase several
pounds of screws and other hardware (approximately $150 worth) to ensure that
it can be rebuilt on site. With any space left on the truck I’m planning to transport
a half dozen 55 gallon drums full of compost for the garden and a multitude of
other building materials to the site. For your donations I’ll be offering
original artworks and printed materials. Also, Mirabelle Jones will compose  a personal theme song using the power of MIDI technology for all contributors! Check out the perks list for other details!
Here’s a list of the costs:
Truck rental for two days: $238
Mileage for 440 miles:  $259.60
Gasoline costs: $150
Fasteners, screws, etc: $150
55 gallon drums x6: $36
Compost: Free
Additional Building Materials (Pallets, found lumber): Free
This will be a very cost effective project for the amount of new installations
and materials that East Jesus will be receiving. With the large stake bed truck
we’ll easily be able to fit all of this, and the hydraulic lift gate will save
us a significant amount of labor. 

I’m hoping to raise 1000 dollars to have a slight contingency over the expected
costs after all the fees get assessed, though any funds not used on transportation and reassembly costs will go
into other building materials for East Jesus as well as the operations budget.
Things that are in constant demand out there include portland cement and
mortar, caulk, screws, lumber, diesel fuel and water.
If you’re not able
to help with costs I definitely need help with loading, unloading, and
rebuilding the installations. Also, as I’ll have a very large truck, additional
materials could be transported to the site, so if you have materials to
contribute that would also be a huge benefit! Another way to help would be to
spread the message. 
It’s been a great three years at The Cube, and I’m really happy that folks have
worked as hard as they have to keep East Jesus alive after Charlie passed. For
all of that I am extremely thankful. This project is the end of a chapter, but
with your contribution it can be the continuation of another. For that, I thank
you! DO BIG FUN!MAKE GOOD THING!

story:
Short Summary

KEEP OUR LYONS ARTISTS IN LYONS!

Art Pharm is a revolutionary program for Lyons that combines the highly successful model of business incubation and the creative talents of Lyons's artists to develop a community of artists and art teachers. The Art Pharm program provides unparalleled support for Lyons artists for the creation and sales of art with the goal of increasing artists' income to be able to afford to live and work in Lyons, Colorado.

What We Need & What You Get

Art Pharm is presently in the process of getting our non-profit 501(c)(3) status but we need our community's help in the meantime for:

  • Art Class Supplies
  • General Overhead
  • Non-profit fees and staff to get the grant writing process started.

The Impact

The mission of the Art Pharm is to provide affordable studio, gallery, and workshop space on Main Street for our Lyons artists. 

  • to create an environment where Lyons artists may explore, create and communicate their craft in a supportive and nurturing environment; 
  • to provide educational experiences to students of all ages with a special emphasis on programming for Elementary - High School students.
  • to present artwork by local artists in an effort to sell their work.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Arts improve individual well-being. 69 percent of the population believe the arts “lift me up beyond everyday experiences,” 73 percent feel the arts give them “pure pleasure to experience and participate in,” and 81 percent say the arts are a “positive experience in a troubled world.”
  • Arts unify communities. 72 percent of Americans believe “the arts unify our communities regardless of age, race, and ethnicity” and 73 percent agree that the arts “helps me understand other cultures better”—a perspective observed across all demographic and economic categories.
  • Arts improve academic performance. Students engaged in arts learning have higher GPAs, standardized test scores, and college-going rates as well as lower drop-out rates. These academic benefits are reaped by students regardless of socio-economic status. Yet, the Department of Education reports that access to arts education for students of color is significantly lower than for their white peers. 91 percent of Americans believe that arts are part of a well-rounded K-12 education.
  • Arts strengthen the economy. The production of all arts and cultural goods in the U.S. (e.g., nonprofit, commercial, education) added $804 billion to the economy in 2016, including a $25 billion international trade surplus—a larger share of the nation’s economy (4.3 percent) than transportation, tourism, and agriculture (U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis). The nonprofit arts industry alone generates $166.3 billion in economic activity annually—spending by organizations and their audiences—which supports 4.6 million jobs and generates $27.5 billion in government revenue.
  • Arts drive tourism and revenue to local businesses. Attendees at nonprofit arts events spend $31.47 per person, per event, beyond the cost of admission on items such as meals, parking, and babysitters—valuable commerce for local businesses. 34 percent of attendees live outside the county in which the arts event takes place; they average $47.57 in event-related spending. Arts travelers are ideal tourists, staying longer and spending more to seek out authentic cultural experiences.
  • Arts spark creativity and innovation. Creativity is among the top 5 applied skills sought by business leaders, per the Conference Board’s Ready to Innovate report—with 72 percent saying creativity is of high importance when hiring. Research on creativity shows that Nobel laureates in the sciences are 17 times more likely to be actively engaged in the arts than other scientists.
  • Arts drive the creative industries. The Creative Industries are arts businesses that range from nonprofit museums, symphonies, and theaters to for-profit film, architecture, and design companies. A 2017 analysis of Dun & Bradstreet data counts 673,656 businesses in the U.S. involved in the creation or distribution of the arts—4.01 percent of all businesses and 2.04 percent of all employees. (Get a free local Creative Industry report for your community here.)
  • Arts have social impact. University of Pennsylvania researchers have demonstrated that a high concentration of the arts in a city leads to higher civic engagement, more social cohesion, higher child welfare, and lower poverty rates.
  • Arts improve healthcare. Nearly one-half of the nation’s healthcare institutions provide arts programming for patients, families, and even staff. 78 percent deliver these programs because of their healing benefits to patients—shorter hospital stays, better pain management, and less medication.
  • Arts for the health and well-being of our military. The arts heal the mental, physical, and moral injuries of war for military servicemembers and Veterans, who rank the creative arts therapies in the top 4 (out of 40) interventions and treatments. Across the military continuum, the arts promote resilience during pre-deployment, deployment, and the reintegration of military servicemembers, Veterans, their families, and caregivers into communities.

story:
CONCEPTION, 

A multi media series that about conceiving a family in this millenium.

This is a creative, social and personal project. 

Socially this series will show that a family is simply about sharing love and nurturing.  As a society we have just started to accept that any configuration of an adult and child (children) is "family” and the barrier of "traditional" family as the only acceptable norm has finally been broken. I also want to hear from my subjects in their own voice. I want to record their stories, which include those at the beginning of their journey to those millennial children whose parents were brave enough to choose alternatives before straying from the “norm” became aceptable..  

As an award winning lifestyle photographer I want to capture heartfelt images of relationships in all the different types of families within their own environment.  Inspiring the viewer to see the amazing choices they can have in this era.

On the personal note, on Christmas Day 2002 my son was born and a lifelong dream of becoming a mom was fulfilled. This dream did not exactly conform to society's idea of how to become a parent and I went through the process of adoption completely on my own with little support from my family.Click here to read a bit more about my story."How a Mommy was Born".

The Images in this piece are just documenting the unique families I have encountered on my journey to become a family as a single mother by choice and through my professional career. I need to raise production costs to complete a visually and important body of work that will document through both motion and photography all different alternatives there are to conceiving a  the way families are conceived in this millenium.

This is a work in progress. I have been researching and meeting awesome alternative families since before my son was born. My journey to motherhood started in the early 90's when I was about 33 years old. I met Sarah, a single mom by choice living in a suburban neighborhood in Miami. What really made an impact was how ordinary their life was. She introduced me to another single mom by choice and from there my journey started. It took another 12 years for my time to come but it has all been worth it. I would like to show my son and other children their parents journey through this project.

Through my career as a fine art portrait artist shooting private commissions  and as a lifestyle photographer  working on numerous advertising and editorial assignments, I have been lucky enough to meet all sorts of families. I want to be able to photograph and chronicle some of the more unique as well as the ordinary non traditional families to make sure that future generations know  that gender, religion, race or whatever stigma can never get in the way of Nurture. Family has truly had a radical evolution in this millennium and I want to celebrate this momentum visually. 

About a year after meeting Sarah, I got a call from a mom who booked me to photograph her newborn. When I arrived at her home, her partner and the grandmothers were also present for the shoot. Another confirmation that there was an alternative to the traditional and that family would support their choices.

Susan and Debra have since had another daughter. One is the biological mother of both girls and the other is the physical mom. Both are fun loving, great parents to two beautiful well adjusted daughters.

I studied a Kabbalah for years and through this spiritual journey I came to believe that I was capable of parenting on my own. At this time Madonna and Rosie had already opened up the conversation about alternative families and parenting.  Another woman (and also a celebrity)I met  through my spiritual studies embarked on her journey to motherhood through in-vitro. I was lucky to witness the process through pregnancy to the little angel above I photographed one day when we were hanging with friends. Sandra was getting so much press at the time that I didn't want to be so invasive and ask her to be another subject. I am hoping through this crowd funding to be able to reach out to some public figures that have chosen alternative families. 

When my son was born I joined a mothering group and I met a really great maternal dad who was the primary caregiver to a set of twins. His partner and him are each the biological father to one of the twins. It seemed that the eggs they both fertilized and implanted in the surrogate produced two children who were born as twins but were actually 1/2 siblings!  A truly magical accident that is both fulfilling and unique. 


Jodie was another client who actually booked me shortly after losing her husband in 9/11. She simply wanted to chronicle her love for their daughter and send holiday cards out to reassure her family and friends that they were doing OK. Single motherhood was initially thrust on her through tragedy but society had accepted her status and given her the perseverance create the family she always dreamed of. She had twin boys a few years later through in-vitro and feels her family is now complete.

Single moms by choice are abundant these days, especially in urban areas. In-vitro has made it possible for all types of caring adults to become parents and most countries that let Americans adopt don't care if you’re single or married. Gender, race, religion are no longer factors to creating happy well adjusted families.

My goal is to travel to rural, country, suburban and urban areas throughout the United States so that no matter who or where you are, you will identify with my subjects. This series will inspire those that want to start the journey of becoming a family and educate those have already chosen one of the many alternatives to the traditional. This visual will be one more catalyst to inspire acceptance of all gender, racial, religious and social configurations of “Family”.

Funding for this project will include  a  producer, cameraman, editor, research assistant, picture editor, proof reader (I really need this - I am sure there are many typos in this piece) and other crew members. I need hard drives an archivist and equipment to coordinate time and support in order to concentrate on producing stellar body of work.

I also need funding for , travel, time and fabrication the final images for a gallery show, documentary video and/or a coffee table book. 

I would like to work with a curator and/or a gallery, publisher and/or agent to help with this project so please spread the word to any connections you might have in the industry.  

 I have wanted to do this project for years but I needed to dedicate my time to making a living and now feel that the time has come to create this piece. Please share this with friends and family through social media, email, personal pleas and whatever form of networking you use to connect. 

  • We would love it if you can spread the word about the project - on your blog, Facebook, Twitter, Google+, basically everywhere!
  • You can easily share the news about our project using social tools provided right here on Indiegogo.

If you know or are a unique family, I would love to include you in this project. 

Email me your story sue@suebarr.com  and please include your phone #

story:
For 15 yrs Norte Maar has been at the forefront of producing, facilitating, and promoting artistic collaborations. What a landmark!

No one does artistic collaborations like us! The programs of Norte Maar have highlighted hundreds of artists, choreographers, poets, musicians and more, in Combines and CounterPointes and Site-specific art events.

This landmark programming includes: 

  • CounterPointe - new work by women choreographers and their collaborating artists, in partnership with Brooklyn Ballet and the Actors Fund Arts Center
  • Free Art for Kids - weekly workshops and bi-annual kids exhibitions, in partnership with the Arlington Branch of the Brooklyn Public Library
  • The Brooklyn Performance Combine - a wild mash-up of dance, poetry, music and more in collaboration with The Muse

Norte Maar celebrates the power of the arts to awe, inspire, and educate!

Money being raised in this campaign will support the hiring of a project administrator and general operating support, propelling Norte Maar into the future by focusing on excellent program support and highlighting the organization's legacy.

  • With your donation you might choose the #makemoreart t-shirt or trucker hat or perhaps the ADK mugs made by our friends in the Adirondacks, or choose 2 tickets with reserved seating for CounterPointe April 26-29, and an invitation to the cast party on April 26, or a special treat would be the Guided Studio Tour with the exceptional Jason Andrew.

Hundreds of visual artists, poets, choreographers/dancers, and musician/composers have been a part of Norte Maar, you can too!

You can always support Norte Maar by sharing this campaign, by spreading the word, and by subscribing to our newsletter!

story:
What's The Story?

Hey! My name is Ronnie J Packe, I'm 20-year-old artist and craftsperson currently living in a rural town in Maryland. I've been into art my whole life, from painting and illustration to crafting and print-making. While I am mostly self-taught, I took an AP art class in my senior year of high school, studied under a few local artists and craftspeople, and attended a short summer art course at a local community college. Last year, I pulled all of my work under a collective label that I call witchmoss, and under that name I sell my works, which include illustrations and hand crafted jewelry. I hope to one day expand to sell more of my own creations, but to also work and collaborate with other like-minded artists, and provide spaces for artists and art enthusiasts to gather, learn, and create together.


Why Portland?

I've visited this city a few times, and I find it to be lovely and incredibly inspiring. The whole atmosphere of the Pacific Northwest is very alluring to me. Portland has the feel of a giant neighborhood rather than an overwhelming metropolis. The city is bustling with crafters and musicians, and numerous talented artists. In Portland, and especially the surrounding areas, there is hardly a disconnect from nature- unlike other cities where trees are confined to sidewalk decorations, and a "park" is just a plot of grass. It provides a great source of inspiration, and will definitely be a big change, coming from my small farming community.

(Mount Tabor park in SE Portland, which happens to be an extinct volcanic vent!)


What I Need ~

I'm going to try and raise at least $600, which will be enough to fly me to the city (including luggage), feed me for a little while, and any extra will go to art supplies and possible transportation costs. I've broken it down in an approximate budget like this:
  • ~$220: cost of a one-way plane ticket
  • ~$100: cost of shipping luggage
  • ~$200: groceries/food
  • ~$50: replacing art supplies
  • leftovers: bus or train fare for travel within the city!

What You Receive!

I'm offering a range of perks for your donations, from simple hand-written letters and doodles, to a set of three large custom illustrations. While I definitely appreciate and will put to use any donation offered to me, the perks that come with donations of $20 or more will provide artwork that I plan on using to build up a portfolio! You will receive the original custom artwork, signed and dated, and I will use photographs as samples for resumes and an updated portfolio. Not only is that a great source of motivation, but I can use that to submit my work to galleries in the city.

Some examples of my work are shown below, but you can also check out my website or facebook for more!



The Impact

As a lifelong artist, there is nothing else in the world I could imagine doing with as much passion and love. This is just a small step in my journey, but it could be the most important. Making art isn't all about showing off some talent, but improving your life and the lives of those around you. Art is deeply personally fulfilling, but making art together, discussing and sharing art that you love, these build culture and community. That's something beautiful!


Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe donations aren't your thing- that's totally okay! There are so many other ways to help out, and I appreciate them all the same-

  • Share this page on facebook, twitter, tumblr, public bathroom mirrors, anywhere!
  • Visit my website or my store, stick around~ You might see something you like!
  • Like my facebook page or follow my art on instagram: @witchmossart

But most of all- thank you for your time!
story_txt:
What's The Story?Hey! My name is Ronnie J Packe, I'm 20-year-old artist and craftsperson currently living in a rural town in Maryland. I've been into art my whole life, from painting and illustration to crafting and print-making. While I am mostly self-taught, I took an AP art class in my senior year of high school, studied under a few local artists and craftspeople, and attended a short summer art course at a local community college. Last year, I pulled all of my work under a collective label that I call witchmoss, and under that name I sell my works, which include illustrations and hand crafted jewelry. I hope to one day expand to sell more of my own creations, but to also work and collaborate with other like-minded artists, and provide spaces for artists and art enthusiasts to gather, learn, and create together.Why Portland?
I've visited this city a few times, and I find it to be lovely and incredibly inspiring. The whole atmosphere of the Pacific Northwest is very alluring to me. Portland has the feel of a giant neighborhood rather than an overwhelming metropolis. The city is bustling with crafters and musicians, and numerous talented artists. In Portland, and especially the surrounding areas, there is hardly a disconnect from nature- unlike other cities where trees are confined to sidewalk decorations, and a "park" is just a plot of grass. It provides a great source of inspiration, and will definitely be a big change, coming from my small farming community.(Mount Tabor park in SE Portland, which happens to be an extinct volcanic vent!)What I Need ~ 
I'm going to try and raise at least $600, which will be enough to fly me to the city (including luggage), feed me for a little while, and any extra will go to art supplies and possible transportation costs. I've broken it down in an approximate budget like this:
~$220: cost of a one-way plane ticket
~$100: cost of shipping luggage
~$200: groceries/food
~$50: replacing art supplies
leftovers: bus or train fare for travel within the city!
What You Receive!
I'm offering a range of perks for your donations, from simple hand-written letters and doodles, to a set of three large custom illustrations. While I definitely appreciate and will put to use any donation offered to me, the perks that come with donations of $20 or more will provide artwork that I plan on using to build up a portfolio! You will receive the original custom artwork, signed and dated, and I will use photographs as samples for resumes and an updated portfolio. Not only is that a great source of motivation, but I can use that to submit my work to galleries in the city.Some examples of my work are shown below, but you can also check out my website or facebook for more!The ImpactAs a lifelong artist, there is nothing else in the world I could imagine doing with as much passion and love. This is just a small step in my journey, but it could be the most important. Making art isn't all about showing off some talent, but improving your life and the lives of those around you. Art is deeply personally fulfilling, but making art together, discussing and sharing art that you love, these build culture and community. That's something beautiful!Other Ways You Can HelpMaybe donations aren't your thing- that's totally okay! There are so many other ways to help out, and I appreciate them all the same-
Share this page on facebook, twitter, tumblr, public bathroom mirrors, anywhere!

Visit my website or my store, stick around~ You might see something you like!
Like my facebook page or follow my art on instagram: @witchmossart

But most of all- thank you for your time!

story:
Important Update: Next week we will begin honoring the awards for your generous contributions.  We are happy to announce that we have located a great property in downtown Albuquerque, NM that would be very suitable to housing the BECA (International Center for Art + Design).  It's a space that will need some TLC but we're fortunate to have pledges from volunteers and in-kind donors to help bring a space into a successful fruition.




With the conclusion of this initial IndieGoGo campaign, we have formally launched the BECA ICAD Founders' Wall where you can permanently add your text/images/logos to the physical and online Wall. What we need now is to raise as much support funding as possible to secure and staff the new space, so please join our FOUNDERS' WALL campaign and be as generous as you can and please encourage your friends and colleagues to do the same.  The campaign is one of the most long-term, valuable opportunities for supporters that we're aware of. Read more at: http://www.becaicad.org/makeyourmark.php


Thank you in advance for your support and for helping us to spread the word! 

_________________________________________________________________________________


The BECA Foundation is creating an important component currently missing in the worlds of art + design yet long needed by artists and designers and the global public who benefit from their new art, new design and new ideas...establishment of the world's first large scale facility and multicultural international platform dedicated to the exhibition of new works by both emerging artists + designers as well as other emerging creative producers from around the world.  The multi-cultural exhibition facility, named BECA ICAD (International Center for Art + Design), will showcase future forward works and new innovations from around the world from an interdisciplinary array of emerging talent in the visual arts, performing arts, music and literary arts - film, video and new media - architecture and graphic, industrial, fashion and interactive design as well as from science and the culinary arts. BECA ICAD is being envisioned as a type of United Nations of emerging art + design with different regions of the world featured in an ever-evolving format.



The History of BECA

For the past 3 years, BECA: Bridge for Emerging Contemporary Art, a non-profit, international public arts programming project, has been developing opportunities for both emerging creative producers as well as the participating public via both physical and online formats. BECA has grown an initial network of a couple of hundred people into network that now encompasses an estimated 32,000 members of the local, national and international art + design communities.

The basic formula has been kept simple...emerging creative producers and the public tell us what they want in benefits, opportunities and programming, we listen and then we do our best to deliver.  We serve in this capacity because each time a talented artist or other creative producer gets shut out of the traditional art world party, we, as a society, lose out.  Our collective futures suffer when emerging talent gives up due to the lack of perceived value and adequate support and opportunities not provided to them along the way. BECA has a mission to plug the holes and fill the gaps in the sometimes archaic art world and other similar systems and deliver opportunities to emerging creative producers that support progress, possibility and innovation toward a tolerant, healthy, just and sustainable future for all.  We do not have all of the answers and probably never will. 
We attempt to provide a few alternatives and we’ve enjoyed promising results thus far.

Driven by our core belief that 'New Art + New Design Fuels the Best of What's Yet to Come on This Planet', we've taken stock in what we've learned over the past recent years and are creating a finely tuned long term plan for BECA international public arts programming.  The daily feedback we receive from artists + designers and the public who are engaged in our programming (along with short-term and long-term professional advisors we have been so fortunate to learn from) has been, and will continue to be, invaluable to us.

Even though at some points over the past 3 years our open experiment seemed counter-intuitive to how most planned arts programming achieves success, it has been a necessary prelude for the next steps in this project.  We’ve had to allow for mistakes to be made, lessons to be learned and research to be conducted.  BECA, as it is today, was not planned to be what is has become nor did we consciously plan to invest 3 years of our lives as non-paid volunteer directors.  Sometimes the most important things in life are much larger than the self and these dictate what transpires in our personal lives.  If we are lucky, we listen and then get down to the business at hand.

BECA ICAD

As we now enter our 4th year, we expect to continue to allow for experimentation but we will take the lessons learned, feedback received and advice given to the next level and move forward with a very important next step in facilitating expanded benefits and opportunities for artists, designers and the public. This next step is to establish the world's first large scale facility and multicultural international platform for the exhibition of new works by both emerging artists + designers as well as other creative producers from around the world.  Someone recently termed the next steps as a United Nations of emerging art + design.  A friend recently referred to BECA as a social justice organization creating an international platform giving voice to creative producers from around the world without regard to whom they know or where they came from.  We think both are fitting but what’s most important to remember as we move into 2011 is that emerging creative producers not only deserve our support but that progress and possibility in our futures depend on them succeeding.

We are launching the first phase of our fundraising campaign with the goal of reaching $10,000 (with the hopes of going beyond our set target and reaching $50,000) within the next 30 days. We have several ways of expressing our sincere gratitude for your partnership and support as revealed in the right-hand column of this campaign page. We thank you in advance for your contribution and for helping us to spread the word about the BECA ICAD project.  To date BECA has assisted approximately 300 emerging artists + designers and we've only just begun!  You may view current and also an archive of past exhibitions and projects at www.BECAICAD.org, www.CurateThis.org and www.BECAgallery.com

Thank you for supporting the facilitation and growth of New Art + New Design + New Ideas!

Melissa Roberts and Kurt Schlough, Co-Founders/Directors
BECA: Bridge for Emerging Contemporary Art

Other Ways You Can Help

IndieGoGo has creating some great tools here to allow you to share this campaign with others with an easy click.  We need your voice and your clicks! Each of our efforts combined together will make BECA ICAD the best exhibition facility it can be.  Please spread the word about this campaign far and wide.  If you have any ideas on getting the word out that are not being utilized here, please email us at becafoundation@gmail.com and we'll try to collaborate with you to bring your ideas into the BECA ICAD campaign.  Please also feel free to email us anytime with your programming ideas or if you have a question that's not answered here.

story:
About OperaWorks52 & Mother King

The goal of OperaWorks 52 is to change everything you think about when you think of the word "opera", the plural of the Latin word opus which means "work". We highlight overlooked narratives: the stories of people of color and Native people; of women; of LGBTQ people; the mythologies, truths, and legends of non-European cultures; and a future that is much brighter and inclusive than we have yet to see. We stretch the walls of opera into an elasticity that will never return to its former shape; it will challenge the status quo. To OperaWorks 52, the word opera is not confining; it is boundless.

Mother King is our debut opera project and, after a lot of hard work, we are nearly ready to stage it. We have an ensemble. We have a cast, including Liz Gre, Sarah Greer, Roland Hawkins, Kevin Kaoz Moore, Ava McFarlane, and Michael McDowell. We are honored to have Mischa Santora as our guest conductor, Mackenzie Owens who made the promotional art, and Miko Simmons on site each night of performance to create artistic projections in our space. We have a venue, thanks to a valued partnership with Public Functionary. We have an initial round of financial backing from generous donors in the community. Now, we're back to ask for more help.

Advance Mother King. Please let us thank you.

Mother King's new fundraising goal is $7,800. We raised $200 the first time around. 

You will support the following:

  • $3,500 for our ensemble of principles and instrumentalists;
  • $1,500 for guest conductor and costuming;
  • $800 for poster, postcard, and program printing; and
  • $2,000 for our Public Functionary, our venue

story:
Short Summary

My name is Stefani Scheck. I've been go go dancing in the Philadelphia industrial scene for a little while now under the name Stefani Suffocation. The main event that I go go at is called I Love Industrial and the promoter is now throwing one in Arizona. I would love to be able to get out there and check it out and possibly go go dance for it (if the promoter will have me!). If anything, I would like to expand my industrial scene knowledge to areas outside of the Philadelphia area.
 

What I Need & What You Get

Break down:

  • $400 - Round trip flight from Philadelphia to Phoenix.
  • $200 - Place to stay and for food/drinks
  • $50 - indiegogo fees
  • Perks will be in exchange of listed services or goods.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any little bit helps!

  • You will be thanked and rewarded for any little bit that you can contribute!
  • If you can't help, please spread the word at least! I would love to check out this event.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Landon Wilson; I am an undergraduate student at the Hartford Art School.  The 24 graduating seniors in the Illustration department, including myself, are raising money for our senior exhibition.  After four years of all-nighters drawing, studying, and painting we are ready to put on the show to end all shows!  The apocalypse is upon us and we are ready to show you what it will look like in our exhibition entitled Epilogue!

What We Need & What You Get

In order for us to put on this show we need to raise money to pay for the deposit at the gallery on campus, decorate the space, cater the event, and print and mail out postcards and posters.  Who knew that my $30,000 a year tuition wasn’t enough for this!?!  All jokes aside, the education we are getting is priceless, however, we do need to put a price on this fundraising and although we are almost at our goal we still could use all the donations we can get.  Any leftover money we will use to buy supplies for framing and hanging the artwork.  If anything else is leftover we may throw ourselves a party or use the funds to start us out on our careers; don't worry, we will surely use it wisely!

The Impact

Being an artist is a tough choice.  Not only will your support help us to pay for this show but more importantly it will show us that our hard work is worth it and that art is really meaningful in people’s lives.  For us, this is the end of one journey and the beginning of another.  We don’t know what the world will bring us but we know that with your support we will be a success.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you can donate money or can’t, your support is always appreciated.  If you could share this with your friends, family, and coworkers that would be amazing.  Together we can make it happen!

 

         Samela Aguirre

         Rachel Cohen

          Emily Cole

     Rachel Cutler

          Michele Epstein

          Mo Grogan

     Katie Jennings

          Sarah Jennings

          Erica Lee

          Julia Love Miller

          Hunter Neal

     David Padilla

          Aidi Parker

          Ben Plant

     Rachel Smith

         Lindsey Sniffin

     Joshua Vieira

          Landon Wilson

          Amanda Zenobio

story:
beinghuman

@ Kathmandu International Art Festival 2012

beinghuman is a cross discipline, media & arts collective that supports fair trade in the arts, working with artists who create art for a more positive, peaceful world.  

beinghuman's director: artist, film maker & campaigner Gaynor O'Flynn, needs your help to take the collective to work at this year’s Kathmandu International Art Festival, a not for profit event for social change through the arts.

The artist’s supporting the event have donated their time & work for free but we need to raise $10,000 for travel, expenses & production costs. We will be working, collaborating, teaching & creating new work with local artists from the Nepalese & Tibetan Community in Exile.

You can help for just $1!

Your name will be projected onto Boudhanath Stupa as part of our interactive, installation art work during Kathmandu International Art Festival! Creating good karma for you and others for aeons to come!

You can also buy great art : mp3, ebook, t shirt or limited edition

We also have unique art experiences including actually coming wth beinghuman on this trip of a lifetime.

www.beinghuman.com

 

beinghuman Director, artist Gaynor O’Flynn, is curating the British Chapter of the Festival. Over 100 artists from 75 countries will be taking part in the Festival with over 50,000 attending exhibitions, talks & seminars during the not for profit event.

The festival believes in the power of art for social change. Nepal is one of the poorest countries in the world, half the population lives below the poverty line.

Gaynor has been commissioned to create a unique interactive installation on Boudhanath Stupa, a UNESCO world heritage site. Inspired by the Dalai Lama’s word, ancient wisdom, modern world her vision is to expand on her work "Breath" performed at Kinetica Art Fair this year & to turn their collective voices into circles of light & project the circles on the stupa, literally shining a light on this ancient, sacred site. 

beinghuman will also work with The British Council in Kathmandu on a series of master classes to pass on knowledge & skills to local artists & create new collaborative work.

The art created will be exhibited back in the UK empowering the artists not only to create new cross discipline, cross culture collaborative work, but also to promote & sell their work to a global audience raising much needed funds & exposure for the nuns, artists & Nepal.

All the emerging artist’s in the collective have donated their time for free but we need your help to the raise the $10,000 

We have had such amazing support from established British artist’s: Turner Prize Winner, Richard Long is Patron of the event, Royal Academy artist David Nash OBE & land artist Chris Drury are exhibiting beautiful video works. Award winning photographer Kevin Cummins is creating a site specific work They have been so generous with their work & time & I really hope you can help too

www.artmandu.org

Please spread the word via Facebook, Twitter, blogs, social networks or simply send an e mail to any friends & family you think may be interested.

If you are in London you can meet us & at our fundraising event titled,

Creativity & Sustainability in the Digital Age

@ Google Campus on October 31st

You will also be able to follow our progress on our blog & we will webcast news, events, seminars & exhibitions from the Festival in Kathmandu.

So have a look at the truely great art & unique experiences on offer & please, please help us if you can! This is your chance to make a difference by being part of this unique, positive, ethical art event.

We will thank you, send you photos, footage, links to webcasts, blogs & keep you up to date with every step of this amazing journey. Plus we are creating a moving spiral of text as a unique art work made up of the name of all our sponsors, our multi media way to thank you! We wil also invite you to the exhibition of the work created in Nepal in London next year on 25.05.13.

We need YOUR support to make this happen!

We have had such amazing support from established British artist’s: Turner Prize Winner, Richard Long is Patron of the event, Royal Academy artist David Nash OBE & land artist Chris Drury are exhibiting beautiful video works. Award winning photographer Kevin Cummins is creating a site specific work They have been so generous with their work & time & I really hope you can help too
www.artmandu.org
Please spread the word via Facebook, Twitter, blogs, social networks or simply send an e mail to any friends & family you think may be interested.
If you are in London you can meet us & at our fundraising event titled,
Creativity & Sustainability in the Digital Age
@ Google Campus on October 31st

You will also be able to follow our progress on our blog & we will webcast news, events, seminars & exhibitions from the Festival in Kathmandu.
So have a look at the truely great art & unique experiences on offer & please, please help us if you can! This is your chance to make a difference by being part of this unique, positive, ethical art event.
We will thank you, send you photos, footage, links to webcasts, blogs & keep you up to date with every step of this amazing journey. Plus we are creating a moving spiral of text as a unique art work made up of the name of all our sponsors, our multi media way to thank you! We wil also invite you to the exhibition of the work created in Nepal in London next year on 25.05.13.
We need YOUR support to make this happen!

story:
Dear internationals, check out the English version below!


Das Projekt

Urban Affairs 2016 - the workshop edition

Nach zwei erfolgreichen Festivals 2008/09 erfinden wir Urban Affairs 2016 mit der workshop edition zwar nicht neu, aber anders: größer, kritischer, als Weckruf für die Stadt. Urban Affairs ist kein Kunstfestival im üblichen Sinne: Wir verbringen drei Tage an der Schnittstelle von Urban Art und Stadtentwicklung, jeder Tag bietet ein anderes Programm aus Kunst, Sozialem und Wissen. Von einem selbstironischen Streetart-vs-Graffiti-Battle, über politisches Stadttheater, hin zu Workshops und Vorträgen über soziale, städtische und künstlerische Fragestellungen, sowie der Untersuchung neuer urbaner Wirtschaftsmodelle - es gibt viel zu sehen und zu tun.

Die drei Tage Urban Affairs - geplant für den Kunstherbst 2016 in Berlin - finden an drei verschiedenen Orten statt, die wir gemeinsam mit Experten, Künstlern und Besuchern kulturell erobern wollen. Neben der temporären Besetzung von städtischen Räumen entwickeln wir mit Publikum und Anwohnern Workshops und Konzepte, die sich dem Trend der Gentrifizierung entgegen stellen und das urbane Leben attraktiver machen. Künstlerische Interventionen zur Anregung langfristiger Veränderung - das will Urban Affairs.

Urban Affairs ist unser Weckruf für die Stadt: jeder kann den wachsenden Kulturwüsten etwas entgegensetzen. Das Festival vermittelt Möglichkeiten für die Reaktivierung von Stadtraum. Drei Tage in Berlin regen die Teilnehmer zur Kommunikation mit der eigenen, lokalen Community an - und mit Gleichgesinnten weltweit.

Wir sind natürlich längst in der Planung des Projekts angekommen. Wir haben Großes vor - was jetzt notwendig ist, um das Festival in der angedachten Größe realisieren zu können, ist Eure Unterstützung!

Unterstützer der Kampagne ist smart mit dem Ideenwettbewerb "smart urban pioneers". Zum erreichten Funding gibt es von smart bis zu 25.00€ Preisgeld on Top.

Featured in

Dass Urban Affairs zur richtigen Zeit das Richtige plant, zeigt ein Blick auf die Medienresonanz: Unter anderem berichteten bereits das Stern Magazin, Spiegel Online, Der Tagesspiegel, Berliner Morgenpost, Berliner Zeitung und Bild. Der deutsch-französische TV Sender arte strahlte eine Dokumentation über das Projekt aus. Und jeweils 10.000 begeisterte Besucher der ersten beiden Festival Editionen 2008 und 2009 haben einiges an Mund-zu-Mund-Propaganda erreicht.

Urban Affairs Features

Ein urbanes Kunstfestival erobert Stadtraum als Ausstellungsfläche, schafft temporäre Projekträume im Gentrifizierungsgebiet und sorgt für nachhaltige Impulse für Veränderungen im Stadtbild.

Urban Challenge

Die Herausforderung von Urban Affairs ist die Rückeroberung urbanen Raums und die Neubelebung von vergessenen oder verschlossenen Orten. Es geht darum, soziale Teilhabe des Einzelnen an der Stadt zu stärken und Fragen rund um Stadt und Gemeinschaft zu diskutieren. Dabei dient die Urbane Kunst als Übersetzungsinstrument und als Zugang zu städtischen Themen.

Was bisher geschah

Urban Affairs ging bereits 2008 und 2009 erfolgreich an den Start. Über 10.000 Besucher, eine breite Medienberichterstattung und Unterstützung durch die EU und der Stadt Berlin belegen den Erfolg und verlangen nach einer Neuauflage. Urban Affairs extended belebte im Jahr 2009 ein ehemaliges Stadtbad im Wedding und führte zum Aufbau des Kunst- und Kulturzentrums STATTBAD Berlin. Im STATTBAD wurden zahlreiche Urban Art Ausstellungen und interdisziplinäre Projekte realisiert, viel Erfahrungen in der Projektentwicklung gesammelt und ein breites kulturelles Netzwerk aufgebaut. Diese Erfahrungen sollen nun in neue Ideen fließen - Urban Affairs braucht Eure Unterstützung!

Die Planung von Urban Affairs 2016 - the workshop edition läuft auf Hochtouren. Drei Festivalorte und Themenschwerpunkte sind gefunden, die Auswahl der Künstler und teilnehmenden Stadtexperten ist im Gange. 


Das Programm der workshop edition 2016 sieht in etwa so aus:

Ort: TEUFELSBERG / Thema: SPACE / Tag: 1

Teufelsberg - ein ehemaliger Abhörposten aus der Zeit des kalten Krieges

Eine großartige Location für Workshops und ein Theaterstück rund um das Thema Raum und neue Architektur. Zudem geführte Touren durch die zahlreichen Bilder der Open-Air Ausstellung „Art of Living“

Ort:  MARIENBURG / Thema: PEOPLE / Tag: 2

Marienburger Höfe - ein ehemaliges Umspannwerk im heutigen “durchgentrifiziertem” Prenzlauer Berg

Hier wird gemeinsam gekocht, entdeckt und spielerisch gekämpft: Schnippeldisko, geführte Stadttouren und ein streetart vs. graffiti Battle, bei dem die Kinder den Gewinner küren.

Ort: ZK/U / Thema: CITY / Tag: 3

Zentrum für Kunst und Urbanistik - ein ehemaliger Güterbahnhof

Im Zentrum für Kunst und Urbanistik (ZK/U)  geht es um das Thema Stadt. Das Programm umfasst die Entwicklung einer neuen Hall of Fame mit Live Painting, Workshops und einer Konferenz über Urbanes Wissen


Das sind wir:

Jochen Küpper // Gründer und Festivalleiter

Jochen, diplomierter Kaufmann aus Köln, ist Kulturmanager, Projektentwickler und Vernetzer. Seit 2007 betreibt er mit seiner Agentur RIOTarts aktive Stadtkultur und organisierte die ersten beiden Urban Affairs Editionen. 2009 gründete er in diesem Zuge das STATTBAD Berlin und initiierte zudem zahlreiche urbane Kunstaktionen. 

info@urbanaffairs.berlin

Clara Stein // Künstlerische Leitung und Koordination

Clara ist Kuratorin und Eventmanagerin und arbeitet im ZK/U. Sie interessiert sich für die heutige Bewegung von Künstlern weltweit, zudem für Urban Art und die Einflüsse von Stadt auf junge Kunst. clara@urbanaffairs.berlin

Luisa Traumann // Soziales und internationale Beziehungen

Luisa ist eigentlich Wirtschaftswissenschaftlerin, hat sich lange mit sozialem Unternehmertum auseinandergesetzt und interessiert sich besonders für städtische Entwicklungsprozesse auf globaler Ebene, ebenso wie für soziale Potenziale in lokalen Nachbarschaften. Sie ist Mitbetreiberin der Programmkneipe Kallasch& in Berlin-Moabit.

luisa@urbanaffairs.berlin

Robert Hummel // Wissen und Urbane Studien

Robert Hummel ist Psychologe und interessiert sich insbesondere für Urban Design Prozesse und den wissenschaftlichen Hintergrund zum Thema Stadt und Soziologie.

robert@urbanaffairs.berlin


Das sind unsere Partner:

Urban Affairs 2016 - the workshop edition hat bisher Partnerschaften auf verschiedenen Ebenen aufgebaut:

Location-Partner sind die Marienburg, das neue Team vom Teufelsberg-Gelände und das Zentrum für Kunst und Urbanistik (ZK/U). Alle drei Orte bringen sich thematisch in das Festival ein und sind mitunter im Fokus der Workshops.

Als Partner im künstlerischen Bereich fungieren:

  • Graffiti Lobby Berlin
  • Skateboard Museum
  • Wheel to wheel - Skateboard Kunst
  • Streetartbln - Gallery und Programm Partner
  • B.I.E.R. ev- Funding Partner und AdBuster Ausstellung
  • Widewalls - Gallery Partner

Medienpartner von Urban Affairs 2016 - the workshop edition sind:

  • UrbanShit - Urban Art and Culture Blog
  • Pieces of Berlin - Blog zu Bildern und Eindrücken aus Berliner Straßen
  • ASK Helmut - Event und Festival App, Eventkalender aus Berlin

Euer Geld fließt...

...natürlich in die Umsetzung! Von dem auf indiegogo gesammelten Geld und der Unterstützung durch smart urban pioneers decken wir Künstler- und Wissenschaftlerhonorare, Materialkosten und Personalkosten. Je mehr wir zur Verfügung haben, desto mehr Programm können wir bieten!

Und so könnt ihr euch noch einbringen:
Wir freuen uns über Freiwillige, die bei der Planung und Umsetzung behilflich sind, oder internationale Kontakte, die sich mit uns vernetzen wollen!

///////////////////////////////////////

The Project

Urban Affairs 2016 - the workshop edition

After two successful festivals in 2008 and 2009, the 2016 workshop edition of Urban Affairs explores new shores: It’s larger, more critical, and a wake-up call for the city. Urban Affairs is not your average art festival: We'll spend three days at the interface of urban art and urban development, treating visitors to a changing schedule of art, social topics, and knowledge-focused activities. From an ironic street art vs. graffiti battle and political urban theater all the way to workshops and lectures on social, urban, and artistic issues, to an exploration of new urban business models – there’s plenty to see and do.

Each of the three days of Urban Affairs – set to take place during Berlin’s fall 2016 art season – will feature one of three locations, to be culturally conquered by us, together with experts, artists, and visitors. Beyond the temporary occupation of urban spaces, we will ask our audience and locals to join us in developing workshops and concepts that oppose the gentrification trend and help to make urban life more attractive. In the spotlight: artistic interventions that encourage long-term change.

Urban Affairs is our wake-up call for the city: Everyone can do something to counter the spread of "cultural deserts". Here, the festival communicates options for reactivating urban space. Three days in Berlin inspire participants to communicate with their own, local community – and like-minded people around the world.

Featured in

A glance at our media coverage tells us that we're on to something. We've appeared in Stern Magazin, Spiegel Online, Der Tagesspiegel, Berliner Morgenpost, Berliner Zeitung, and Bild. German-French TV channel arte even made a documentary on the project. And the first two festival editions in 2008 and 2009, attracting 10,000 enthusiastic visitors each, added some great word-of-mouth.

How it works

We've made some excellent progress planning Urban Affairs 2016. Now we need your help to give the festival the impact it deserves!

Beyond the workshop edition, Urban Affairs could be described as

an urban art festival that transforms the cityscape into an exhibition space, creates temporary art spaces in gentrifying areas, and provides impulses for lasting change in the city.

Urban challenge

The main challenge Urban Affairs takes on is the recapture of urban space and the revitalization of forgotten or shuttered locations. It’s all about strengthening social participation in the urban context and discussing questions related to the city and community. In this, urban art serves as a translation tool and an access medium to urban issues.

Situation: now

Two successful editions of Urban Affairs in 2008 and 2009 attracted more than 10,000 visitors, broad media coverage, and support by the EU and the City of Berlin – underscoring the need for a rematch. In 2009, Urban Affairs revived a former public bath in Wedding, which led to the launch of the STATTBAD Berlin art and culture center. STATTBAD hosted countless urban art exhibitions and interdisciplinary projects, gave us plenty of project development experience, and helped us to establish a wide cultural network. These experiences will now power new ideas such as Urban Affairs - and now we need your help!

The planning phase of Urban Affairs 2016 – the workshop edition is in full swing. We’ve pinpointed three festival locations and topics and are currently selecting the participating artists and urban experts. 


The Urban Affairs workshop edition will look something like this:

Location: TEUFELSBERG / Topic: SPACE / Day: 1

Teufelsberg – a former monitoring station from Cold War days – is a fantastic location for workshops and a performance on space and new architecture. These are accompanied by guided tours through the many images of the “Art of Living” open-air exhibition.

Location: MARIENBURG / Topic: PEOPLE / Day: 2

The Marienburger Höfe – a former substation in today’s gentrified Prenzlauer Berg – is a media and print collective.

Here, we invite you to cook together, explore the neighborhood, and put up a good fight: think chopping disco, guided city tours, and a street art vs. graffiti battle whose winner will be chosen by kids.

Location: ZK/U / Topic: CITY / Day: 3

At the Zentrum für Kunst und Urbanistik (Center for Art and Urbanism, ZK/U) – a former train station – the city is at the center of our explorations. The schedule includes the development of a new hall of fame with live painting, workshops, and a conference on urban knowledge.


Who we are

Jochen Küpper // Founder & Festival Director

Jochen Küpper, a trained business manager from Cologne, is a cultural manager, project developer, and networker. Since 2007, he has been promoting active urban culture with his agency RIOTarts while also staging the first two editions of Urban Affairs. In 2009, he founded STATTBAD Berlin and initiated several urban art events. 

info@urbanaffairs.berlin

Clara Stein // Artistic Direction & Coordination

Clara Stein is a cultural manager working at ZK/U. Her main interest lays by the current global art movement, urban art, and the impact of the city on emerging art.

clara@urbanaffairs.berlin

Luisa Traumann // Social & International Affairs

Luisa Traumann is a business graduate with a focus on global urban development processes and the potential of community organization. She also co-owns the bar and venue Kallasch& in Berlin-Moabit. 

luisa@urbanaffairs.berlin

Robert Hummel // Knowledge & Urban Studies

Robert Hummel is a psychologist with a special interest in urban design processes and the fields of urban studies and sociology. 

robert@urbanaffairs.berlin


Our Partners

Urban Affairs 2016 - the workshop edition has already established partnerships on several levels:

Our location partners are the Marienburg cooperative, the new Teufelsberg management team, and the Zentrum für Kunst und Urbanistik (ZK/U). These three contribute to the overall festival theme and feature in our workshops.

Among our artistic collaborators you'll find:

  • Graffiti Lobby Berlin
  • Skateboard Museum
  • Wheel to wheel – skateboard art
  • Streetartbln – gallery and program partner
  • B.I.E.R. ev- funding partner and AdBuster exhibition
  • Widewalls - gallery partner

Urban Affairs' media partners include:

  • UrbanShit - urban art and Culture blog
  • Pieces of Berlin – blog featuring images and impressions from Berlin’s streets
  • ASK Helmut – event and festival app, Berlin-based event calendar
The money you contribute...
...will be used for the realization of the festival, of course! 
Want to get involved?
We're a small team that could definitely use some helping hands, both during the months leading up to the festival and the festival itself. We're also keen on hearing from people around the world interested in collaborating in some creative way, so get in touch!

Location: MARIENBURG / Topic: PEOPLE / Day: 2
The Marienburger Höfe – a former substation in today’s gentrified Prenzlauer Berg – is a media and print collective.
Here, we invite you to cook together, explore the neighborhood, and put up a good fight: think chopping disco, guided city tours, and a street art vs. graffiti battle whose winner will be chosen by kids.

Location: ZK/U / Topic: CITY / Day: 3
At the Zentrum für Kunst und Urbanistik (Center for Art and Urbanism, ZK/U) – a former train station – the city is at the center of our explorations. The schedule includes the development of a new hall of fame with live painting, workshops, and a conference on urban knowledge.
Who we are
Jochen Küpper // Founder & Festival Director
Jochen Küpper, a trained business manager from Cologne, is a cultural manager, project developer, and networker. Since 2007, he has been promoting active urban culture with his agency RIOTarts while also staging the first two editions of Urban Affairs. In 2009, he founded STATTBAD Berlin and initiated several urban art events. 
info@urbanaffairs.berlin
Clara Stein // Artistic Direction & Coordination
Clara Stein is a cultural manager working at ZK/U. Her main interest lays by the current global art movement, urban art, and the impact of the city on emerging art.
clara@urbanaffairs.berlin
Luisa Traumann // Social & International Affairs
Luisa Traumann is a business graduate with a focus on global urban development processes and the potential of community organization. She also co-owns the bar and venue Kallasch& in Berlin-Moabit. 
luisa@urbanaffairs.berlin
Robert Hummel // Knowledge & Urban Studies
Robert Hummel is a psychologist with a special interest in urban design processes and the fields of urban studies and sociology. 
robert@urbanaffairs.berlin

Our Partners
Urban Affairs 2016 - the workshop edition has already established partnerships on several levels:
Our location partners are the Marienburg cooperative, the new Teufelsberg management team, and the Zentrum für Kunst und Urbanistik (ZK/U). These three contribute to the overall festival theme and feature in our workshops.
Among our artistic collaborators you'll find:



Graffiti Lobby Berlin


Skateboard Museum


Wheel to wheel – skateboard art


Streetartbln – gallery and program partner


B.I.E.R. ev- funding partner and AdBuster exhibition


Widewalls - gallery partner


Urban Affairs' media partners include:



UrbanShit - urban art and Culture blog


Pieces of Berlin – blog featuring images and impressions from Berlin’s streets


ASK Helmut – event and festival app, Berlin-based event calendar


The money you contribute...
...will be used for the realization of the festival, of course! Want to get involved?We're a small team that could definitely use some helping hands, both during the months leading up to the festival and the festival itself. We're also keen on hearing from people around the world interested in collaborating in some creative way, so get in touch!

story:
My name is Patrick Guerre and I have been painting for over 20 years. Life has been rather dark with a lack of work and wifes disability over the last few years not to mention the news that surrounds us all. Living on the central coast of California, I took in the beauty and decided to paint brighter works.

I started a new project near the end of 2011 which I call Painting On Others Peoples Trash. It is a work in progress using reused materials to brighten up the world around us all though it has been localized to my community so far. Hopefully you all can help change that and spread these works around to others.

I am currently trying to raise  $500 dollars to continue the project. This will be used for materials to paint on supplies, and fuel to get materials. If none are donated, materials will come from the reuse project of Habitat For Humanity in San Luis Obispo, Ca.

I feel that this project can only brighten peoples spirits. Evn if it is just one person, it is a success. Please help me realize this dream of a brighter future through my art.

I understand in these hard times many can not help with this but at least spread the word. You will make your's, and other's, a brighter world.

I would like to thank maRia from Bali & Beyond

http://www.balibeyond.com/

&

Joshua from Joshua Simas Photography

http://joshuasimasphotography.com/

&

Producer Max Maksimovic

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Pass-The-Salt-Please/165058403542860

For their generous contributions
