story:
Past, present... and future?

When I joined the virtual world of Second Life over 5 years ago, I was a painter showing digital copies of my work in virtual galleries. I immediately saw the potential of this online digital environment for artists, writers and musicians. I have met so many amazing and talented people from all over the world. I have often compared the art community in Second Life to Paris of the 1920s which attracted a similar group of artists, writers, poets and musicians who sought inspiration and an exchange of ideas.


Hi there, Iâ€™m Kristine Schomaker, a Los Angeles based new media and performance artist, painter and art historian. Because of my work with new media, and my projects in which I used Second Life as a medium; My Life as an Avatar and The 1000 Avatars project, I have been very lucky and honored to be invited to create a solo show- an installation/performance at Gallery 825 in Los Angeles opening in May 2012. For my upcoming show I will bring artists together from all over the world, in one space in Los Angeles , using the World Wide Web. I will transform a 700 sq ft gallery space into a 1920â€™s dining room inspired by Gertrude Steinâ€™s salons. Opening night will see a performance involving a dinner party between artists in Los Angeles and Second Life.


Like Montparnasse in the 1920s, artists flock to the virtual world of Second Life to thrive in the creative, imaginative atmosphere where anything is possible. Second Life is fulfilling the promise of inspiration, innovation and experimentation just as Paris did. A community has been created, a lost generation of sorts where expatriates who are unhappy with their world gather and find freedom. Like Duchampâ€™s Rrose Selavy, Identities can be recreated and alter-egos emerge. Pseudonymity and anonymity become prevalent forms of identification. Why be yourself, when you can be someone else?


With your support, I will be able to transform the gallery space into a 1920s dining room. The walls will be lined with 70-100 Avatar portraits in different sizes, printed to look antique and framed in vintage frames. The walls will be painted and aged to a 1920s style. I will be able to purchase a vintage dining room table and chairs, chandelier, rugs and decorations. We will be able to rent costumes for the opening night performance. There will be dinner on the table that night, wine in the glasses and great conversation. I will be able to hire a videographer and editor for the performance as well as buy a projector that will project second life clearly onto the screen. I will also be able to pay virtual rent, costumes, video streaming and a DJ for the extension of the real life gallery within Second Life. I am also going to be hiring an audio/video engineer to create a communication/teleconference system which will allow the real dinner party participants to converse easily with the Second Life dinner party participants.


The Impact:

5 years ago I had no idea how much my life would change. My aunt and uncle had told me about an online virtual world where I could upload digital images of my paintings and show them to people who live all over the world. They were so excited when they met an artist â€˜in personâ€™ and were able to get to know them. Even when you go to a gallery in the physical world you rarely find the artist there.


I initially started showing and selling digital copies of my paintings in my own gallery. Then I was invited to have shows at other peopleâ€™s galleries. Within a year, I had made a name for myself and I was selling 50+ virtual copies of my work a month. I also started to sell the original paintings to people who saw my work in this virtual world.


While working on my Masters Degree I explored ideas of identity and our online representations. It first started on a very personal level looking into the relationship between myself and my avatar. I then did a visual study of other peopleâ€™s avatars looking into why they chose to create the avatars the way they did I took over 2000 portraits to document their diversity and published the avatar portraits in a 2 volume set.


Second Life is an amazing platform for self expression, building community, art, music, education, health and so much more.  I have met with a team at USC who are helping veterans work through PTSD using avatars that allow them to remain anonymous. Many of the major Universities hold online classes within Second Life. Musicians stream music from their home studios into concerts where people from all over the world are able to attend. And artists have formed communities where they gather and share their work, critique, exchange ideas and hang out.


While my paintings are one medium I share in Second Life, I have come to value Second Life as a medium in itself. Exploring notions of identity through my own avatar, who is tall, thin and virtually ideal, I have experienced the amazing potential that virtual worlds offer in helping others. In my project â€œGracie and the Real Girl,â€ I examine media and societyâ€™s distortion of beauty, eating disorders, body image and self esteem.


This show I am creating for May 2012 is going to help blur the line between the virtual and physical world. It will help bring attention to the amazing possibilities of this medium. It is my hope, my intent for people to see how communities can be built, ideas can be exchanged and the imagination can be expanded beyond the 3rd dimension.


After this show, I plan on doing more projects, installations and performances on a more personal level. I want to share our story with others by continuing the dialogue of mediaâ€™s distortion of beauty and its impact on so many lives. I am really looking forward to the opportunities that this show will give me. It has been a rewarding journey in so many ways. Thank you so much for your support and encouragement.


Please help support expression, art and my future:

The estimated budget for this project is $10,000. Besides this crowdfunding site I am also applying for grants and using my savings and credit cards to put this together. So every donation helps out so much.

Please forward this to your friends and family. Share it on Facebook, Twitter, Plurk, Google+. I would love and appreciate your help so  much.

story:
The Goal and Why I Need Your Help

Fine Art Print is expensive, especially if you want to make a high quality Art Print.  
With this campaign I hope to cover all producing expenses and to show my work to a wider audience. 

Rewards

 

Screen Background Description:

2880*1800 px

T-Shirt Description:

190 gms

High quality print

Size: S, M, L, XL

Art Print (Limited Edition) Description:

Limited Edition of 40 + 1AP from the original
Cason Rag Photographique 310 gsm

Size: 16.9 x 23.6 in (43 x 60 cm)
Signed, stamped and numbered by the artist
With a certificate of authenticity

(Art Print without Watermark)

Fine Art Print (Original) Description:

Unique print
Cason PrintMaking Rag 310 gsm
100% cotton with no optical brightness

Size: 28.34 x 39.37 (72 x 100 cm)
Signed and stamped by the artist
With a certificate of authenticity

Originals:

- "Graveyard"

- "Death In The Desert"

- "Silent Shell"

Special Rewards

 

T-Shirt Description:

190 gms

High quality print

Size: S, M, L, XL

Art Print (Limited Edition) Description:

Limited Edition of 40 + 1AP from the original
Cason Rag Photographique 310 gsm

Size: 16.9 x 23.6 in (43 x 60 cm)
Signed, stamped and numbered by the artist
With a certificate of authenticity

Risks & Challenges

Honestly, there aren't many risks! The project is finished and If the campaign is successful all the products should be ready to be shipped by Late May 2019.

Other Ways You Can Help

If there's someone you know that might enjoy this project, please share it with them and spread the word on social media!

Follow me on Instragram to keep updated.


Thank you so much for reading this and  for your support!

story:
About Intra Faction:

IF is a communal love song for a dying world and the collective dream of Nick Demo, Hil Dar and Kristin Mercy. Together they make music-based total art experiences with primitive materials, electronics, homemade midi instruments, bodies, light, projection and interactive technology. 

IF needs your help to develop and produce THE HOLIDAY, two days of multisensorial music, performance and installation held at a secret location in Brooklyn this May-- bringing about transformative visceral, spiritual, and sexual experiences-- generating a positive mass contagion. 

Check out a sample track at:

https://soundcloud.com/intrafaction/satisfaction_if

Mercy, Demo and Hil met at the Performance and Interactive Media Arts Program at Brooklyn College (http://www.pima-mfa.info). Your contributions will not only help make THE HOLIDAY a reality, but will also help them earn their master's degrees this spring.

Your funds will help support:

  • $1500 Technology and design costs and rentals (sensors, cable, computer programs, equipment, projectors, lighting, costume, scenic elements)
  • $1500 - Space rental, insurance, transportation
  • $1000 Paying our production team members (welder, stylists, production manager, production assistants)
  • $600 - Web Design, Media Outpost and Illustrations
  • $400 - Merchandise and Publicity

No heart is too big, no pocket too deep. We are in love with you until we die and then also after that.

story:
Update 9/12:

We did it! We built the Sonic Runway! The project was a big success on playa, thanks to a great crew and all our supporters. There is still a bit of a funding gap, so we launched a new IndieGoGo campaign to help make up the difference. Thank you for your support!

Update 8/19:

We're gearing up to pack the truck for the playa! The structure and electronics are done, and we're busy fine tuning the visualizations. We've got a whole slew of thumping art cars lined up to "plug in" from dusk to dawn!

In fact, the only bad news is that a number of busted parts and unexpected cost overruns have pushed the budget over $23k. While the 'official' campaign is ended, we're still soliciting contributions to help us make it happen. In fact, there are still some really great un-claimed perks, including Charu's amazing oil paintings!

Thank you so much for your help. We can't wait to share the Sonic Runway with all of you who are able to make it. And for those who can't, we promise to get some great photos and video!

The Sonic Runway

Thirteen years ago, we built the original Sonic Runway -- a visualization of music rippling across the desert at the speed of sound. This year, we're completely updating the concept to illuminate the entire spectrum of sound with an all new Sonic Runway!

The first Runway was a corridor of pyramids topped with strobe lights. Every thump from the massive speakers of Sol System triggered a streak of flashes in sync with the sound waves.

The corridor encouraged people to walk its length and experience the speed of sound from all angles.  DJs and other musicians loved playing the Runway because they could see every beat as it travelled across the desert. At the far end, revelers enjoyed watching light race towards them, then hearing the sound at the same time as the light hit them.

Sonic Runway 2016

The all new Sonic Runway will take advantage of the advances in electronics over the last decade. Instead of strobe lights, every gate will be covered with full-color, individually addressable LEDs. This lets us visualize much more than just the beat. 
Instead of pyramids, we are building circular gates. Our goal is to make twice as many as before, so the effect will be smoother and more immersive.

We're also installing the Runway in the open playa and inviting Sound Art Cars to drive up and plug in. When there are no art cars around, we'll have a microphone set up so anyone can play the Runway.

We can't wait to see what YOU bring to this experience!


Help Make it Happen

The Sonic Runway is not funded by Burning Man; we're raising all of the money on our own. We've put in the first several thousand dollars ourselves, enough to cover the electronics for the base station, truck rental, and thousands of feet of cabling, but we need your help to get the Runway to the playa. 

We've got an experienced team of programmers, welders, animators, and audio engineers working hard to build the Runway. Right now, we're busy building steel prototypes, testing lights, and programming all the crazy patterns!

Each illuminated gate, including the steel, lights, diffusers, and electronics, will cost about $500. The more we can build, the cooler it's going to look! Our goal is to build 32 gates. Help us build as many gates as we can!


Perks

Check out our follow up IndieGoGo campaign for the latest Sonic Runway perks.  Thanks for your support!

More Ways to Help

We're truly excited to bring the next generation of the Sonic Runway to the playa.

Help us spread the word and build support for the Runway. Please share our campaign on Indiegogo and “like” our page on Facebook.

Thanks so much for your support!

FAQ


1. How fast is the speed of sound?

The speed of sound is roughly 767 miles/hour or 343 meters/sec. The Sonic Runway is 1,000ft long, so a single beat will travel the Runway in about a second. Of course, the elevation and atmosphere of the Black Rock Desert affects the sound waves, so we tune the Runway lights onsite to be exactly at the speed of sound.

2. Who created that amazing music for the video?

Actually, there are two songs that were used in our crowdfunding video. The one we use to showcase the Sonic Runway LEDs in action was created by Lee Coombs and Kostas G. The overall soundtrack for the video is under a Creative Commons license through freemusicarchive.org, and it's by Signal-to-Noise: "Night Owl".

3. Who created our cool crowdfunding video?

Afonso Salcedo filmed and edited our video through his production company Sutro Studios: http://sutrostudios.com.

FAQ

1. How fast is the speed of sound?

The speed of sound is roughly 767 miles/hour or 343 meters/sec. The Sonic Runway is 1,000ft long, so a single beat will travel the Runway in about a second. Of course, the elevation and atmosphere of the Black Rock Desert affects the sound waves, so we tune the Runway lights onsite to be exactly at the speed of sound.

2. Who created that amazing music for the video?

Actually, there are two songs that were used in our crowdfunding video. The one we use to showcase the Sonic Runway LEDs in action was created by Lee Coombs and Kostas G. The overall soundtrack for the video is under a Creative Commons license through freemusicarchive.org, and it's by Signal-to-Noise: "Night Owl".



3. Who created our cool crowdfunding video?


Afonso Salcedo filmed and edited our video through his production company Sutro Studios: http://sutrostudios.com.

story:
Sometimes  a picture makes all the difference.

I am working on a picture for a special place and need your help to complete it.

Holy Ghost Parish is a church that was founded in 1953 in a multiethnic neighborhood in Albuquerque. The church has a school connected to it and is attended by families, retirees, and single people.  The parish has English and Spanish masses and hosts a Vietnamese festival during the spring. It is a small parish. It is located in my neighborhood.

Last fall I donated and installed a statue to the church to replace statuary that had been vandalized. I often pause in the church to pray and take in the silence it offers.

My project features a dove, the symbol of the Holy Spirit, and that is the painting I am making to grace the entrance of the church. It will measure 6 feet by 3 feet.

My design has been approved by the parish council. The rest is up to donations in order for me to complete the picture.

I am writing to ask you for help. Any donation you give will be greatly appreciated and will be rewarded.

Think of your gift as a pledge and I will reward all pledges with a hand made bookmark or a notecard or an original signed print (depending on your level of support).

Sometimes a picture is more than something to hang on the wall. Sometimes a picture is a welcoming gesture and invokes the quiet mystery of life itself. It is my goal to make such a picture and , with your help, it will be made to serve the fine people at Holy Ghost parish for years to come.

Thank you for your attention to this request. Take care. Peace.

story:
Maison l’art en folie de la Reine soleil (la Reine soleil’s Home of Wild Artistry)

What is the Maison l’art en folie de la Reine Soleil? 

Background of the Project

The aim of the Maison l’art en folie de la Reine Soleil is to provide a safe haven for disadvantaged Haitian children who were traumatized by the 2010 earthquake as well as other natural catastrophes. Young survivors’ recovery would be facilitated through various therapeutic opportunities, particularly through the arts - dance, painting, music, crafts, theatre, storytelling, traditional games, jump up and more. The main objective of this initiative is to help children who have experienced trauma to regain a sense of balance and healing and allow for healthy growth and development. 

The selected approach is a modern form of art therapy where children will be exposed to art in all its guises, ranging from performance art to other types of artistic manifestations.  This would be provided by specialists in the field of art therapy as well as child psychologists. Treatment will be supervised by the project coordinator, child psychologists, artists and volunteers.

 

Why such a project?

Over the past decades, great socio-political instability has led to an unemployment rate of over 70% in Haiti. Furthermore, the massive earthquake of 2010 left a path of destruction in which 350,000 people lost their lives, 600,000 were made homeless, and 200,000 children became orphans. To date, many children continue to live in inhumane conditions and others are either exploited or abandoned. 

 

Throughout Haiti, survivors, particularly children (school- or preschool-aged), show signs of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), which is characterized by anxiety, fear, panic, depression and violent behaviour. An entire generation who has grown up alongside destruction, death, fear and shortages continues to struggle to make sense of its experiences and to find a way forward.  Without adequate support, children risk developing maladaptive behaviours that will affect their capacity to learn and function effectively in society.  It is estimated that more than 2 million children in Haiti suffer from psychological scars left by the earthquake or other catastrophes.

 

In spite of the numerous organizations working to improve the living conditions of Haitian children through health and education programs, insufficient attention has been devoted to their mental health. Consequently, the psychological state of children remains fragile. Addressing this need is the primary focus of Maison l’art en folie de la Reine soleil.

Who is the project intended for? 

 The project is intended for disadvantaged school-aged children (6 to 14) who are survivors of the 2010 earthquake as well as other natural catastrophes and who show signs of trauma. Services will be offered free of charge to these poor families. Given the lack of resources, any attempt to charge a fee would make the services inaccessible to those who need it most. Currently, no other service of this type is being offered to this segment of the population. 

 

Where would the intended clientele come from?

Students attending schools in the most disadvantaged areas will be invited to participate in the program. In addition, partnerships will be established with these schools so that affected children can be identified and referred by educators and other professionals in the field. The Maison l’art en folie will also strive to develop close relationships with other organizations offering services to children who show signs of mental illness.   

 What are the project’s goals? 

 

The Maison l’art en folie de la Reine soleil’s goals include:

  • Giving children aged 6 to 14, with symptoms of trauma, the opportunity to receive therapy from specialized workers in the field of child psychology
  • Provide psycho-education on catastrophes and their consequences
  • Developing, with children, therapeutic tools that will help them find themselves again and regain their childhood
  • Empowering children to choose the type of art that best suits their healing needs  
  • Giving affected children the means to embrace nature again
  • Providing a safe space where children can verbally express their experiences, fears, anxieties and more
  • Giving affected children a safe place to hang out and to be themselves
  • Teaching children to recognize, understand, and manage stress
  • Teaching children to develop a sense of peace, hope and confidence in the future
  • Helping children to learn self-confidence, develop trust, recognize safe relationships and environments, acquire a sense of well-being and allow themselves to be kids again.

 

Project Governance

The management and governance of the Home will be the responsibility of a Board of Directors (President, Vice-President, Treasurer, Secretary, and Directors) that includes residents of Haiti and North America

How will the Home work? 

 In its first year, the pilot project of the Maison l’art en folie de la Reine Soleil, due to initial budgetary constraints and to ensure the quality of the care given, will offer services to about 50 children. A critical goal will be to substantially widen the scope in the second year. A single point of service is planned for the first year, however, the aim will be to expand to Port-au-Prince and its surrounding slums  to reach a greater number of children.

 

Children will participate in the program on a 6 to 12 months basis. Following the recommendations and instructions of the psychologist/evaluator, each child will participate in a custom therapy-through-art program. Throughout therapy, parents will be closely involved in their child’s healing process.

Once the initial therapy program is completed, the children will be re-evaluated to determine their psychological progress. Children who have achieved their mental health goals will be moved to home care, provided by our psychologist, to allow another child to take their place in the program. In this way, the Home can help as many children as possible.

 

Who will be working at the Home?

 

Staff will include full-time and part-time employees (coordinator, psychologists, artists, and volunteers). The Home will also welcome young foreign professionals who are experts in their field and willing to donate their time and knowledge in helping disadvantaged children regain good mental health.

How much money does the Home need to open its doors?

 

The project needs $100,000 to ensure it can function during the first two years.  An initial amount of $65,000 is required to launch the initiative. We rely on your utmost generosity to bring this project to life. The $65,000 received will be distributed as follows:

 

·       Facilities (two years of rent, paid upfront)

·       Furniture (chairs, tables, couch, fridge, stove and more)

·       Office materials (desks, computers, telephone, printer and more)

·       Logistics

·       Transportation for children and parents (to and from  the site)

·       Refreshments (meals, juices, water and snacks)

·       Salaries (8 to 10 staff members)

·       Travel expenses for staff

The Maison l’art en folie de la Reine Soleil aims to open its doors by the second trimester of 2015 and the Home is counting on your generosity to bring this critically important pilot project to life. Your involvement would not only change the future of Haiti’s children, it also has the potential to change the future of the entire country.

 

As your means allow, please become a:

  • Friend – $10
  • Fan – $50
  • Partner – $100
  • Champion – $250
  • Benefactor – $500
  • Angel – $1,000
  • Guardian Angel – $5,000
  • Founding Partner – $10.000

 

** The doors of the Home will always be open to donors or persons who wish to visit, contribute to the project, volunteer, etc. **

**Every donor name will be painted on the entrance wall of the home, so that everyone entering the facilities will know who our wonderful donors are. **

How will the ongoing existence of the Maison l’art en folie de la Reine Soleil be ensured?

 

For the project to be launched and to ensure its survival, the Home will be soliciting the support of government (Ministry of Social Affairs and Ministry of Education) and non-governmental organizations working with children like UNICEF, Save The Children/Aide à l’enfance, Food for the Poor, etc. The Home will also seek financial assistance from religious organizations. Finally, the Home is planning to hold annual fundraising events and will seek donations in Haiti and internationally.

Finally, who is la Reine Soleil? 

 The soul of the project 

 

La Reine soleil, Marie-Monique Jean-Gilles, is originally from Haiti. A multi-talented artist, she uses songs, dance and storytelling to preserve the treasure of Haiti’s oral tradition in her various roles as facilitator, educator, author, and producer and director of children’s films.

Marie-Monique holds a Bachelors degree in Human Relations and Spirituality from Ottawa’s Saint-Paul University and a certificate in Art and Education from Toronto’s York University. She has also studied cultural animation at the Université du Québec à Montréal.

A survivor of the January 12th, 2010 earthquake, Marie-Monique was a horrified witness to the devastation left in its wake. Back in Canada, she vowed to help Haitian children affected by the earthquake and other natural catastrophes who, in spite of their trauma and vulnerability, remain the future light of Haiti. The Maison l’art en folie de la Reine Soleil is the culmination of her efforts.

Maison l’art en folie de la Reine Soleil is but the latest of Marie-Monique’s activities in Haiti, which include:

 

  • Kay Ti Moun arts camp (1,500 disadvantaged children participating during the summer)
  • Humanitarian dental clinic in Borel, in the Artibonite region, in collaboration with Ontario dentists (500 patients to this day), and eye health clinic
  • Founder and manager of a daycare (La Reine Soleil Jardinière) and a training school for at-risk girls (l’École de formation internationale/Nanny School), also in Borel
  • Franco Soleil library in Borel
  • Organizer of the first edition of the Tim Tim Festival Chante ak Mizik pou Ti Moun Festival for children affected and infected by HIV/AIDS (1,500 young participants)
  • Distribution, each year, of meals to patients at Albert Schweitzer Hospital
  • Annual Christmas party for children.
For more info, please contact committee members: 

 

    For more info, please contact committee members:

    Marie-Monique Jean-Gilles, artist, author

    Aniocles Grégoire Artist adviser

    Maryse Bermingham, Master in sociology and a Bachelor degree in psychology

    Winy Fred Bernard, strategic partnerships

    Alexandra Jean-Joseph Communication officer

story:
Festivals can be planned, experiences can not. 

We set our plans for LEAF into motion on a Thursday night last March- and then the people who came took that notion and transformed the land into a natural artistic canvas beyond any of our wildest expectations. The people became LEAF and it was magical.

We started out with a simple concept- let's make a little festival about rock balancing.  The fun of being outdoors and using nature's materials to create sculpture was too intriguing  to pass up.  It was from this little seed of an idea that we evolved the notion of the Llano Earth Art Fest (LEAF)- which would encompass not only rock balancing, but art in all it's forms.  Add some good food, live music, amazing performers, engaging workshops, and a crowd that became immersed in artistic experience themselves, young and old, novice and expert- side by side creating art- and we had the captivating festival that was the first ever LEAF. 

Again, for 2016, we have a plan. We want to recreate the enchantment that was the first ever LEAF, but- we want to make it even more magical.  More music, more art, more workshops, an array of mind blowing performers, a multitude of other activities and surprises and, of course, more awe inspiring earth art installations.

The one thing we don't have to pay for, itself priceless, is the imagination and creativity of the Leaflings. Everything else we plan to do costs money.  From airline tickets and accommodations, more than a dozen musical artists, various performance artists, as well as the more mundane needs such as sound crews, advertising, restroom and washing stations, event literature, supplies, lighting, and security.  The list goes on and on and the expenses are adding up to more than we can hope to raise with bake sales and the like. This is where you, dear donor and potential Leafling, can have an impact and make a difference.

LEAF 2016 will manifest with whatever amount of money we raise- so please be assured that whatever amount you are able to give will be put to use and will make a difference. Our $25,000 goal will enable us to fully realize the fantastic plans that have been in the making since the very first day after the last festival. Please also understand that LEAF has no paid employees and is a not-for-profit organization. The majority of the monies that we raise go into the hands of the various artists that make LEAF the incredible event that it is and which enables them to change the world with their artistic talents.

story:
PERFORMANCE ART SUBVENTIONIEREN

Ende September geht es los. Die Flüge sind gebucht, die Reiseimpfungen gemacht, die Tasche zumindest gedanklich gepackt. Thailand, Performance Art Workshop und Asiatopia Festival; organisiert ist die Exkursion von der Universität Hildesheim.
Bis vor ein paar Tagen wähnte ich mich finanziell in Sicherheit - dann machten mir eine Heizkostennachzahlung und ein aktualisierter Kostenplan einen Strich durch die Rechnung.
Für einen Rückzieher ist es jetzt zu spät, aber um mich nicht total zu verschulden, möchte ich auf diesem Wege versuchen, ein bisschen Geld aufzutreiben. Mit 1000€ wären alle Kosten für die Reise abgedeckt. Aber auch, wenn nicht so viel zusammen kommt, hilft mir das schon sehr weiter!
 

KUNST GEGEN GELD

Leider kann ich euch im Gegenzug nicht an den Früchten dieser Reise teilhaben, da Performances eher flüchtiger Natur sind und sich nicht so gut als Dankeschön eignen. Dennoch möchte ich euch nicht leer ausgehen lassen: Ich habe meine Schubladen durchwühlt und Bilder von den Wänden abgehängt, um euch ein paar meiner liebsten Zeichnungen und Aquarelle der letzten paar Jahre anzubieten. Ob als Postkarte, Druck, gerahmt oder ungerahmt oder sogar als Original ist euch überlassen.
Es gibt kleine (ca A5), mittlere (ca A4) und große (ca A3) Bilder.

Die Kleinen gibt es als Dankeschön in Form einer Postkarte ab 5€, als ungerahmten Druck ab 10€ und mit Rahmen ab 30€.
Die Mittelgroßen gibt es als Postkarte für 5€, als ungerahmten Druck für 15€ und gerahmt für 40€.
Und die großen als Postkarte ebenfalls für 5€, ohne Rahmen für 20€, gerahmt für 60€.
Außerdem gibt es für Beträge zwischen 100€ und 500€ die Originale - allesamt gerahmt.

Bitte seht es mir nach, dass ich erst nach dem Thailand-Aufenthalt dazu kommen werde, die Bilder Rahmen zu lassen und zu versenden zu lassen.

Das hier sind die Bilder:

1.1 form / function [klein]

1.2 no thoughts no title [klein]

1.3 Fabl [klein]

1.4 Krokodil, einen Kopf essend [klein]

1.5 Treppenhaus, kristallin [klein]

1.6 Vermessung I [klein]


2.1 Geburt der Komödie [mittel]

2.2 Vermessung II [mittel]

3.1 Katharsis [groß]

3.2 Chimäre [groß]

3.3 function / form [groß]

3.4 Leeches [groß]

3.5 Spinne / Angst / Perspektivischer Fehler II [groß]

3.6 Akt grün [groß]

3.7 Akt rot [groß]
story_txt:
PERFORMANCE ART SUBVENTIONIEREN
Ende September geht es los. Die Flüge sind gebucht, die Reiseimpfungen gemacht, die Tasche zumindest gedanklich gepackt. Thailand, Performance Art Workshop und Asiatopia Festival; organisiert ist die Exkursion von der Universität Hildesheim.Bis vor ein paar Tagen wähnte ich mich finanziell in Sicherheit - dann machten mir eine Heizkostennachzahlung und ein aktualisierter Kostenplan einen Strich durch die Rechnung.Für einen Rückzieher ist es jetzt zu spät, aber um mich nicht total zu verschulden, möchte ich auf diesem Wege versuchen, ein bisschen Geld aufzutreiben. Mit 1000€ wären alle Kosten für die Reise abgedeckt. Aber auch, wenn nicht so viel zusammen kommt, hilft mir das schon sehr weiter!
 KUNST GEGEN GELD
Leider kann ich euch im Gegenzug nicht an den Früchten dieser Reise teilhaben, da Performances eher flüchtiger Natur sind und sich nicht so gut als Dankeschön eignen. Dennoch möchte ich euch nicht leer ausgehen lassen: Ich habe meine Schubladen durchwühlt und Bilder von den Wänden abgehängt, um euch ein paar meiner liebsten Zeichnungen und Aquarelle der letzten paar Jahre anzubieten. Ob als Postkarte, Druck, gerahmt oder ungerahmt oder sogar als Original ist euch überlassen.Es gibt kleine (ca A5), mittlere (ca A4) und große (ca A3) Bilder.Die Kleinen gibt es als Dankeschön in Form einer Postkarte ab 5€, als ungerahmten Druck ab 10€ und mit Rahmen ab 30€.Die Mittelgroßen gibt es als Postkarte für 5€, als ungerahmten Druck für 15€ und gerahmt für 40€.Und die großen als Postkarte ebenfalls für 5€, ohne Rahmen für 20€, gerahmt für 60€.Außerdem gibt es für Beträge zwischen 100€ und 500€ die Originale - allesamt gerahmt.Bitte seht es mir nach, dass ich erst nach dem Thailand-Aufenthalt 
dazu kommen werde, die Bilder Rahmen zu lassen und zu versenden zu 
lassen.Das hier sind die Bilder:

1.1 form / function [klein]1.2 no thoughts no title [klein]1.3 Fabl [klein]1.4 Krokodil, einen Kopf essend [klein]1.5 Treppenhaus, kristallin [klein]1.6 Vermessung I [klein]2.1 Geburt der Komödie [mittel]2.2 Vermessung II [mittel]3.1 Katharsis [groß]3.2 Chimäre [groß]3.3 function / form [groß]3.4 Leeches [groß]3.5 Spinne / Angst / Perspektivischer Fehler II [groß]3.6 Akt grün [groß]3.7 Akt rot [groß]

story:
Hello beautiful people!

In case we aren't already acquainted, my name is Sarah and I'm a British Artist and Illustrator who lives in sunny Queensland, Australia. During my career, I've illustrated for the likes of Smithsonian Magazine, MAC Cosmetics, L'Oreal Paris, Netflix, Havaianas AU, The British Fashion Council and Stella McCartney. I've been really lucky! I've also exhibited all over the globe from New York and Ottawa to London, Paris and Sydney. Here's some of my artwork:

I'm asking the help of my friends, followers, fans of my work and The Internet to help me realise my latest project - Garbage Pail Politics. It's an illustrated series that pokes fun at the crazy global political quagmire we are steeped in at this moment in time. And I am hoping to print my Garbage Pail Politicians into a sticker series (possibly with bubblegum!) Fellow kids of the 80s my remember the Cabbage Patch Kids - popular dolls that were parodied by Topps Sticker company's Garbage Pail Kids. These 2 childhood relics helped to inspire my own series which includes Trump, Putin, British PM Theresa May and North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un:

So I'm asking for your help to cover print and design costs to bring the series to life! In return - you'll get the printed product - or if politics ain't your bag - a whole host of other Beetson goodies, delivered to your door wherever you are located on the globe.

 

So here's what I need:

To print 2 packs of Stickers plus packaging, 100 packs = approx £350

To print a small edition of 30 Propaganda Posters (Impeach Trump and Maggie May) = approx £150

If I raise the target of £600, I'll have enough to do all of the above.

If I beat the target, here's what will happen to the additional funds:

If I make £750, I'll use the additional funds to extend the print run and make more packs of stickers.

If I make £1,000 - I'll have enough to pay my awesome graphic designer in more than just art - whoop!

After that, my exhibition fees in Melbourne and London (where I'm showing the series), plus flights run into approximately £2,800.

If by some astronomical anti-political miracle I cover all of the above - I would donate additional funds to the following charites:

The American Civil Liberties Union

The Bar Pro Bono Unit (UK)

Amnesty International

If I don't reach my goal, I can still use the funds raised to make a very small run of stickers and posters - so whatever we raise will see fruition of the Garbage Pail Politicians series.

I'm becoming a dab hand at this... 

I've previously funded 2 separate crowdfunders, both successful in getting my projects off the ground. In 2012, the I funded the printing of 2 decks of playing cards, and in 2014, my dream artist residency in Coney Island.

I am confident I can make this happen again, with your incredibly appreciated help!

You can still help even if you can't donate 

By sharing this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, to your friends and family, and shouting about it everywhere - you are still helping me infinitely - cash or no cash!

Thanks for reading and here's to 'Trumping' political BS with ALL of The Colour and The Love and The Art!

P.s Thank you to my nephew Wynton and nieces Etta and Millys for adding a breath of fresh air to this campaign and giving me hope for the future!

story:
The long and short of it is that Graduate School is an expensive endeavor. I want my MFA because I believe it will make me a stronger artist and more able to be competitive in the contemporary art world. I want my MFA so that nothing can stand in my way of getting a full time teaching position when I decide that is to be part of my art practice. I want my MFA so I can get some focused critique of my work and build a group of peers that I'll be able to rely on in my future artistic life. While these things are important, it's unrealistic to ask artists to take out loans equal to those of medical students. 

SAIC's Fiber & Material Studies program is the best textile program in the country. I'm told it's the most difficult department to get into at the school, and here I am, one of 11 incoming graduate Fibers students. I can't turn down this opportunity, and yet I'm faced with taking on more debt in an economy that shows no sign of creating jobs for all of us oh-so-educated 20-somethings.  This is where you come in. Crowd source funding offers you the unique opportunity to fund things you believe in and helps support people and ideas in a way that has a direct impact. 

I want to thank you ahead of time, for taking an interest, for your contributions and support, or for taking five minutes out of your day to take a look at my site or to spread the word. As with all things collaborative, I can't do this without a community of people to back me up.

story:
Who are we?

We are a bunch of burning man veterans that have participated in many projects over the years.  Theme camps like Xara, The Red Nose District, and Homojitoville; aerialist performances at Center Camp and the Temple of Flux; volunteering at Play Info, Ice Camp and Center Camp Cafe.  This year we want to turn two golf carts into art cars that play off of this year's Cargo Cult theme and our own camp: Gaylactic Invaders.

By day our fleet of planes will be ferrying people around the playa in cargo boxes that can seat up to 4 guests each.  Certainly nothing odd about these planes, even if they do look like they are made from bamboo?  We're not aliens!  At night, EL wire, lasers, and LED lighting reveals the true nature of the beast as we abduct humans and tranform them into interglactic love slaves!

 

Why We Need Your Help

It's a ton of work to modify a vehicle into something fantastic, and when you finish, you have to haul it to the playa and then back.  We have the dream, the time and the will, but we need specialized tools, materials, and (the biggie) transportation.  We need your help to ensure the project gets finished as we labor to turn THIS:

 

...into THIS:

 

Where is the money going?

*Repair:  we have already purchased two golf carts, but they need some TLC to make them playa worthy such as new batteries, some engine work, and some brake work.

*Fabrication:  metal welding for the framework, bamboo for the covering, and the purchase of lightweight trailers for the cargo box frames.

*Lighting:  each plane will have EL wire in a circuit-like pattern, LED spotlights, and lasers.  These are both aesthetic, but also for safety at night.

*Costuming:  All pilots and flight attendants will be in ET Airline uniforms.  

*Transportation:  We have a trailer for the carts, but we need to rent a truck with a high tow capacity to get them from San Diego to Black Rock City, and then back.

 

Swag/Perks

To thank you for your contributions we are creating some great SWAG, including hand crafted backpacks, blinky gear, and costume pieces.

 Gaylactic Invader Glowing Dog Tags and Mugs

  

 

Alien Friend Backpacks

 

EL Necklaces

 

Boot Covers and Cloaks courtesy of Wish Wear

 

 

6' Tall Blinky Walking Staffs

 

Note:  We would prefer to give you the swag on the playa, so we can thank you in person for your contribution.  If you are not going to the playa, or would prefer to have your swag mailed to you, let us know and we'll work it out.

 

How Else You Can Help?

Please tell your friends to contribute!  Share our Indiegogo campaign on social media and spread the word.  We could also use your help BUILDING the cars!  If you are in San Diego and can pitch in, visit our camp page or send an email to us here.  We will send you info about our build days.

story:
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

What is Cooper Studios?-

Cooper Studios is a student led registered not for profit organization in partnership with Empty Shop community interest company. 

Sofia and I (Christian Cooper Ellinas) have set up this campaign alongside our 20 artists and members because we are all seriously passionate about art and the amazing atmosphere a creative space produces, and we wish to ensure Durham city and University become actively involved in art.

We are both students at Durham University where there is no art degree or course. Access to space to create art is therefore extremely limited and often non existent. There is a serious demand from the student body for an art studio and after six months of building our organization and acquiring members we are ready to ask for your support.

But we also want to set up a student run community art centre dedicated to supporting art among the local community, allowing us to give back to the city we stay in during our academic studies.

We have set our minimum goal at £3,200 pounds. If we are able to raise more than this figure the additional money will be used to increase the amount of workshops/ facilities we can provide and ensure Cooper Studios remains a permanent feature of Durham City by helping fund our second year of operation.

Our key aims: 

  • We aim to end the three year gap students must make from developing their practical skills and portfolios. This is a serious problem which has faced me when applying for jobs and projects in the art job sector as I have not had the facilities to carry on my work whilst studying. This is also an issue all of our members have raised. 
  • Cooper Studios is designed to also be a community art centre and studio. Every Saturday we will be running free workshops for different groups in the local community encouraging them to engage with art and learn new skills. We will also be offering free studio space to members of the local community which revolves around an online rota system. 
  • These workshops and studio spaces are specifically designed to support young disadvantaged members of the local community who either have an interest or talent in art but lack the materials and facilities to build up a portfolio from which to launch themselves into an Art college or profession. We will however be providing workshops and events for other groups such as elderly groups, youth groups and charities. 
  • To host professional exhibitions, art installments, performance art events, guest talks and life model classes open to everybody.

How the student membership works:

Members from the student body will be able to access the top floor of the space to work on their art, outside the hours of any community activities that we will be running, for an annual fee. This will therefore generate stable income helping us afford a property from which to launch our community engagement factors. The student members will be sharing the communal studio space with the members of the local community using our free studio space system, whilst also leading or designing the weekly workshops. We currently have (as of 02.03.2014) 23 members and are still growing! But this still does not generate enough, at the present, to cover the whole of the rent and bills.

Cooper Studios believes that our members combined with our organization have the ability to really improve the art scene in this beautiful city and provide a suitable platform to aid the artistic community but we can not do this without you. 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------                   

What We Need & What You Get-

We need your help! 

We require £3,000 pounds to help pay the £4,500 rental and annual bills of a property in the heart of the city centre which is very close to the bus station making it accessible as possible to those from the outskirts of the city. A £1,000 portion from the funding will be used to equip the studio/ workshop rooms with furniture and stock of materials for our workshops. 

We have already independently raised £1200 through sponsorship and business awards but this is not enough for us to set up and will be used to support the materials budget, legal fess and insurance.

All of your generous funding from this campaign will go directly to supporting groups and individuals in the local community who require support and also a group of students dedicated to art and setting up an integrative arts centre.

For your contribution there are some amazing things up for grabs, including original art from our Pilot project (the video above) and also the chance to have bespoke paintings created for you by our talented members. Do not miss out on these limited and one off gifts!

‘The "Hatfield Trust" is delighted to support this new "Art Studio" initiative with £400 which will provide a much needed base in the city  for student and community participation in fine art’.

*Please share this campaign, via Facebook, Twitter and email, as far and wide as  you possibly can with friends, family and colleagues to make sure we raise enough funding to really make a difference!

And recommend any groups in Durham and the surrounding areas to get in touch to see all the ways in which we can work with them!

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------      

All of us at Cooper Studios would like to thank you all for your support and donations. We would also like to thank Durham Creatives and Empty Shop.org for your guidance, support and mentoring over the last five months, without you this would not have been possible!


For more information or to meet all of our members see our webpage: http://christianellinas.wix.com/cooperstudios 


-Cooper Studios

story:
This project has been sucessfully funded, thanks to our contributor support!

Books are now for sale at the Eric Losh Illustration Store


"The Chorus of Kibale" is a children’s book (ages 8+) about a young Redtail Monkey named Kibale. Her wild nature gets her separated from her monkey troop in the African rain forest. During a journey through the forest she meets many other primate animals—from Chimpanzees to Bushbabies—that teach her how to listen to find her way home.

Book Website: www.TheChorusOfKibale.com


The story is set in Kibale National Park, in Uganda, Africa. Its lush rain forest, swamp, and grassland habitats are home to an orchestra of wildlife. The animals are often hidden among the foliage, but exciting part of the Kibale Forest is not so much what is seen, but what is heard! There are a cacophony of sounds that emerge from all levels of the rain forest—from birds, insects and a record density of primates—that can often only be encountered by ear. This book explores those sounds, and the creatures who make them.

 


I have had a lifelong passion for illustration, conservation and rain forest wildlife, but I was particularly inspired to create The Chorus of Kibale after first visiting Kibale National Park in Western Uganda in 2009. It was there that I had my first encounter with a troop of Redtail Monkeys during an evening meal. I also camped in a treehouse overlooking a swamp, listened to bird calls, searched for nocturnal primates by flashlight, and trekked for wild Chimpanzees through the dense tropical rain forest—all which helped to inspire the scenes and characters from this book.   

I am excited to finally share this book with fellow primates around the world!

Eric Losh Illustration: www.elosh.com

I want to produce a first edition publication of The Chorus of Kibale. Copies of this book will help teach readers about the importance of listening and teamwork, as well as the value of wildlife diversity in the African rain forest. I also want to share my love of wildlife with readers worldwide, and foster support for environmental conservation to young readers.

To carry out these conservation education goals, I have partnered with two non-profit organizations that work in and around Kibale National Park, Uganda: the North Carolina Zoo's U.N.I.T.E. for the Environment, and the globally-connected Primate Education Network. Proceeds from books sold and contributions from this fundraising campaign will contribute toward the organizations' ongoing conservation education initiatives.



U.N.I.T.E. for the Environment (part of the North Carolina Zoo) is a program that works with ten grade schools around Kibale National Park to promote long-term conservation education projects, as well as raise awareness and appreciation of the park's wildlife through teacher trainings, curriculum support, and classroom field trips. 

Your support will help to bring this book and other educational materials into grade schools as part of units on biodiversity and wildlife conservation.

 


The Primate Education Network is a global network dedicated to connecting and empowering primate conservation educators. The network creates opportunities for educators to receive training, build relationships and collaborate, and share resources and best practices to deliver successful primate conservation education programs.

Your support will benefit Primate Education Network's (PEN) small grants programs for primate conservation educators.


Additionally, I will be taking a trip to Uganda in September to re-visit Kibale National Park. After four years working on this book, the ablility to have copies of this book on-hand to distribute to local conservation education organizations around Kibale will make for quite a meaningul "bookend" to this artistic and professional endeavor.


I need your support to help fund the first edition publication of The Chorus of Kibale!
Each contribution level comes with its own rewards: from the book itself, to goodies like fact cards, art prints and even a few original paintings!
story_txt:
This project has been sucessfully funded, thanks to our contributor support!
Books are now for sale at the Eric Losh Illustration Store






"The Chorus of Kibale" is a children’s book (ages 8+) about a young Redtail Monkey named Kibale. Her wild nature gets her separated from her monkey troop in the African rain forest. During a journey through the forest she meets many other primate animals—from Chimpanzees to Bushbabies—that teach her how to listen to find her way home.
Book Website: www.TheChorusOfKibale.com



The story is set in Kibale National Park, in Uganda, Africa. Its lush rain forest, swamp, and grassland habitats are home to an orchestra of wildlife. The animals are often hidden among the foliage, but exciting part of the Kibale Forest is not so much what is seen, but what is heard! There are a cacophony of sounds that emerge from all levels of the rain forest—from birds, insects and a record density of primates—that can often only be encountered by ear. This book explores those sounds, and the creatures who make them.



 

I have had a lifelong passion for illustration, conservation and rain forest wildlife, but I was particularly inspired to create The Chorus of Kibale after first visiting Kibale National Park in Western Uganda in 2009. It was there that I had my first encounter with a troop of Redtail Monkeys during an evening meal. I also camped in a treehouse overlooking a swamp, listened to bird calls, searched for nocturnal primates by flashlight, and trekked for wild Chimpanzees through the dense tropical rain forest—all which helped to inspire the scenes and characters from this book.   I am excited to finally share this book with fellow primates around the world!



Eric Losh Illustration: www.elosh.com

I want to produce a first edition publication of The Chorus of Kibale. Copies of this book will help teach readers about the importance of listening and teamwork, as well as the value of wildlife diversity in the African rain forest. I also want to share my love of wildlife with readers worldwide, and foster support for environmental conservation to young readers.
To carry out these conservation education goals, I have partnered with two non-profit organizations that work in and around Kibale National Park, Uganda: the North Carolina Zoo's U.N.I.T.E. for the Environment, and the globally-connected Primate Education Network. Proceeds from books sold and contributions from this fundraising campaign will contribute toward the organizations' ongoing conservation education initiatives.


U.N.I.T.E. for the Environment (part of the North Carolina Zoo) is a program that works with ten grade schools around Kibale National Park to promote long-term conservation education projects, as well as raise awareness and appreciation of the park's wildlife through teacher trainings, curriculum support, and classroom field trips. 
Your support will help to bring this book and other educational materials into grade schools as part of units on biodiversity and wildlife conservation.
 


The Primate Education Network is a global network dedicated to connecting and empowering primate conservation educators. The network creates opportunities for educators to receive training, build relationships and collaborate, and share resources and best practices to deliver successful primate conservation education programs.
Your support will benefit Primate Education Network's (PEN) small grants programs for primate conservation educators.Additionally, I will be taking a trip to Uganda in September to re-visit Kibale National Park. After four years working on this book, the ablility to have copies of this book on-hand to distribute to local conservation education organizations around Kibale will make for quite a meaningul "bookend" to this artistic and professional endeavor.



I need your support to help fund the first edition publication of The Chorus of Kibale! Each contribution level comes with its own rewards: from the book itself, to goodies like fact cards, art prints and even a few original paintings!

story:
The Reason

I am IAYON noemind - a channel, a sage, a lightworker, an evolver, a bringer of the light- it is my mission to share with the world the energy of UNCONDITIONAL LOVE & LIGHT - through the format of digital art, I have been all over the united states performing LIVE digital painting with other producer dj's. It is my mission to share this vision world wide. It is a restoration process of the divine masculine and feminine energy. I invite everyone to reflect the divine with in.

The Impact

Through the creation, and co-creation of healing, reiki, energy light work in the digital format of art, on an archtype level, balance is restored. Just as the audio waves produce and effect the overall vibration of a person and place, As does the visual programing.


What's Need & What You Get

Any little bit helps- Upon any donation, you will be added to a list which will receive a free print of my art (as soon as its in production this spring) I appreciate in advance anyone who's taken the time to read this far and consider a donation.. It's not a very high goal, I believe in the come-Unity...


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! If you are buying a ticket to envisionfestival.com - then put in the code

IAYON11

on your ticket order and I will get credit... that will help with airfare just as much as financial donation would.


thank you- INfiite blessings of love and light <3




Live Digital Painting by IAYON Noemind (Jesse Noe)

http://www.makingcontact2012.




Iayon [pronounced] eye•on \ I•yawn: Third eye On. I yawn. When you yawn, it is a reminder to breathe. 

When you breathe deep conscious breaths, you turn your third eye on.


Noemind [pronounced] no•mind \ know•mind: All Heart = no mind. When thinking stops. BEING takes over.


Iayon Noemind (Jesse Noe) is an up and coming LA based artist who is transmiting the light everywhere he goes. His visionary approach to a dream with in a dream provokes higher states of consciousness. The intention behind his creations is calling forth unconditional love, healing energy, and restoration of all imbalances on this planet, and all dimensions everywhere. 


The alchemical art of Iayon has made its way around the country performing with producer DJ's (random rab, heyoka, nastynasty, vibesquad, martyparty, etc) He has been featured in magazines, blogs, and has created album cover art for many musicians. Having his art displayed in fine art galleries such as the Temple of Visions (Los Angeles) and Tribe 13 (Ukiah, CA), Iayon has proved himself to be an emerging artist in the visionary world.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Summary

I'm a Seattle-based writer and photographer. My current project examines ornamentation traditions in India, and how these styles of dress are altering because of globalization.

I want to document these traditions traditions and changes by interviewing and photographing women in both cities and villages, and will travel to India for four weeks to do so.

With your donation, I will be able to put together the two media of visual photography and audio interviews to best explain the story of these changes in women’s adornment.  

What We Need & What You Get

The $4500 raised will contribute to:

A roundtrip plane ticket from Seattle to Mumbai 

Transportation within the country 

Translator fees 

Audio equipment rental for the 4 week journey

Food and lodging costs

If goal is not reached, the trip will be shortened to 2 weeks, and take place in fewer regions.

The Impact

There are three distinctive moving parts to my project- photographs, audio interviews, and scholarly research. It is my mission to understand the history behind women’s ornamentation in India, how it has altered over the generations to the distinct dress we see today, and how globalization has played a role in these changes.

By documenting this photographically and pairing the imagery with first-hand interviews, I aim to gather a cohesive, cross-disciplinary story of globalization’s affect on Indian women’s adornment with which to share and educate the public.  

Women have strong traditions of adornment practices, and their stories, passed from mother to daughter, are changing in the process. Their stories, some centuries old, need to be told.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that some people cannot contribute monetarily. An awesome way to show your support is by spreading the word on various social media sites like Facebook and Twitter, or with friends and colleagues face to face. Thank you!

story:
Help!

Hi, my name is Peter and this is my 1964 Cadillac Sedan DeVille. I've had this lovely American "land yacht" for about 11 years now. I purchased it on eBay in 2003 from a kid who bought it from the original owners. I never intended to drive the car very much because she needed work. However, I didn't even make it 75 miles from the pick-up spot in southern Oklahoma before a transmission-related problem ended the journey to Houston. Nearly a thousand dollars and a week later I was able to limp her home. I puttered about with her over the ensuing years but mostly she was garaged, waiting for her day to shine.

A couple years ago I pulled her out and tried to replace her leaking water pump. I thought I could do it because my dad was a mechanic (he taught me a few things) and I inherited his tools. As reasonable as my aspirations were, I broke a bolt off in the engine block while removing it and suddenly was left with a problem beyond my ability. As life would have it I couldn't afford to fix her, so there she sat for another two years, stuck on a flat tire, baking in the scorching Texas sun and drowning in our torrential rains. To say that her gold-and-white paint suffered during this time would be putting it mildly.

Early November last year I thought I was in a position to finally do her right, so I had her towed to a trusted shop for repairs. I thought I could get her back before Christmas but I was naive: fixing a 50-year old car like this is like opening a can of worms. When the shop finally got around to assessing the car in April this year I was floored with the result. Whatever I had saved (and then spent during a period of unemployment earlier this year) was peanuts. Here's a list of the major work needed:

  • water pump, timing chain, and all the rusty, broken bolts involved
  • carburetor rebuild (or replacement)
  • exhaust system, and all the rusty, broken bolts involved in that
  • wobbly drive-shaft
  • major tune-up and all the deferred maintenance
  • dead window motors and dry-rotted seals
  • sagging rear springs
  • tires and safety inspection
  • ruined seats and carpets
  • proper wheels

Please fix me.

It's not her style but if she could talk she'd ask for your help because:

  • a classy automotive gal like her likes all the attention she gets
  • she actually has low miles and a good body
  • she's got plenty of life left in her motor
  • she's cool because her air conditioning was fixed early on
  • she's tired of sitting
  • they don't make'm like her anymore

What I need

The $1,500 or so I budgeted for the water pump and broken bolt repair was woefully inadequate. A good shop takes time to do good work, and all of that is expensive. My primary goal is just to get her reliably road-worthy, so I can put off things like the interior work and proper wheels. And as bad as the list is a restoration actually isn't required. (OK, that would be great but I'm realistic.) Nonetheless, all the mechanical work listed above is now pushing past $5,000 and I just don't have that; that's why I need your help. She can be a beautiful cruiser again. I don't want to lose her!

Anything over the goal that the campaign garners will be set aside for maintenance and later work. Thanks for reading until the end.

 - Peter

story:
Short Summary


A Jewish woman on a mission... to tell the stories of Jewish women across America. Contribute today, and join me in a journey of discovery, art, and life.

We don't always think about how multi-faceted and deeply layered the people around us are. What would happen if we took the time to look a little deeper, and get to know the women who make up our communities? That is what I intend to do through the Women of Valor project. 

I am Gracey Levine, a Portland based artist with a passion for storytelling. The project will seek to highlight the uniqueness and diversity of Jewish women in America through storytelling and portraiture.

With this project, I am hoping that Jewish women across America will be able to reflect, learn, and recognize themselves within their own community. Those who participate in the project will have the pleasure  of being a part of documented Jewish history. 

What We Need & What You Get

I am hoping to raise $18,000 towards this project. A third of that amount will go towards the cross country road trip, to take place in August of 2014. It will cover renting a car, gas, lodging, and meals, as well as supplies. This month long journey will allow me to meet Jewish women across America, and get their unique stories first hand, while laying the foundation for the following 6 months- the creation of the paintings and book. 

The last 2 thirds of the funding goal will go towards 6 months of art creation- 44 paintings, countless refined sketches, processed photos, and transcribed interviews. The costs for this period included canvas, paint, framing, brushes, studio rent, and living expenses for the duration of the project. This isn't a 'moneymaking' venture for me, I just want to be able to devote my time to this project and see it to it's completion with my full attention.

Contributors will receive a number of benefits at different levels, including a 'Thank you!' printed in the book, custom sketches, or even a custom painting. They will also have the peace of mind of knowing they have become a patron of the arts, and are supporting the creation of a snapshot of Jewish women in America today.

The Impact

This project is more than just a series of paintings. It will be a comprehensive look at Jewish women in America, celebrating our collective strengths and the unique qualities we all possess. 

The Woman of Valor project will give women the opportunity to tell their own stories, as well as providing a mirror for the rest of us, to look back and see a piece of ourselves in the women who are featured. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Getting the word out about a project like this is so important! Pass this on to people you think would be interested in participating, or contributing! Use the handy share links and spread the love!

story:
Help Me Build My Dream!

I've spent many years helping others heal...now I need to focus on a new kind of healing. I want to build a garden art studio where I can explore the healing power of gardens, art, and a combination of both!

What I Need & What You Get

Your support will help me accept the offer of a lovely space in a lovely garden, where I can focus on creating beautiful images, assemblages, and blessings. I need room for breathing, for reading, for growing and making, surrounded by calm and the growing things that inspire me so much. 

The ten thousand dollars raised will pay for the foundation and construction of the exterior including windows, door, roof, siding and electricity,  all professionally built to spec. on land that is already cleared and waiting. The interior will involve a barn-raising kind of party using many recycled materials to create a tree-house themed interior workspace and fill it with garden art supplies, seeds, paints, plants and other comforts, and the chickens will be my nearest neighbors.

Help me share  my vision with others! I am offering fairy doors, macrame clothes-hangers, original photography and hand-painted blessings, all hand-made by me in thanks for your support. 

    You have the power to help! Every little bit gets me closer to my goal...

    I have overcome many obstacles in my life, and it is important to remember that we don't all have to do everything alone...we can help one another to heal and grow. Let's make something beautiful together.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign!
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share and connect with  friends and family.

    8-26-14 Update:

      After one day on line I have reached 20% of my goal. This is a wonderful surprise for me but I am sad that my good friend, Audrey, just passed away today. She is one of the great friends that spurred me on this healing journey and we made plans to invite her to the new homestead to enjoy the garden and art together when I finished building.

       I have cared for her community garden during the time she was too ill to work on it herself. Last year we were able to get out into her garden together and have some garden fun. But this year she just couldn't seem to get healthy enough to get out into her garden with me.

      I will miss her shoulder to cry on; when I started this healing journey we met each other at the Palo Alto Farmer's Market one Sunday and both of us having had a really challenging week, proceeded to cry loudly in public while hugging each other tightly. It's so nice to have a friend who doesn't mind crying with you in odd places.

      I'll be posting pictures of her garden in the gallery section. Look for "Audrey's Garden" in the descriptions of the photos.  Thank you all for your support. Rita Morgin

She is one of the great friends that spurred me on this healing journey and we made plans to invite her to the new homestead to enjoy the garden and art together when I finished building.    I have cared for her community garden during the time she was too ill to work on it herself. Last year we were able to get out into her garden together and have some garden fun. But this year she just couldn't seem to get healthy enough to get out into her garden with me.   I will miss her shoulder to cry on; when I started this healing journey we met each other at the Palo Alto Farmer's Market one Sunday and both of us having had a really challenging week, proceeded to cry loudly in public while hugging each other tightly. It's so nice to have a friend who doesn't mind crying with you in odd places.   I'll be posting pictures of her garden in the gallery section. Look for "Audrey's Garden" in the descriptions of the photos.  Thank you all for your support. Rita Morgin

story:
My first solo show

I have been given the honor and privilege to have my very first solo show at Discourse Gallery in North Adams, Massachusetts at the end of July. 

I am an artist who focuses in printmaking, collage, book arts, and etched glass.  I hope to express through my work a sense of realization of mortality as well as the loss of memory. I toy with reality of the past, its fiction, the tension between the two, and how it is capable of leaving us suddenly. 

What you can do to help

I am extremely tight with funds, but it has been my dream to have a solo show. The more funds I get, the more work I will be able to show. I'm asking for funds for supplies to create new work, as well as for presentation (matting, framing, etc) and transportation from Long Island, NY to North Adams, MA. 

What you will get in return

Every contribution, from the smallest to the largest, gets something in return. Whether it be a personalized Thank You card, a batch of your own blank cards, or even a small print, I will make sure to provide something for everyone's generous donations. 

Other ways you can help

Spread the word! Share this link via Facebook, Tumblr, Twitter, Instagram, or any other form of social media. It would mean the world to me. 

Thank you! 

Sincerely, 

Monica Chulewicz
