story:
PROJECT SUMMARY

May 29, 2014 will be the 100th anniversary of the sinking of the Empress of Ireland. The passenger liner bound for Liverpool slammed into the Norwegian collier Storstad in a fog in the St. Lawrence river and sank in 14 minutes claiming the lives of 1,012 people. This little known shipwreck was one of the worst maritime disasters of all time.

Carlton Films plans to build a memorial wall in the form of a ship’s hull to commemorate the Empress of Ireland disaster. The wall with its jagged edges and twisted metal surface -  a bit like the steel hull of the Empress of Ireland after the Storstad penetrated its outer skin - will be engraved with the names of the victims and the survivors of the disaster.

RESUME EN FRANCAIS

Le 29 mai 2014 sera le 100ième anniversaire du naufrage de l’Empress of Ireland. Le paquebot Empress of Ireland est entré en collision avec le charbonnier Storstad dans un brouillard dans le fleuve St-Laurent au large de Rimouski et a coulé en moins de 14 minutes entrainant vers le fond quelque 1,012 personnes.

Les Films Carlton ont comme projet de construire un mur dédié aux victimes du naufrage. Le mur ressemblera à une coque d’un bateau avec une paroi en métal ébréché et tordu par une grande force - un peu comme le coque en acier de l’Empress of Ireland écorché par la force inouie du Storstad. C’est sur ce mur qui seront inscrits les noms des victimes et des survivants.

(version française en bas)

                                                               ***

WHO WE ARE

Carlton Films is a Canadian film distributor who will be helping to finance and promote the Empress Wall while simultaneously releasing the movie Wreck of the Empress in May 2014. This is not the usual kind of disaster movie, but a reflective human and courtroom drama played out on the eve of WWI. The movie tells the story of the captain of a transatlantic passenger liner who ran his ship into a Norwegian collier in a fog killing over a thousand people. It is the story of a woman who survived the disaster losing her husband, a Salvation Army musician, and her boy whose body she has to fight to recover. And finally, it presents the moral dilemma of being true to oneself and at the same time loyal to the company, during a Commission of Enquiry opposing a multinational in the transport industry and a tiny Norwegian coal-hauling firm.

The movie is now in preproduction and will be shooting the enquiry scenes in the old Quebec courthouse on St. Louis Street in Old Quebec. It was there that Lord Mersey and the Canadian judges attempted to determine who was to blame for changing course in the fog in 1914.

Carlton Films was founded in 2004 to distribute films and TV programming in Canada. The company recently purchased Canadian and world rights to the movie Wreck of the Empress which will be delivered in the spring of 2014.

The president of Carlton Films is Nicholas Kinsey, a prolific and multi-talented film director, who has been a successful director of photography, a scriptwriter, a film editor, and a producer over a long career. Kinsey is a Canadian of English origin (dual citizenship), born in Ontario and raised in England. His director credits include several new features: Tree Line (2012), Killing Ruth - the Snuff Dialogues (2011), Leatha Acidents (2011), Short Change (1989), Women Without Wings (2002) and the TV drama series Cottage in America (2012).

THE GOAL

We want to build a memorial to help the families remember their lost parents, aunts and uncles, brothers and sisters. A thousand men, women and children died that night in the fog on the St. Lawrence river. Today the offspring of those people now number over a million people.

Many of the passengers were first generation Canadians and Americans on their way back to the old country for a visit. Their deaths provoked long periods of unhappiness and changed the course of their children’s lives. This is why we want to provide a site where  the families can come together, to remember the event and to communicate with one another.

 THE DESIGN

The Empress Wall in the form of a ship’s hull with a visible tear in its skin and engraved with the names of the victims and the survivors of the shipwreck will impress on the mind of the public how the Empress of Ireland ship was rammed by the collier Storstad in 1914 and caused a colossal loss of life. The Norwegian ship tore into the Empress with enormous force, backed up by a load of some 11,000 tons of coal. It’s bow cut through the steel plate of the Empress like butter.

The wall will be approximately 20 feet by 10 feet high and a corner of the structure will show the twisted metal surface and jagged edges caused by the collision. The metal skin will be stretched over the support structure and engraved  with the names of the some 1000 victims, 400 survivors, passengers, crew, sponsors, etc.

The names will be arranged in alphabetical order on the thin metal skin (copperplate or other material) for easy consultation. There will be an interactive video and an electronic message centre for visitors to the site. Family members will be able to leave messages about their loved ones so that others can read their stories. There will also be a short video about the fabrication of the wall.

 The Empress Wall will be mobile since it will be installed on an aluminium base on wheels so it can be moved about easily. Furthermore, it will be modular in design allowing easy installation and shipping overseas when required.

THE UNVEILING CEREMONY

On May 29, 2014 the Canadian and Quebec governments will commemorate the Empress of Ireland disaster in the Quebec City port area. At this ceremony Carlton Films will unveil the Empress Wall to a large public gathering of representatives of Quebec City, the City of Liverpool, the City of Glasgow, the Consul General of Norway, several historians of the CPR history, and journalists from the US, Canada and Britain.


A TRAVELLING MEMORIAL

The Empress Wall exhibit will travel to various cities in Canada , Britain and the US during the year of 2014. We expect the Merseyside Maritime Museum in Liverpool will request the exhibit and other museums such as the Massachusetts Maritime Museum in Boston, the Maritime Museum of the Atlantic in Halifax, the Riverside Museum and the Clydebuilt Scottish Maritime Museum in Glasgow, the Waterfront Museum of Toronto, etc. The home of the exhibit will be Quebec City and we will be looking for a permanent installation at perhaps the Musée de la Civilisation or at another place in the city.

THE EMPRESS LEGACY

For some 80 years, Empress passenger liners travelled the oceans of the world, linking Liverpool to Quebec City and New York, Vancouver to Hong Kong, Yokohama, Sydney and Auckland. The Empress ships belonged to the Canadian Pacific Steamship line, a branch of the famous railway empire and were built on the Clyde in Scotland with Liverpool as their home port. Empress ships offered the ultimate experience in trans-Pacific or trans-Atlantic travel and so the Empress name is still today a familiar symbol in Canada, Britain, Australia, and New Zealand where numerous families travelled on CP ships.

HOW WILL WE USE THE FUNDS

We estimate the cost of the memorial including materials, support structure and the electronic message centre at approximately $750,000.  The cost breakdown is as follows:
Conception: $50,000
Design: $150,000
Support structure: $150,000                
Metal skin & engraving: $250,000
Video about the construction: $40,000    
Interactive video: $60,000
Administration: $50,000

We will finance some 70% through government contributions, sponsor funding, and movie promotional funding. We hope to finance the remaining 30% through private donations and crowd funding.

WHAT YOU GET FOR YOUR SUPPORT

You are a vital part of this project and you will be regularly updated as to the progress of work on the memorial. We have developed a range of gifts for our supporters: mini-posters, t-shirts, bumper stickers, digital downloads and DVDs of the movie Wreck of the Empress, free tickets to movie premieres and VIP invitations to the unveiling of the Empress Wall at the opening ceremony on May 29, 2014.
             
CHECKING ON PERKS

After the campaign, we will send you updates as to delivery dates for your perks. DVDs won’t be delivered until May 2014.  The same goes for tickets and VIP invitations. Other merchandise will be delivered before the end of 2013.

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR READING THIS - WE TRULY APPRECIATE YOUR INTEREST IN OUR PROJECT

If you want to know more about our work, please visit our website www.empresswall.com or click her to go to our facebook page.

                                                         ***

VOIR TEXTE EN FRANCAIS

QUI NOUS SOMMES

Les Films Carlton sont un distributeur de films de long métrage qui vont financer et promouvoir le projet Empress Wall et simultanément lancer un film Wreck of the Empress dans les cinémas canadiens au mois de mai 2014. Ce film raconte l'histoire d'un capitaine d'un grand paquebot transatlantique qui a frappé un petit charbonnier norvégien dans un brouillard causant la mort de plus de mille personnes. C'est l'histoire d'une femme qui a survécu au désastre laissant derrière elle un mari, musicien de l'Armée du Salut, et un petit garçon et qui doit par la suite se battre pour récupérer son corps.  Le film présente le dilemme moral entre le faux témoignage et l'infamie des patrons lors d'une commission d'enquête mettant en opposition une grande compagnie multi-nationale dans l'industrie du transport et une petite firme norvégienne transportant du charbon sur la côte est.

Les Films Carlton ont été fondé en 2004 afin de distribuer des films et des émissions de télévision dans l’est du Canada. Le président est Nicholas Kinsey, un réalisateur de films qui a été tour à tour directeur-photo, scénariste, directeur technique et metteur en scène de long-métrages sur une longue carrière dans l’industrie. Kinsey est canadien d’origine britannique (double citoyenneté). Il a réalisé plusieurs longs-métrages incluant Tree Line (2012), Killing Ruth - The Snuff Dialogues (2011), Leatha Acidents (2011), Women Without Wings (2002) et Short Change (1989) et la série dramatique Cottage in America (2012).

Le tournage de l’enquête se fera l’an prochain dans l’ancien palais de justice de Québec sur la rue St-Louis dans le vieux Québec. C’est là que Lord Mersey et les juges canadiens ont tenté de determiner qui était coupable d’avoir tourné son bateau dans le brouillard en 1914.

Pour promouvoir le film, les Films Carlton ont le projet de construire un mur dédié aux victimes du naufrage. Le mur ressemblera à un coque d’un bateau avec une paroi en métal ébréché et tordu par une grande force - un peu comme le coque en acier de l’Empress of Ireland pénétré par la force inouie du Storstad. C’est sur ce mur qui sera écrit les noms des victimes et des survivants.

Le mur sera installé dans un édifice public ou dans un musée pour souligner le 100ième anniversaire avec une vidéo montrant le travail de fabrication et les noms qui apparaissent sur le mur. L’exposition sera prêtée aux musées qui le demandent. Carlton prévoit déjà l’envoyer à Liverpool et à Glasgow où le navire a été construit. À long terme la compagnie prévoit trouver un lieu permanent dans le port de Québec.

L’OBJECTIF

Nous désirons ériger un monument commémoratif afin d’aider les familles à honorer la mémoire de leurs disparus puisque quelques milles hommes, femmes et enfants sont morts cette nuit-là dans un brouillard sur le Saint-Laurent. Aujourd’hui leurs descendants représentent plus d’un million de personnes.

Plusieurs des passagers étaient des canadiens de première génération qui se rendaient visiter leurs familles dans les vieux pays. On peut imaginer les drames vécus par ceux qui restent, le vide laissé par les disparus et tous les malheurs qui en ont découlé. C’est pourquoi nous voulons fournir un endroit où on pourra se recueillir, se souvenir et échanger.

SPÉCIFICATIONS TECHNIQUES

Ce monument dans la forme d’une coque de bateau avec une déchirure dans sa paroi et gravé des noms des victimes et survivants du naufrage va rappeler de façon éloquente comment le paquebot Empress of Ireland a été enfoncé par le charbonnier Storstad en 1914 et causé une perte colossale de vie humaines. Le bateau norvégien Storstad a enfoncé l’Empress of Ireland avec une force énorme puisque le Storstad transportait quelques 11,000 tonnes de charbon. Sa proue a enfoncé l’acier de l’Empress comme un couteau dans du beurre.

Le mur ou la coque du bateau mesurera approximativement 20 pieds par 10 pieds de haut et un coin du mur aura une forme tordue avec une bordure ébréchée. La paroi sera une feuille en métal tendue sur un cadre de support et la surface sera gravée avec les noms de quelques 1000 victimes, 400 survivants, des passagers et membres de l’équipage, et des commanditaires.

Les noms vont apparaître en ordre alphabétique sur la mince feuille de métal (possiblement du cuivre ou sur un autre matériau). De plus, il y aura une video interactive et un centre des messages pour les visiteurs. Les familles pourront laisser des messages ou des témoignages pour permettre à d’autres de lire leurs histoires. Il y aura également une courte video sur la fabrication du mur.

L’ Empress Wall sera mobile puisque il sera fixé sur une base en aluminium avec des roulettes pour permettre de le déplacer facilement. De plus, le mur sera modulaire pour faciliter l’installation et le démontage pour l’expédition outre-mer lorsque nécessaire.

LA CÉRÉMONIE DE COMMÉMORATION

Le jour du 29 mai 2014, les gouvernements du Canada et du Québec vont commémorer le naufrage de Empress of Ireland dans le port de Québec. Lors de cette cérémonie, nous prévoyons dévoiler le Empress Wall devant un grand public comprenant les représentants de la Ville de Québec, de la Ville de Liverpool, de la Ville de Glasgow, du Consulat de la Norvège, les historiens du CPR bien connus, et les journalistes des États-Unis, du Canada et de la Grande-Brétagne.
  
UNE EXPOSITION QUI SE DÉPLACERA

Le Empress Wall se déplacera dans différents villes canadiennes, en Angleterre et aux États-Unis pendant l’année 2014. Nous comptons que le Merseyside Maritime Museum de Liverpool nous le demande et que d’autres musées le réclament tels que Massachusetts Maritime Museum de Boston, le Maritime Museum of the Atlantic de Halifax, le Riverside Museum et le Clydebuilt Scottish Maritime Museum de Glasgow, le Waterfront Museum de Toronto, etc.

Le port d’attache de l’Empress Wall sera la Ville de Québec et nous allons chercher à l’installer de façon permanente soit au Musée de la Civilisation ou dans un autre endroit dans le port de Québec.

La paroi sera une feuille en métal tendue sur un cadre de support et la surface sera gravée avec les noms de quelques 1000 victimes, 400 survivants, des passagers et membres de l’équipage, et des commanditaires. Les noms vont apparaître en ordre alphabétique sur la mince feuille de métal (possiblement du cuivre ou sur un autre matériau). De plus, il y aura une video interactive et un centre des messages pour les visiteurs. Les familles pourront laisser des messages ou des témoignages pour permettre à d’autres de lire leurs histoires. Il y aura également une courte video sur la fabrication du mur.L’ Empress Wall sera mobile puisque il sera fixé sur une base en aluminium avec des roulettes pour permettre de le déplacer facilement. De plus, le mur sera modulaire pour faciliter l’installation et le démontage pour l’expédition outre-mer lorsque nécessaire.LA CÉRÉMONIE DE COMMÉMORATIONLe jour du 29 mai 2014, les gouvernements du Canada et du Québec vont commémorer le naufrage de Empress of Ireland dans le port de Québec. Lors de cette cérémonie, nous prévoyons dévoiler le Empress Wall devant un grand public comprenant les représentants de la Ville de Québec, de la Ville de Liverpool, de la Ville de Glasgow, du Consulat de la Norvège, les historiens du CPR bien connus, et les journalistes des États-Unis, du Canada et de la Grande-Brétagne.    UNE EXPOSITION QUI SE DÉPLACERALe Empress Wall se déplacera dans différents villes canadiennes, en Angleterre et aux États-Unis pendant l’année 2014. Nous comptons que le Merseyside Maritime Museum de Liverpool nous le demande et que d’autres musées le réclament tels que Massachusetts Maritime Museum de Boston, le Maritime Museum of the Atlantic de Halifax, le Riverside Museum et le Clydebuilt Scottish Maritime Museum de Glasgow, le Waterfront Museum de Toronto, etc. Le port d’attache de l’Empress Wall sera la Ville de Québec et nous allons chercher à l’installer de façon permanente soit au Musée de la Civilisation ou dans un autre endroit dans le port de Québec.

story:
1975 - Nomadic No More.

My name is Erich Lehman, owner/curator of 1975. I started out merely as an art appreciator, longing to be as talented as the friends around, and then became a collector, first with art from those very same friends and eventually reaching out to collect work by any artist that inspired me. It was over the course of 10+ years that I built my own collection and eventually wanted to help expose these same talented artists to a community that might otherwise overlook them and facilitate other potential art collectors who perhaps just didn't even know where to begin. I think art can and should be a part of everyone's lives; it enriches life in ways that often are not easy to describe.

Since 2008, I have operated 1975 as a nomadic gallery in Rochester, NY. My original goal for the project was to last one full year, and before I knew it, three and a half years have flown by. During that time, I've worked with over 75 artists, from fledgling local talent to internationally known artists, showcasing many to a community that did not know they exist. 

In early 2012, the opportunity to put down roots and establish a formal gallery in the heart of downtown Rochester unexpectedly presented itself to me. 

The building is located right in the heart of downtown Rochester, just behind The Little Theatre and Restuarant 2Vine just off the corner of Charlotte St. and Pitkin St., in what Rochester locals would remember most recently as the former Little Bakery Building. You can see the location on Google Maps here.

With this next step, I want to create a proper gateway for Rochester, one that connects with other galleries in the US and abroad to share our local artists and to expand upon what is possible. 

1975 has been my labor of love since the beginning, but I need your help to take it the next step further.

 

What We Need:

1975 has been self-funded since the beginning, building off of $500 and existing off whatever is left over after the artists and expenses are paid. I've used freelance design work to help with costs during this time as well, but to make this huge leap, I need you!

Right now, the expense to renovate the inside of this new space is hovering around $7500 to get it up to code and set up to host art shows. I am charging ahead to meet this goal, but the expense of renovation is much more than I had anticipated. Like I said, this opportunity came up unexpectedly!

The sole purpose of this fundraiser is to raise funds towards those renovations costs. 

I intend to open the doors by mid-July 2012.

 RENOVATIONS INCLUDE (but are definitely not limited to):

  • ADA approved restroom facility
  • New flooring (the current one needs a lot of love!)
  • New electrical work for the whole building
  • Gallery lighting
  • Improved walls to better facilitate art display
  • A fresh coat of paint for everything.
  • A host of other minor renovations.
  • The cost of labor for the professionals!

 

What You Get:

Much like anything in life, I could never ask this of you without offering something in return (other than awesome, inspring art shows, of course!) Wherever possible, I've worked with local businesses and artists to create unique rewards that speak to what 1975 is all about. 

Justyn Iannucci, who sold his first piece of fine artwork at 1975's By The Pale Moonlight three year anniversary show, is designed a limited edition shirt commemorating this new phase in 1975's life as a reward. (image down below)

EvenOdd Creative will be pairing up with some of my colleagues from the Sweet Meat Co. to create limited edition bags in two styles as well as creating more affordable co-branded supporter bracelets, all from upcycled materials.

In addition to the bags, Lea Rizzo and Sarah C. Rutherford, two artists who were in 1975's very first show Inauguration. in 2008, along with Saint Monci, who joined the 1975 family about a year later, have offered up their amazing skills to do custom commission works as higher-tier rewards. 

Update 6/2/2012: Mr. Prvrt, also from the Sweet Meat Co., will also be creating some of these amazing bags!

PLEASE NOTE! Due to the limits on the number of perks, we can only offer one artist commission at a time. If you are interested in this reward, please contact me at erich@1975ish.com to specify which artist, and I will tailor the reward individually.

I myself will also be creating a series of pieces celebrating my own love of skateboarding and Rochester and offering them as rewards.

You can also donate in smaller increments; anything over $5 will get a handwritten note from me (if you want it) and a small sketch.

I'm also working on a few other perks to fill in the price gaps and will update this as I can! We can only offer 12 thorugh this Indiegogo at a time, so new rewards will be added as others sell out. Please keep in mind each reward level includes the cost to produce and ship the reward! 

 

For more on the artists:

www.justyniannucci.com

www.evenoddcreative.com

www.saintmonci.com

www.sarahrutherford.net

www.artbylea.com

www.mrprvrt.com

www.sweetmeatco.com

 

The Impact

I've spent the last three and a half years celebrating artists that I believe in, both in the local community and from all parts of the world. Being able to lay down roots in a proper space like this will enable me to celebrate these artists and a host of others I've wanted to bring in to Rochester. I want to help make Rochester an art destination for a niche of artists that are near and dear to my heart, and to share their amazing talents with all of you.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are tough, and I understand if you yourself cannot contribute to this fundraiser. However, I do ask that you share this campaign through your own networks, be it Facebook, Twitter, etc. to get the word out! Indigogo itself has a whole host of sharing tools right through this page, please use them! 

 

IMAGES OF REWARDS:

THE WRISTBAND
Image coming soon, please reference EvenOdd Creative to get an idea of the style.  


THE SHIRT

Graphic celebrating the construction of 1975 Gallery by the inimitable Justyn Iannuci. Please check out www.justyniannucci.com to see more of his work!

 

OH ROCHESTER series 2 original artworks
Pieces pictured are from Series 1, but pieces created will be very similar to those pictured, with varying wear and stickering. 

 

THE HOLCOMB ARTIST TOTE
Image coming soon, please reference EvenOdd Creative to get an idea of the style. Final product will vary based on the artist's work.   

 

THE KINNEY V2 ARTIST MESSENGER BAG
Image coming soon, please reference EvenOdd Creative to get an idea of the style. Final product will vary based on the artist's work.  

 

These rewards are brought to you with the amazing collaboration of EvenOdd Creative and the Sweet Meat Co. Please visit their sites to learn more!

 

      

 


UPDATE: DAY 1! - 5/31/2012

You guys have blown my mind!
We reached $3010 dollars before 24 hours were up! THANK YOU!!

Due to the huge demand for the Oh Rochester! pieces, I have made 12 more available as a perk for a grand total of 24 (two dozen). Each one will be completely unique and one of a kind. I can't wait to break out the scroll saw again!

Thank you for the amazing support from the bottom of my heart!

 

UPDATE: DAY 3! 6/2/2012

In just three short days, we've gotten within $1300 of our goal of $5000! Your support is amazing! 

To make room for some new rewards (our limit is 12 at a time), I'm going to "hide" anything that gets sold out. For example, if you bought one of the original 12 "Oh Rochester!" pieces, I'm going to hide that sold out reward and show a new one from the artist Mr. Prvrt (also from the Sweet Meat Co.). But rest assured, all your information has been collected and you'll receive your perk!

So, friends . . . can you do it? Can you help me reach the $5000 mark by the end of the weekend? We're so close!!

Also: If you are interested in the artist commission, please contact me prior to selecting so that we can specify which artist in the perk!

 

UPDATE: DAY 5! 6/5/2012

It's only been five days, and you amazing, astounding people have helped me reach my $5000 goal! I am blown away by your support!

So what next? There's 32 days left in fundraiser, and still quite a few perks open (with the option to make more!), I'm going to see if we can cover the entire cost of the renovations through this campaign with anything extra going to putting on even better shows than before.

Thank you for believing in 1975 and what I'm trying to accomplish in Rochester. My heart is absolutely swelling with happiness!

story:
Short Summary

I will keep this simple. My name is Gregg Deal. I am a member of the Pyramid Lake Paiute Nation, and the artist behind The Last American Indian On Earth. Recently I got an article in the Huffington Post and have been gaining some ground on the already exsisting documentation of this ongoing performance piece. In the excitement, I have had a number of people inquire about being able to contribute to this project. It is ongoing, which means I am still working on it, and will continue to work on it. By means of photography and video, I am compiling enough information to produce a short film about this project and the social implications of it. Any money going into this is coming out of my own pocket or through donations. This campaign is here for you to donate, support, or share as it continues. 

What I Need

Donation funds go to the following:

  • equipment
  • travel (gas, food, tolls, etc.)
  • materials/props
  • fees associated with film production
  • general support
There are a few goals in place, and these donations will most certainly contribute in that. I would like to get to some other cities like NYC, Boston, and even West coast cities. 

The Impact

So much of this project is about Indigenous people and the way people interact with them and perceive them. While my set up is 'hyper-percieved', it still illustrates the point from all sides. As a social project this becomes invaluable in being a clear indication about the tone and attitude towards our nation's Indigenous, thus beginning a dialog concerning race relations between Natives and non-Natives.

What You Get

There are a number of incentives listed below. In addition to the performance work, I am a working artist. I have a number of existing pieces and also take commissions if there is something I do that you like, or would like me to create. I work as an artist full time and can do custom work, just let me know!

Other Ways You Can Help

Donations are obviously helpful, but you are not required to give your money in order to support. I am a full time working artist, and I have existing works available and am always accepting commissions. Additionally, there is always more to do than just giving money, buying my art or commissioning me for something. There are a slew of links below that show the progress, the goals, the interaction and even ways to get involved listed below. Share, like and engage!

Twitter: @Last_Indian

Facebook: /TheLastAmericanIndianOnEarth

Instagram: thelastamericanindianonearth

Foursquare: last_indian

Email: TheLastAmericanIndianOnEarth@gmail.com

Gregg Deal art: http://www.greggdeal.com

Gregg Deal Twitter: @the_lame_sauce

Gregg Deal Instagram: @thelamesauce

Gregg Deal Facebook: /greggdealart

Shout Outs and Accolades

Huffington Post: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/03/gregg-deal_n_3844624.html?utm_hp_ref=arts

Indian Country Today: http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2013/09/04/last-american-indian-earth-public-displays-nativeness-151150

story:
The story

I want to move to Norway, and I want my fiancée to come with, for this I need moneys, so I'm hoping there are some friendly people-lovers/love-encouragers/art-enablers out there that would be able/willing to donate us some money, in exchange I will make you an art, the bigger the donation, the more time I will spend on your art!

To sum up a long story, I recently got engaged to my soul-mate, he is the one that makes me complete, and now every minute away from him is painful. 

Unfortunately, the timing could have been better. Having lived away from my homeland (Norway) for near 6 years now, I had been planning to move back this April-May to be closer to my family, to see my little brothers grow up, to be around for my niece and nephew, to be able to help my ageing granny, and generally be around more for when my mum/stepdad/dad/stepmum need someone to help out. 

I've had to sit and watch from afar too many times now, when one of them has had to go into hospital, and there has been nothing I could do to help.

For me it's not too much of a problem, my family between them can scrape up my air fare, and what little belongings I have would likely fit in my luggage or be donated to the local charity shop, however to fit two people into a life in Norway, the requirements are slightly higher, like needing a room, a bed to fit us both, a chance to get a job, etc.

Basically, we need to be established enough that we can live without being a drain on the system, and get jobs to support us both within 6 months, so that he doesn't have to leave the country.

TL;DR

Donate money to fund two young creative souls in love, receive personalised art.

The art, and the options

Examples of what to expect from my art:

THESE are some of the requests I have done so far in my life, 
THESE are some of my pieces of art done of my own will, or for contests, or school
THESE are some more of my drawings/paintings.

There are more, but I have a tendency to give them away before making a digital replica for everyone to see.

What tools I will be using to create these arts:

Pencils (for sketches, or full detail pencil/charcoal/graphite drawings)
Pastels (look something like this)
Markers (look something like that)
Watercolours (look something like tits)
Acrylic and misc paints that I have lying around, or Mixed media, of varying kinds.

IF YOU FEEL LIKE DONATING A RANDOM AMOUNT AND WANT SOMETHING NOT MENTIONED IN A PERK, let me know I will happily do variations to suit you. 

What We Need & What You Get

What we will spend the contributions on:

  • £0-20 Art supplies (We have most of these, so will only be if we run out).
  • £0-00 Shipping to get the art to your eyes.
  • £400-700 Shipping all our important belongings to Norway, so that we'll be able to go about day-to-day things without being kicked out of the country.
  • £250-350 Getting there, plane tickets + coach to&from the airport or coach to France and interrail passes to trek the whole journey on train.
  • ~£650 Paying off the remains of debt, bills and phone contracts in the UK.
  • ~£106 A months worth of bus travel pass so we can apply for all the jobs, and get to and from work with reasonable ease (it's green and more importantly neither of us drive or can afford a car).
  • £40-1400 Course/lessons/books for learning Norwegian (One of us knows it, but not in a teaching capacity).

If we don't make our target:
Paying off debts are the priority, so neither of us get into financial trouble long term. After that is done with, we'll be selling off everything of sentimental value, all our electronics, and anything we may be able to re-buy in a few years time, once we have a steady income, we'll be travelling by the cheapest available mode of transport, currently plane, but if we don't scrape together enough money soon, interrail will be cheaper.

If we exceed our target:
Shipping non-essentials like our bikes, the little sail boat that could, our double bed+matress, not selling our camera and instead taking it with to take all the pictures, buying my granny a nice thank you gift for being epic and renting us her spare room.


What you get in return for helping us:

  • Personalised piece of art, made by me, to your specifications.
  • Virtual hugs.
  • Much gratitude.
  • Such Love
  • <3

Other Ways You Can Help

Upvotes, karma, sharing etc, anything that makes this reach more people, so that we can reach Norway with a realistic chance to get jobs, and not get deported.

The storyI want to move to Norway, and I want my fiancée to come with, for this I need moneys, so I'm hoping there are some friendly people-lovers/love-encouragers/art-enablers out there that would be able/willing to donate us some money, in exchange I will make you an art, the bigger the donation, the more time I will spend on your art!To sum up a long story, I recently got engaged to my soul-mate, he is the one that makes me complete, and now every minute away from him is painful. Unfortunately, the timing could have been better. Having lived away from my homeland (Norway) for near 6 years now, I had been planning to move back this April-May to be closer to my family, to see my little brothers grow up, to be around for my niece and nephew, to be able to help my ageing granny, and generally be around more for when my mum/stepdad/dad/stepmum need someone to help out. I've had to sit and watch from afar too many times now, when one of them has had to go into hospital, and there has been nothing I could do to help.For me it's not too much of a problem, my family between them can scrape up my air fare, and what little belongings I have would likely fit in my luggage or be donated to the local charity shop, however to fit two people into a life in Norway, the requirements are slightly higher, like needing a room, a bed to fit us both, a chance to get a job, etc.Basically, we need to be established enough that we can live without being a drain on the system, and get jobs to support us both within 6 months, so that he doesn't have to leave the country.TL;DRDonate money to fund two young creative souls in love, receive personalised art.The art, and the options
Examples of what to expect from my art:THESE are some of the requests I have done so far in my life, THESE are some of my pieces of art done of my own will, or for contests, or schoolTHESE are some more of my drawings/paintings.There are more, but I have a tendency to give them away before making a digital replica for everyone to see.What tools I will be using to create these arts:Pencils (for sketches, or full detail pencil/charcoal/graphite drawings)Pastels (look something like this)Markers (look something like that)Watercolours (look something like tits)Acrylic and misc paints that I have lying around, or Mixed media, of varying kinds.IF YOU FEEL LIKE DONATING A RANDOM AMOUNT AND WANT SOMETHING NOT MENTIONED IN A PERK, let me know I will happily do variations to suit you. What We Need & What You GetWhat we will spend the contributions on:
£0-20 Art supplies (We have most of these, so will only be if we run out).

£0-00 Shipping to get the art to your eyes.

£400-700 Shipping all our important belongings to Norway, so that we'll be able to go about day-to-day things without being kicked out of the country.
£250-350 Getting there, plane tickets + coach to&from the airport or coach to France and interrail passes to trek the whole journey on train.
~£650 Paying off the remains of debt, bills and phone contracts in the UK.
~£106 A months worth of bus travel pass so we can apply for all the jobs, and get to and from work with reasonable ease (it's green and more importantly neither of us drive or can afford a car).
£40-1400 Course/lessons/books for learning Norwegian (One of us knows it, but not in a teaching capacity).

If we don't make our target:Paying off debts are the priority, so neither of us get into financial trouble long term. After that is done with, we'll be selling off everything of sentimental value, all our electronics, and anything we may be able to re-buy in a few years time, once we have a steady income, we'll be travelling by the cheapest available mode of transport, currently plane, but if we don't scrape together enough money soon, interrail will be cheaper.
If we exceed our target:Shipping non-essentials like our bikes, the little sail boat that could, our double bed+matress, not selling our camera and instead taking it with to take all the pictures, buying my granny a nice thank you gift for being epic and renting us her spare room.What you get in return for helping us:
Personalised piece of art, made by me, to your specifications.
Virtual hugs.
Much gratitude.
Such Love
<3

Other Ways You Can Help
Upvotes, karma, sharing etc, anything that makes this reach more people, so that we can reach Norway with a realistic chance to get jobs, and not get deported.

story:
A friend and collector surprised me with the offer of a trip to Hong Kong this September. I have long longed for an experience with my camera in any part of Asia. I am so excited about this trip. What an amazing opportunity.

Please support the creation of new works in my “trying to find my way … “ portfolio, featuring images made in Hong Kong and, hopefully, Shanghai, too. 

These funds will cover:

1. Remaining costs for this trip
                            Equipment and Insurance Rider 
                            Travel to and from Shanghai
                            Food and Accommodations 
2. Production of a printed portfolio and gift prints
3. Exhibition of Asia images in the FotoFest 2016 Biennial

trying to find my way... started in 2009 with an Individual Artist Grant from the Houston Art Alliance to produce new photographic work that explored the ugly/pretty paradox present in urban centers.  To date: Houston, Marfa, Paris, London, NYC, LA, San Francisco and Nashville have portfolios in the project.  In 2014, The Jung Center of Houston selected this project as their featured Fotofest exhibition.  Here are some links to more information and reviews related to this project.  

CultureMap --Photographer finds his way in the urban realm  http://houston.culturemap.com/news/entertainment/10-26-10-photographer-david-brown-finds-his-way-in-an-urban-world/

Essay by David Eagleman about Brown's trying to find my way... project http://dabfoto.com/2011/archives/29/

Houston Press -- New Works by David A Brown: Trying to find my way…” http://www.houstonpress.com/arts/new-works-by-david-a-brown-trying-to-find-my-way-opens-at-the-jung-center-6363706

Houston Chronicle -- Houston photographer deconstructs time to reveal mindful, present moment http://www.chron.com/life/houston-belief/article/Houston-photographer-deconstructs-time-to-reveal-5325642.php

Art and Culture -- Braque, Magritte and Brown http://artsandculturetx.com/braque-magritte-and-brown/

Houston Public Media -- Trying to find my way interview with David A. Brown https://youtu.be/S-VLxdfWUew

Statement of Work: 

One third of the human brain is devoted to processing 8960 kilobits of information per second. [1] My objective is to arrest the brain’s split-second arrangements, assumptions and filtering systems by pausing the subconscious deconstruction process, creating moments of reflection, exploration and possibility.

These images bisect time, capturing simultaneous experiences that happen within the same 1/100 of a second. Their layers of reflected and refracted light reveal an often overlooked truth: reality is all relative. This project explores the automatic split second assumptions we make while navigating each second of our lives, as our experience recalls mental tapes on how to respond. These photographs are intended to halt those processes while navigating to a the new space that is somewhere between what we see and what we understand

About David: He lives and works in Houston with his wife and two children. David's work has primarily focused on the space between what we see and what we understand. He studied at the University of Houston under Paul Kittleson and Luis Jimenez, graduating Magna Cum Laude with his BFA in Studio Arts and Digital Communication. David is an Alumni of Leadership Houston Class XXX and an American Leadership Fellow XXXIII. 

1. Calculating the speed of sight – being-human – 28 July 2006 – New Scientist

story:
Short Summary

Natchie Art is illustrator/singer/songwriter Nadia Ackerman.

- Natchie Art draws her songs with pencil.

- I would really LOVE to participate the Christmas Markets at Columbus Circle. I need assistance in putting down the deposit. The payment has to be in by June 26th. In Septmber I will pay the rest of the fee out of my own pocket.

 

What We Need & What You Get

All Natchie needs is the 3K deposit.

In return you will recieve incredible pieces of art and help me on my way.

What you can purchase:

Greeting Cards

Prints

Mugs

Originals

and one of a kind comissioned drawings

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also just help me spread the word! On your facebook page, twitter or by simply telling your friends!

And that’s all there is to it.

 

ABOUT THE MARKET

ABOUT NATCHIE ART

VIEW ALL OF NATCHIE ART'S PRODUCTS

story:
CHECK OUT THESE IMAGES TO GET AN IMPRESSION OF THE DESIGN OF THE TEMPLE OF DISSOLUTION


Outline

The Temple of Dissolution is a Burning Man-style temple to be built for the European regional event, the Nowhere festival. The Temple of Dissolution celebrates the liminal anniversary of ten years of the Nowhere Festival, by gifting a temple experience to this community in transition.The design of the structure and its practice are on a Nowhere scale and with Nowhere's limitations of being a "non-burn" Burn event in mind.

Design wise, the temple is a very simplified version of a basic Oriental temple, with the traditional Yin-Yang shape and the octagon of elements that surround it. In the middle of the Temple, a pond in Yin-Yang shape will provide participants the opportunity to dissolve either sweet or bitter memories, thoughts, beliefs, or whatever they want to let go off. They can write these things on soluble paper and ink, that can be placed inside of the pond and will dissolve. To speed up this dissolution, the centre of the Temple is open to sunlight, that can evaporate the water inside. On a daily basis, water will be added to the pond to facilitate a new day of letting-go! 

Apart from that, we are currently working on the ability to write on the temple "walls" [made of translucent fabric] and having a way to 'dissolve' these walls as well!

  

Current status of the project 

As for now, this project is still very much in development. We have a preliminary design and the dedication to bring this structure to Nowhere. One way or another! We are working out the details of the design, the placement of the Temple on the Nowhere grounds, getting together a construction crew, the budget, etc. 

 

We need your help

Building and transportation costs of the Temple will amount to a total of approximately 2500 euros, including the Indiegogo fees. Nobody on the team will benefit financially from your donations: every single dime will be put to constructing the Temple and getting it to Nowhere! 

That's a lot of money, that we can't raise without your help. But we think that for such a potentially powerful and emotional structure, we should do it justice by trying and build it this way. If we don't reach our funding goal, we will try and make a slimmed down version. If by a miracle the total raised amount will exceed this budget, we will add and refine enhanced elements to the Temple! 

This money goes to buying of the materials: wooden poles, translucent fabric, and other construction elements. To the construction of the dissolution pond. To lighting the structure to facilitate participants going there at night as well. To dissolvable paper and ink. And to the total cost of transporting all the materials to the Nowhere site. 

No money to help us out financially, but love the idea? Apart from this financial help, we need volunteers as well! So if you can't contribute with a donation, maybe you'd like to help out yourself? Either by being part of the construction crew, or maybe even being a Temple guardian on-site? Let us know how you'd like to contribute!

  

Reward

This is where things get complicated. Your reward would be something transitory and 'soluble' as well. 

One of the principles of Burning Man is Gifting. "The value of a gift is unconditional. Gifting does not contemplate a return or an exchange for something of equal value." We would like to gift this temple experience to the Nowhere community. And we invite you to gift us the opportunity to gift this experience.

We have limited time and resources, and would like to dedicate them to actually building this temple. Also, we don't want to further raise the budget of our fundraising by adding a 'hidden' budgeted amount for perks. So no, no goody bags, no tokens, no VIP treatments. Just love and appreciation!

Your reward would be the immaterial knowledge that you have helped and contributed to bringing this structure to Nowhere. To enjoy the structure whilst attending Nowhere. Or, if you're not attending, to know that Nowhere attendants can live a part of the Burning Man experience because of you. What better reward is there, than gifting a true and meaningful experience to others?

story:
Our Project:

An installation piece for AXIS Chicago in west loop gallery area during Art Expo week Sept 19th- 21st.  We are funding the design and materials and space costs and are in need of additional support.  Our idea is an art concept, with no tangible salable item or goal for profit of any kind.  This is the type of work that will immerse a visitor in a "place" and provoke an emotional response.  Our project is a collaboration between artist Jason Watts and writer AB Gorham, and what is currently in the works are painted backdrops and wooden sets that will hold the written pieces, and booklets that tell the story.  It is about mystery, isolation, loneliness, ecology and being at peace with nature, and there is a thread that hints at the people that have passed this place before.

About the Artist and Writer team:

Jason Watts is known for his landscapes, which capture a sense of place. He resides in the Chicago area and has had many successful solo gallery shows across the country.   AB Gorham is a book artist and writer, She lives in Tallahassee, FL and teaches Structural Book at Florida State University.


What We Need & What You Get

We are in need of  $2500 which will fund the cost of the space in the gallery in the west loop, materials cost for the 12' x 12' construction (wood posts and beams, backdrop 4' x 8' panels and paint) and  the technology for the ambient sound within our space.  If we can reach our goal, we plan on also using some of the funding for original recordings from musician friends that will serve as the soundtrack for this installation.  We are artists and are used to funding our own creations- and would only ask for more if we hadn't gotten a bit over our heads with this current project!

Sound track and videos on creating the piece will be posted on our Facebook page as indication of  progress, and if we exceed our goal we hope to send a memento of the project to our top donors.  All will be invited to our show at AXIS Chicago during Art Expo week and will receive invites and V.I.P. treatment during the show.  We will be giving a presentation at the event that will talk about our collaboration, the artwork and the back stories.  

The Impact

We believe that some of the best ideas and creative pursuits are done out of creative passion, an inkling that comes to you in the middle of the night and we hope to be a part of that type of concept.  We individually sell our own work, but feel this type of concept is different- and there should be a different type of societal regard for art pieces that are solely about the concept, and to engage the viewer and create a place of beauty and intrigue.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us also by helping us tell our story- share it on Facebook, Pinterest, Tumbr, Twitter or your favorite social networking site!  We appreciate any support and/or help you can provide, and do not take this idea lightly- we are one of the featured artists at AXIS Art Festival in the west loop  845 W. Washington 4th floor, Chicago IL.Chicago Sept 19th -21st and hope all of you can make it to see this installation in its completed form!

story:
Based in South Sudan's capital, Juba, The Aggrey Jaden Cultural Center and Cinema will be a place for education and creativity; A place that helps youths overcome the traumas of war.


Now that South Sudan has reached independence, and has the chance to build a new country from the ground up, there’s an imminent need for places where young people can go and learn skills that will help them with their future, as well as deal with their past.


There are an estimated 10 million people living in South Sudan, and UNICEF data indicates that more than 53% of them are under the age of 18.

The cultural center will provide a space for the many young people living in the region to overcome the traumas of war through education, performance, and art. The center will be located across the street from a primary school in Juba Town and will have an after school art program for children during day, and then operate as a cinema at night.  The center will also hold concerts and art exhibitons, showcasing the work of local artists.


Moving Forward:
We are currently looking for funding to begin building the main infrastructure and facilities.  We have secured land in a great location in the middle of Juba.  In addition we are looking for donor partnerships that will help maintain and develop the center over the next five years.

story:
Will you help us celebrate the creativity of our senior artists?

For the past several months, Eldergivers has been developing a book titled Look Again, featuring artists in the Art With Elders program at Laguna Honda Hospital and Rehabilitation Center in San Francisco. When its published, it will be a full color book with more than 100 paintings by these artists along with their life stories.

 The book design is complete. All we have to do is raise the $9,000 required to print it!



Too many people in our society ignore seniors – especially those who are living with chronic illness in long-term care facilities. They believe their lives are winding down, that they are through learning new lessons and new skills, and that they don’t have much to give any more. Nothing could be farther from the truth.

This beautifully-designed, attention-getting volume will blow these beliefs out of the water!

The elder artists involved are eager to “go public”. After almost two years in development, you can imagine how much they are anticipating their debut! The book will also be a great encouragement to other seniors who have long been considering the possibility of exploring their own creativity but just need a nudge.

Will you help us print the book and put elder creativity on the map?

Your Donations are Tax-Deductible!

WHO WE ARE

Eldergivers is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, established in 1985 and operating in four San Francisco Bay Area counties. Eldergivers is dedicated to helping seniors stay connected to their communities – especially those are isolated by chronic illness and institutionalization. Nationally, as well as here in the Bay Area, more than 60% of residents of skilled nursing, assisted living and residential care facilities never have a visitor.

Eldergivers is equally intent on encouraging San Francisco Bay Area residents to stay connected with their elders. The organization’s mission is to connect the generations through programs that celebrate the wisdom, talents and creativity of older adults.

A society’s oldest members are among its most valuable assets. If experience is the matrix of wisdom and experience is the coin of old age, then as our days lengthen our emotional, intellectual, social, spiritual and creative resources ripen. A whole and healthy society recognizes this and not only welcomes the on-going involvement of its older citizens, but actively seeks out their contributions.

Art With Elders (AWE) is a program of Eldergivers. AWE, a fine arts program emphasizing skills building in painting was started in 1991 and now has 18 professional artists teaching approximately 375 seniors in 32 long-term care facilities in San Francisco, Alameda, Santa Clara and San Mateo counties. Laguna Honda Hospital is our largest site. A team of 4 Artist-Instructors provides morning and afternoon instruction in a dedicated studio for up to 80 residents four days a week.

Laguna Honda Hospital and Rehabilitation Center is a branch of the San Francisco Department of Public Health. It provides acute care, skilled nursing and rehabilitation services for a safety- net population of 765 seniors and adults with disabilities. This 146-year old institution moved into a totally rebuilt state-of-the-art facility in December of 2010.

Mark H. Campbell, MFA, has been AWE director at Laguna Honda since September of 1997 and has, in the interim, established a distinguished program. He is a nationally-known artist and his work can be seen here: http://www.markhcampbell.com/
story_txt:
Will you help us celebrate the creativity of our senior artists?For the past several months, Eldergivers has been developing a book titled Look Again, featuring artists in the Art With Elders program at Laguna Honda Hospital and Rehabilitation Center in San Francisco. When its published, it will be a full color book with more than 100 paintings by these artists along with their life stories.

 The book design is complete. All we have to do is raise the $9,000 required to print it!


Too many people in our society ignore seniors – especially those who are living with chronic illness in long-term care facilities. They believe their lives are winding down, that they are through learning new lessons and new skills, and that they don’t have much to give any more. Nothing could be farther from the truth.
This beautifully-designed, attention-getting volume will blow these beliefs out of the water!

The elder artists involved are eager to “go public”. After almost two years in development, you can imagine how much they are anticipating their debut! The book will also be a great encouragement to other seniors who have long been considering the possibility of exploring their own creativity but just need a nudge.
Will you help us print the book and put elder creativity on the map?

Your Donations are Tax-Deductible!

WHO WE ARE
Eldergivers is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, established in 1985 and operating in four San Francisco Bay Area counties. Eldergivers is dedicated to helping seniors stay connected to their communities – especially those are isolated by chronic illness and institutionalization. Nationally, as well as here in the Bay Area, more than 60% of residents of skilled nursing, assisted living and residential care facilities never have a visitor.
Eldergivers is equally intent on encouraging San Francisco Bay Area residents to stay connected with their elders. The organization’s mission is to connect the generations through programs that celebrate the wisdom, talents and creativity of older adults.
A society’s oldest members are among its most valuable assets. If experience is the matrix of wisdom and experience is the coin of old age, then as our days lengthen our emotional, intellectual, social, spiritual and creative resources ripen. A whole and healthy society recognizes this and not only welcomes the on-going involvement of its older citizens, but actively seeks out their contributions.
Art With Elders (AWE) is a program of Eldergivers. AWE, a fine arts program emphasizing skills building in painting was started in 1991 and now has 18 professional artists teaching approximately 375 seniors in 32 long-term care facilities in San Francisco, Alameda, Santa Clara and San Mateo counties. Laguna Honda Hospital is our largest site. A team of 4 Artist-Instructors provides morning and afternoon instruction in a dedicated studio for up to 80 residents four days a week.
Laguna Honda Hospital and Rehabilitation Center is a branch of the San Francisco Department of Public Health. It provides acute care, skilled nursing and rehabilitation services for a safety- net population of 765 seniors and adults with disabilities. This 146-year old institution moved into a totally rebuilt state-of-the-art facility in December of 2010.
Mark H. Campbell, MFA, has been AWE director at Laguna Honda since September of 1997 and has, in the interim, established a distinguished program. He is a nationally-known artist and his work can be seen here: http://www.markhcampbell.com/

story:
Chicago Sun Times


Soraya Sheppard’s passion and love for the visual arts and her birth country inspired her to establish Color Me Africa Fine Art in 2012. Her goal: to sponsor, celebrate and recognize talented African artists across the Diaspora. Sheppard, 25 years after fleeing South Africa’s apartheid regime, decided it was time to face her past and give something back to the country she loves.

THE RETURN

While checking out the art scene, Sheppard stumbled upon a treasure trove of art by South Africans at a small exhibit in Johannesburg. The art was striking, reflecting the pain and strife so many South Africans felt during the oppressive apartheid regime. An artist at the exhibition told her how black artists struggled there. Sheppard was inspired to act, resolving to help tell the unique stories of artists so often lost or unrecorded.

THE VISION

Color Me Africa’s vision is to bring the vibrant fine art and culture of South Africa to the rest of the world. Due to exploitation, many artists are not fairly compensated for their work, which art dealers sell for high prices in the open market. Sheppard is committed to helping African artists connect with their audience to build a reputation and a following. Through professionally curated exhibitions and events, Color Me Africa seeks to promote cultural awareness and provide artists opportunities to earn a fair price for their brilliant work.


What We Need & What You Get

Plans for 2014-2015

This year we are planning 3 exhibitions (featuring several up-and-coming African artists). We hope you will be able to attend--if not, we are offering wonderful rewards for your donation.

Your Contribution Will Help Fund:

Our starting budget is $30,000. This includes: staff, equipment, art supplies, basic utilities, insurance, panels, materials for exhibitions and shipment of the art. Our end goal is to seek grants from art foundations that will enable us to open a permanent gallery where our artist’s paintings can be viewed on a daily basis.

THE IMPACT

 At this time, we mostly highlight South African artists, but intend to eventually feature artists from other African countries. By giving them access to a global community, they learn how to be art entrepreneurs that not only uplift their lives but positively impact others in the community. A community is only as powerful as its members. Empower and educate them and watch the community flourish.

THE ARTIST AND THEIR STORIES

Bongi Bengu

Bongi Bengu was born in Eshowe, KwaZulu-Natal,  and grew up in exile in Geneva, Switzerland, where she attended high school and later at Waterford Kamhlaba in Swaziland. As a student in Swaziland, she received a distinction for a research project, which included interviewing established and major artists, who later became her colleagues at The Bag Factory Studios in Newtown, Johannesburg. This exposure to the art world was an eye-opening experience that inspired her at a young age to become an artist. She later graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree from Mount Vernon College, in Washington, DC, and earned a Master's Degree in Fine Arts from The University of Cape Town. She has since participated in numerous international residencies and workshops.

Xp Art Matshikiza

Xolelani Pat Matshikiza  was born in Cape Town, South Africa, where he attended classes at Cape College studying visual art. He was also tutored privately and spent time on a farm drawing and painting with the well-known South African artist Gavin Collins. In 2006 he took part in a six-month visiting resident program at Greatmore Studios followed by a three-month stay in Germany, where he taught art at a private school in Stendal, "Private Grundschule Altmark."

As an artist, he is inspired by everyday life, hardship, music and history of old houses, places and people from different cultures. His creations reflect how he looks at things,  be it in detail or more in general from all possible angles. His work is steeped in contradiction and deeper meaning. He uses different media, like oil on canvas and found objects, to create sculptures and paintings. He uses various techniques and styles: figurative painting, series of old buildings, portraits, abstract work and ceramic. The ideas on which he bases his work are always appealing. Despite the dark view of the world we have to face, there is always a sight of anger, love, happiness and life in his work.

artist 'Jabu

 ’Jabu’s art is unique and vibrant with a twist of both urban and contemporary touch. He captures diverse appeal from his abstract work to artwork inspired by elements and tapestry from South African background as this is his origin. However, his work is inspired by experiences outside of his origin. He combines timeless materials such as maple wood, aluminum, and glass that add to the value of his creations. This has created a growing demand for his signature style and Afrocentric Contemporary Perspective collection.

Ndabuko Ntuli

Ndabuko Julukani Mabhele Andries Ntuli was born on July 1, 1975 in the mountains of Enkandla KwaZulu Natal. Ndabuko was groomed for his artistic journey at an early age surrounded by Zulu dance, singing, playing and poetry.  Reciting, storytelling and art was part of daily life in his village and his family. He exhibited his gifts and his love for the arts from his village as a toddler and never stopped.

Life in the villages during the apartheid era made it difficult for artists to earn a living from the work they produced.  Many dreams died and talent unrealized because of this hardship. The only expectation held within the village was to  leave home for the big cities to seek employment and work to support their families in the villages. Many artists had to flee South African security forces and live and work in exile, and Ndabuko’s grandfather was on the list of artists whose work suffered dearly under the oppressive regime.

Art and inspiration were gifts stolen from Ndabuko’s late grandfather, Masobeshe Nqamaziyanqubula Hezekiah Ntuli, who produced gigantic sculptures, a gift he inherited from his father who was brutally killed by white South Africans for his work because it was seen as a threat and to discourage the next generation of African artists. A stubborn man, his grandfather continued to produce great work, most of which left the country with foreign buyers. Masobeshe eventually went into exile where he continued to produce his craft.  Upon his return to South Africa, he was captured and died under suspicious conditions.

Ndubko’s focus on art followed him all through his education from preschool to high school.  He moved to Alexandra Township where he began developing his craft at the Alexandra Art Center for less advantaged artists. Doors started opening up to galleries and exhibitions, but unfortunately, unscrupulous art dealers exploit artists from the townships and villages and are perpetuating the struggle for artist like Ndabuko to secure a healthily life for himself and his family.

Today, Ndabuko is a well established sculptor, painter and singer. Ndabuko Ntuli has a masterpiece that has been sculpted from the valleys and fields of KwaZulu Natal to become one of the most creative and inspirational stories of our time. He has been featured in a number of group exhibitions in South Africa and London.

Moses Masoko

Moses Masoko began his creative journey as a graphic designer. In 1997, he ventured into textiles and fabric designs at EzixeleleHlombe and at the Vosloorus Art Centre. Masoko expanded on his talents as a print-maker at the Artist Pro Studio. While at the Artist Studio, a non-governmental organization focused on helping black artists, Masoko also taught art at the Creative Inner City Initiative in Hillbrow, Johannesburg.

In 2003, Masoko, took his art to new frontiers by studying at the South African Printing College. He exhibited at the Art on Paper Gallery in Melville, and at many other galleries. In addition to being featured in various galleries in South Africa, Masoko has also been featured in DirkieOffringa’sbook, "Walking Tall, Without Fear (24 South African Artists from the Struggle Era)." Moses has since expanded his horizons and his works have traveled abroad, currently in exhibits in Chicago.

Jerry Lion

Jerry Lion has a unique style, working predominantly in pastel and charcoal, giving us his interpretation of life in the townships. He focuses mostly on kids as they remind him of his childhood. In most of his work he depicts the joy and hope of people of people being happy regardless of their poverty, struggle or their underprivileged background. Jerry’s work is well sought after by private collectors, organizations, art galleries, government organizations.


Other Ways You Can Help.

Get the word out and make some noise! Share the campaign and video on Facebook or by email.

story:
We Want Change - Just Not This Change

ILove99 is an entire community of LA-based actors, directors, producers, stage managers, designers, patrons and enthusiasts. We are young, old, rich, poor, of all ethnicities and backgrounds. We believe strongly that Los Angeles's small theater scene, under the decades-old "99 Seat Theater Plan", is only beginning to blossom into its full potential as a home and incubator for exciting, new  theater of the future.

However, Actors Equity Association's current Proposal, due to be voted on as a referendum by its members on April 17th, directly  threatens  this dynamic landscape. If implemented, AEA's Proposal will cut off union-affiliated talent from many small theaters and slowly price them out of operation. Risk-taking venues creating the next generation of art will be replaced by a few overpriced theaters, stifling opportunity for the next generation of artists.

That's where you come in. Your contributions will go to an all-out campaign to raise awareness of AEA members about the exact content and potential ramifications of the Proposal. Through social media, billboards, PSAs, and outreach, ILove99 will be able to get the word out and help save LA's small theaters! 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raise a bank of approximately $15,000.00 (the more the better, of course). 
  • Of that total, a portion will go to street-level messaging, such as print ads. Portions will also go to analytics-based paid promotion on social media platforms such as Twitter, Facebook, and Vine. If these strategies are successful, your continued support will go to more sophisticated fundraising events!
  • If our goal is not met, Indiegogo will keep a bigger percentage, but the remainder will still go to future endeavors for the cause, such as legal counsel. 

Why You Should Help

If you live in Los Angeles and love theater, the next month is crucial to its future. AEA has a bold vision where its members are required to be paid minimum wage by every theater company, even non-profit ones. Of course, we all want to eventually pay actors a living wage. But not in exchange for the very stages they work on!

ILove99 simply wants everyone to Stop. Study. Strategize. Stop advocating the Proposal and clarify what it does. Study the data and facts available (there has not been enough time for anyone involved to do so). And finally, Strategize a workable solution for all artists involved in the Los Angeles theater industry.

Will theater survive? Yes. Theater will always survive. But if this Plan goes through, there will be far less of it at a bigger price tag in LA. Far fewer houses with bigger budgets producing less work. And actors will have less opportunities to hone their craft. In the end, AEA's Proposal hurts AEA actors too.


The Hurdles We Face

We won't lie: this is going to be an uphill battle. But we already have tons of momentum working for us:

  • Visit our Facebook page and see how many of us are already actively spreading awareness! We have the numbers to spread the message.
  • We've already had local city officials such as Councilman Mitch O'Farrell express the cultural and economic value of 99 seat theaters, as well as concern for their future. 
  • A recent debate on the local radio show Which Way LA made a very strong case for AEA'a Proposal being detrimental to the local theater community.
  • In addition, many celebrities have come out to endorse the 99 seat theater community and express strong opposition to AEA's current Proposal. This list includes Tim Robbins, French Stewart, Frances Fisher, Alfred Molina, Noah Wyle, Parvesh Cheena, Richard Azurdia, Rebecca Metz, Patrick Duffy, Jane Kaczmerek, Sean Hayes, Katie Lowes, Ed Asner, Sharon Lawrence, Robert Patrick, Laurie Metcalf, Martin Landau, Jennifer Lee, and Ed Harris , who spoke up nationally on The Talk .

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if money's tight (heck, that's why we're fighting this battle!). So if you can only give so much, there are so many other ways you can help ILove99's efforts:

  • Share the link to ILove99.org and follow @99SeatsLA on Twitter. Also, use the hashtags #Pro99 and #ILove99 when messaging.
  • Talk to Equity actors about the Proposals. Tell them what concerns you may have. Make sure they know their ballots will be sent to them Wednesday, March 25th and need to be mailed or sent online by Thursday, April 17th.
  • Don't forget to share this campaign too! Spread the word that we need to fund this campaign over the next month. The quicker the contribution, the better! A Facebook post or email blast by merely 1/3 of contributors could double our desired goal!
Thank you for your support; let's keep this glorious community growing! #ILove99

story:
Why "Readings At The X"?

Short Summary

Greetings.  My name is Dr. Rhone Fraser and this summer with the help of the Friends of Malcolm X Park, am launching this summer "Readings at the X."  Readings at the X is a showcase of historical plays that tell stories that tend to get ignored or overlooked in basic public school education.  Each play is intended to show the dramatic aspects of this history in a way to inspire and to encourage critical thinking about issues we face today like austerity and imperialism.  For example, John Brown's efforts at fighting slavery could inspire in an audience member a way to fight austerity or imperialism in this day and age.  Donations will contribute to three main expenses: one, paying the actors for their time, their travel (some are coming from New York, others from DC) or both; two, the videographer who will record this reading not for commercial purposes but strictly for the writers' revising purposes; three, to a donation to the Friends of Malcolm X  Park for future events. 

FUNDING BREAKDOWN

$1,500 to all actors that is part of this series including travel and lodging expenses for eight weeks

$400 to record all readings for eight weeks

$400 to rent audio projection for eight weeks

$100 to rent chairs and music stands for eight weeks

$100 for bottles of water for eight weeks

The Impact

This project will bring a unique dramatic storytelling form to an audience that does not regularly receive this message of empowerment. 

I have directed a 2012 production of Sonia Sanchez's play Dirty Hearts at the Adrienne Theater that was sold out in its Saturday, July 14, 2012 performance. 

I am a volunteer coordinator at West Philadelphia Community Radio nearby Malcolm X Park and I regularly promote educational programming in our community. 

    Risks & Challenges

    We may not raise enough to pay all the actors, however with your helping us reach our goal, we can pay them some amount. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools
    • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
