Why "Readings At The X"?
Short Summary Greetings.  My name is Dr. Rhone Fraser and this summer with the help of the Friends of Malcolm X Park, am launching this summer "Readings at the X."  Readings at the X is a showcase of historical plays that tell stories that tend to get ignored or overlooked in basic public school education.  Each play is intended to show the dramatic aspects of this history in a way to inspire and to encourage critical thinking about issues we face today like austerity and imperialism.  For example, John Brown's efforts at fighting slavery could inspire in an audience member a way to fight austerity or imperialism in this day and age.  Donations will contribute to three main expenses: one, paying the actors for their time, their travel (some are coming from New York, others from DC) or both; two, the videographer who will record this reading not for commercial purposes but strictly for the writers' revising purposes; three, to a donation to the Friends of Malcolm X  Park for future events.  FUNDING BREAKDOWN$1,500 to all actors that is part of this series including travel and lodging expenses for eight weeks$400 to record all readings for eight weeks$400 to rent audio projection for eight weeks$100 to rent chairs and music stands for eight weeks$100 for bottles of water for eight weeks  The Impact This project will bring a unique dramatic storytelling form to an audience that does not regularly receive this message of empowerment.  I have directed a 2012 production of Sonia Sanchez's play Dirty Hearts at the Adrienne Theater that was sold out in its Saturday, July 14, 2012 performance.  I am a volunteer coordinator at West Philadelphia Community Radio nearby Malcolm X Park and I regularly promote educational programming in our community.     Risks & ChallengesWe may not raise enough to pay all the actors, however with your helping us reach our goal, we can pay them some amount.    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help: 
Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools
Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.

story:
Welcome!

Thank you for your support in bringing the latest and grandest incarnation of the Mystic Midway to life at Burning Man!

Inspired by an abundance of community spirit and social artistry he first witnessed at Burning Man in 1996, project director Barron Scott Levkoff (aka The Professor) set out on a 20-year mission to study what made these marvelous social experiences possible.

The "Mystical Midway," to be presented at Burning Man: Carnival of Mirrors, will be the most ambitious manifestation of that mission yet.

The Mystic Midway is a multi-media, interactive social theater experience that invites participants on a journey of discovery.  It begins when they step into the Midway, an other-worldly setting of evocative props and engaging attractions.  Inside, the Ensemble will perform rituals, skits, and original songs.  Lavishly costumed characters from the “7 Families of the Mystic Midway” will engage participants in inquiries designed to arouse their reflection as they move through their journey.  

Within the Mystic Midway there is no boundary between creator and consumer.  Burners from around the world are being invited to cosplay as a persona from one of the “7 Families” and embody their role on the Mythic Stage alongside us at Burning Man!  We have published a Cosplay Guide, a series of tutorials on creating costume pieces, and a deck of Story Cards which introduce the concepts and characters of the Midway.

The Mystic Midway takes a playful approach to modeling a new social dynamic.  It proposed a culture of collaboration, empathy, self-discovery, confrontation of fears,  and liberation from internal barriers to joy...   

By appearing at Burning Man this year, the "Mystical Midway" invites the very community that was a major source of its inspiration to join us in stepping onto the Mythic Stage!


What We Are Creating...

The Mystic Midway Story Cards

These cards provide the backbone of the entire project. 


There are four Story Card suits- Characters, Attractions, Concepts, and Main Acts. Each card has a Basic Interpretation, set of Inquiries, and suggested activities designed to bring participants deeper into ‘the heart of their story’.

Get a closer look at one of our favorite Story Cards, the Mystic Fire:


We will be offering a ‘teaser’ deck of some of these cards as a perk for this campaign and a full deck for our campaign this fall.

Pop-up Wagon Carnival

The Pop-up Wagon Carnival will travel Black Rock City, performing the interactive Professor Grimaldi’s Medicine Show for playa citizens as we weave our merry way, joined by Mystic Midway Family members from around the world.


Our wagons will appear in the Bay Area this summer at events prior to Burning Man and will continue to bring their unique flavor of social theater to spaces afterwards. 


Cosplay and Instructable Tutorials

We will create video tutorials and simple style/character guides to inviting burners from all over the world to create their own Midway characters and join their chosen Mystical Midway Family while on the playa.

Anyone from anywhere around the world will be able to join in the show and run away with the Mystical Midway. Are you a member of the Harlequin, Mystic, Hobo Kin, Wyrdding Wizzard or Fae Families?

Welcome home, Mystical families of the Midway!

"Mystical Midway" Performance Booth in Burning Man’s Carnival of Mirrors Midway

We will run an immersive 30' x 24' space  at the base of the Man from Sunday till Thursday night, where the Midway Ensemble will unleash Professor Grimaldi’s New World Medicine Show in the evenings. The booth will be open 24 hrs for anyone to explore, spin the Wheel of Mirrors, and step inside the stories on our over-sized Story Cards.

Professor Grimaldi's New World Medicine Show 


In our booth, on the Carnival stages, and amidst the circle of our Midway Wagons, we will host interactive sing-a-longs and theatrical rituals that bring to life the 4 Story Acts of The Mystical Midway Wheel of Mirrors:

  • ACT 1: The Mythic Stage- Who are you on your Mythic journey into The Midway?
  • ACT 2: In the Midway- What inner magic will you find in the Midway?
  • ACT 3: In the Shadow of the Midway- How will you use your magic to meet challenges?
  • ACT 4: Ars Miraculum (Everyday Miracles) - How will you use your magic to help create magical experiences for others?

Ensemble Training

This summer, we will immerse the Mystic Midway community, and anyone who wants to join us,  in ensemble training and costume character workshops taught by Bay Area masters of diverse Commedia, Clowning, Improv and physical theater traditions. 

What We Need & What You Get

The "Mystical Midway" is supported in part by a grant from Burning Man, but we need to raise  significantly more to bring the project to completion.  Our goal is to build the most engaging experience possible for Burning Man and beyond. The content and materials created for Burning Man 2015 will live on in the Professor’s future manifestations in the Bay Area.  Funds will be used for:

  • New set, prop and booth construction
  • Low-cost materials for the Story Cards, games and attractions
  • Mutant Carnival Wagons constructed from re-purposed tricycles
  • Transport of materials and equipment to and from the playa

We are seeking to raise $15,000. The budget breakdown is as follows:

  • $2k Ensemble Direction, Organizational staff
  • $2k Training, workshops (open to anyone!)
  • $2k Set, prop construction and materials (many recyclable materials)
  • $2k Wagons, lighting and materials 
  • $1k Costuming and make-up (re-purposed thrift clothes, hand-made costumes)
  • $2k Story Card artwork, design, Adventure Game Board
  • $1000 Graphic layout, animation
  • $1.5 Rewards fabrication (posters, cabochons, card printing, keys)
  • $1k Transport of sets, wagons, props, costumes to Burning Man
  • $1.5k *some* limited, essential Camp support 
  • $ 500 Indiegogo Video costs
  • $ 500 Indiegogo consulting & promotions
  • 10% Contingency Fund

The Mystical Midway is a project by the Mystic Midway, an ongoing non-profit endeavor sponsored by Independent Arts & Media and can now receive tax-deductible donations. 

We have a proven  track record of managing donations through our sponsor to produce successful events on time and on budget.  Our plans for the Mystic Midway extend well beyond Burning Man, such as our just-confirmed appearance at the Life is Beautiful Festival September 25, 26th and 27th in Las Vegas, Nevada.

The Impact

The Mystic Midway is an ongoing body or work, many years in development, that explores the value of social design in creating abundant, deeply engaged, participatory communities.The Professor has brought  unparalleled, innovative social events to the SF Bay Area for over 25 years and now seeks support to continue to evolve the methods, create content, build community and bring highly engaging events and experiences to participants locally and further afield.


In the tradition of local legends such as SF Mime Troupe, Mystic Midway serves to enliven local community by modernizing traditional Theatrical forms: Improv, festival traditions, puppetry, mask work, costumed role play, fantastic narratives, mythical themes, social games, storytelling and more.

In the Mystic Midway, everyone is invited to participate in stepping onto the mythic stage of their own lives!

 “All of the arts, poetry, music, ritual, the visible arts, the theater, must singly and together create the most comprehensive art of all, a humanized society, and its masterpiece, free man” - Bernard Berenson

Want a taste of the social theatre magic that the Mystic Midway weaves? Check out this video of the Midway at the Augmented World Expo:

Other Ways You Can Help

Even those who cannot contribute financial can help by getting the word out about our project.  Visit our Facebook community page.  Come to one of our future events.  If you’re planning to be at Burning Man, join us at our booth as a member of one of the 7 Mystic Midway Families. 

Our Mystic Midway Cosplay Guide tells you how. 


Meet The Professor


Barron Scott Levkoff aka ‘The Professor’, Director of Mystic Midway, is an innovative event producer, director, designer, community builder, and Creative Culture Champion working in the SF Bay Area for over 25 years.  Recent credits include Spookeasy, a 1930’s era Halloween Vaudeville Spooktacular in SF’s Chinatown; Whobilation Holiday Funhouse; Master Mondo’s Bizarre-o-Tronic, an underground cabaret series; and The Lagunitas Beer Circus, an ongoing annual event created for Lagunitas Brewery. 

The projects for Burning Man that Scott has created in the past have delighted many within its community, and include the following:

  • 1998 Center Camp Cafe "People's Fashion Show" co-producer, decor lead, and booking; including techno-tribal musical pioneers, Lost at Last
  • 1999 The Eternal Return- Large scale theatrical ritual spectacle created for the Community Dance featuring attended by thousands
  • 2001 The Stardome- Esplanade Theme Camp for Superstar Avatar Social Artistry project
  • 2003 Peepshow Mini Golf- participatory "Gong Show" style game show meets flashmob/ Mini golf dance party

Meet the Mystic Midway Community

We are a community of artists, technologists, game designers, performers and cultural visionaries dedicated to creating participatory, entertaining and meaningful social spaces by harnessing Social Theater & Mythic Inquiry in service to Evolution and Marvelous Potential!

Our advisors:  Martin Caplan, Neal Gorenflo, John Doffing

Footage of our colorful ensemble at the 2014 Edwardian Ball:


Testimonials for the Barron Scott Levkoff's Projects

"Scott never fails to deliver enchanting, heartfelt and deeply moving experiences at all levels of resource and infrastructure.  He thinks deeply about the experience he creates, engages performers who are able to embody and transmit his vision, and transports participants into endlessly creative, exquisitely moving and inventive alternative worlds." - Dana Harrison- Managing Director at Theatre Bay Area, General Manager/Executive of Producer Post-Playa Productions

"Scott's interactive social theatre is a whimsical invitation to explore your deepest hopes, fears and magical talents on a purposeful journey of inquiry and discovery. No need to buy what's being hawked by the snake oil salesmen, for you just might discover that healing elixirs are already amongst you." - Neal Gorenflo- Director, Project Founder of Shareable.net
  "I've had the great pleasure of knowing and periodically working with Scott for 20 years now and have appreciated his completely unique approach to community building and the creative process from the start. He is a furnace of artistic ingenuity; I can't wait to see what he does next." -  Autumn Adamme- Founder of Dark Garden Unique Corsetry

 "I'd been feeling in such a funk all week, and embodying Lady Fortuna as a golden mirror with a simple assortment of Story cards was a perfect way to get me out of my own head and into something deeper and richer. People loved reflecting on their stories and sharing them."    'N'- A Mystic Midway Ensemble Player


"The cards were really speaking to people's soul potential, and urging people to dive deep within to cull their inner depths for transformation, encouraging people to tap inside themselves for unmanned gems."         -J- A Mystic Midway Salon Guest

Risks and Challenges

  • Ensuring the quality of our team of ensemble performers is our paramount risk; without performers, there is no Mystical Midway. To make sure we put on the best possible show we can, we are engaging with top professionals to do training workshops in the “default world,” developing show content and troupe cohesion well in advance of putting on the show itself on-playa.

  • Art production against a hard date is always challenging. To mitigate this risk, we are starting early and putting key art assets in the can, so to speak, so that we can make sure we have what is needed to make the project look amazing. We also have a large body of work from years past that we are drawing upon to shore up any art asset schedule slips.

  • Financial risk is present but manageable. We have a minimum viable budget that we’ll need to pull off the show and support our team, but that is very achievable given the support that we have already seen. We are confident we can adapt the scope of our show to the final amount we are able to raise. We have also secured backing funds help us cover our costs while we wait for our fundraising goals to finalize.

  • Weather on the playa is a large factor in how we are designing both our camp and stage. We are keeping in mind conditions like extreme heat, extreme cold, dust storms, rain, mud, and so on. Our team’s combined decades of experience going to Black Rock City will help in preparing for these harsh conditions.

  • Transport to and from the playa is a real risk, both in safety and in expense. We are building all our pieces, in true carny fashion, to be packed flat and go on the road. This will minimize the number of large vehicles we are taking out on the road and allow us to ensure the safe passage of the troupe, camp, and sets.

story:
Edit

Moments is an artist collaboration composing of 7 enthusiastic individuals. Each of our practices vary, yet center around the theme of how we uniquely view the world around us and record it in the world of art in a way which is new and exciting.

We are currently preparing for an exhibition in May 2016, where we will be using the medium of light to create an immersive exhibition experience in the cellar of BrewHaus Lincoln.

The title? 'I Can't Give Everything Away'. 


We are looking for donations of as little or as much as possible;i 
 - whether it is donated lightbulbs (working or broken)
- wiring/cables
-attendance to the festival
-capital of any amount

We are aiming to raise £500 in order to obtain the equipment needed to create this exhibition and make it come to life. Your money will allow us to pay for the venue, and any necessary materials.
If you would like to get in contact, please reach us via the email provided below, or on our Facebook page 'Moments'.
EMAIL:
moments_7@lycos.com
FACEBOOK:
https://www.facebook.com/MomentsLincoln/

Artists:
Abi Coe - https://www.facebook.com/Abi-Coe-Art-1644753749...
Arooj Naeem - http://xeverlastinglight.deviantart.com
Emily Phillips - https://www.facebook.com/EmilyRosePhillipsArt/?fref=ts
Connie Riley - https://neene.org/beta/profile/connieriley 
Imogen Ryan
Francesco Scalici - https://www.facebook.com/Francescoscaliciartworks/?fref=ts
Paige Webb - https://www.facebook.com/paigewebbart/?fref=ts

story:
Marie Nimier is one of France’s beloved novelists, songwriters, children’s book writer, and screenwriters. She is known for her surreal and magical writings such as Sirène (Mermaid), and Les Inséparables (The Inseparable Ones), and for her daring plays. "Another Year, Another Christmas" was first performed in Paris at Le Théâtre du Rond-Point to sold out performances, but surprisingly none of her plays have been performed in the U.S. until now.

We at Haberdasher Theatre have the amazing opportunity to introduce the American audience to Marie's work.  One of Frances premiere contemporary writers, she is part of group whose use of language has been called:

"...violent, direct and free, their characters torn, disenchanted, and unsettled, their world cold, brutal, and closed off. Their humor spicy, iconoclastic, and dark.  Their style lucid, fragmented and lyrical."

-Beyond French Feminisms: Debates on Women, Culture and Politics in France 1980-2001

Through this production we seek to bring Marie Nimier's unique voice to the American audience.  A voice that both plays with the musicality of language while at the same time delving into the bonds of family.

"Another Year, Another Christmas" explores each year, a mother, a son, and his current "girlfriend(s)" at the time of meeting for a Christmas dinner that reveals the family’s dysfunction and hidden tragedies of loss and death. Despite the comedic mishaps that take place each year, the mother and son grow closer together and learn to appreciate their short time together on earth. Through Marie Nimier’s inventive use of language and word play, "Another Year, Another Christmas" attempts to highlight the ways in which language can communicate deep emotions that are sometimes hidden within the veneer of formality and routine.

This play will be performed simultaneously with a production in Columbus, Ohio, Directed by Hollie Klem. Making this production not only a wonderful story told for the first time in the United States, but also, a Columbus/New York production as well. Both stages will share the same honor of bringing to life the English translation of Marie Nimier’s words in collaboration.

Your support today will go towards our New York production for sets, props, costumes, studio rehearsals, lighting, and paying the amazing artists we have the privilege to work with. 

This production also mark Haberdasher Theatre's 10th anniversary creating independent work in New York City, and our second year in Columbus, Ohio.

Community and collaboration have been key staples for Haberdasher since it's inception, and continue to be our main focus in every production.  We view each production as an opportunity for artists to learn and be inspired by each other.  We encourage risk taking, and endeavor to help each artist achieve the fullest realization of their dream. 

Our philosophy is, we always say yes...until we have to say no. 

By becoming a part of our community you allow us the ability to say yes, and take the risks needed for our community of artists to reach their full potential.  

Your support can come in many forms too.  By sharing this production, and our message, you help build our community further.  We are always looking for like minded individuals who want to take risks, collaborate, and inspire new ideas. 

We appreciate any support you are able to give. 

As we welcome you into our community, we thank you for your time, and look forward to seeing you at the theatre.

"Another Year, Another Christmas" is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of "Another Year, Another Christmas" must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
story_txt:
Marie Nimier is one of France’s beloved novelists, songwriters, children’s book writer, and screenwriters. She is known for her surreal and magical writings such as Sirène (Mermaid), and Les Inséparables (The Inseparable Ones), and for her daring plays. "Another Year, Another Christmas" was first performed in Paris at Le Théâtre du Rond-Point to sold out performances, but surprisingly none of her plays have been performed in the U.S. until now.
We at Haberdasher Theatre have the amazing opportunity to introduce the American audience to Marie's work.  One of Frances premiere contemporary writers, she is part of group whose use of language has been called:
"...violent, direct and free, their characters torn, disenchanted, and unsettled, their world cold, brutal, and closed off. Their humor spicy, iconoclastic, and dark.  Their style lucid, fragmented and lyrical."
-Beyond French Feminisms: Debates on Women, Culture and Politics in France 1980-2001
Through this production we seek to bring Marie Nimier's unique voice to the American audience.  A voice that both plays with the musicality of language while at the same time delving into the bonds of family.
"Another Year, Another Christmas" explores each year, a mother, a son, and his current "girlfriend(s)" at the time of meeting for a Christmas dinner that reveals the family’s dysfunction and hidden tragedies of loss and death. Despite the comedic mishaps that take place each year, the mother and son grow closer together and learn to appreciate their short time together on earth. Through Marie Nimier’s inventive use of language and word play, "Another Year, Another Christmas" attempts to highlight the ways in which language can communicate deep emotions that are sometimes hidden within the veneer of formality and routine.
This play will be performed simultaneously with a production in Columbus, Ohio, Directed by Hollie Klem. Making this production not only a wonderful story told for the first time in the United States, but also, a Columbus/New York production as well. Both stages will share the same honor of bringing to life the English translation of Marie Nimier’s words in collaboration.
Your support today will go towards our New York production for sets, props, costumes, studio rehearsals, lighting, and paying the amazing artists we have the privilege to work with. 
This production also mark Haberdasher Theatre's 10th anniversary creating independent work in New York City, and our second year in Columbus, Ohio.
Community and collaboration have been key staples for Haberdasher since it's inception, and continue to be our main focus in every production.  We view each production as an opportunity for artists to learn and be inspired by each other.  We encourage risk taking, and endeavor to help each artist achieve the fullest realization of their dream.

story:
My name is Paul Lazes and, although I am from Long Island and have spent most of my life in Manhattan – where there are many strong women, I'm struck by how many strong, independent women live on Martha's Vineyard. I've lived here for 17 years. 

This project is to honor some of these dynamic Vineyard women, each of whom possesses striking and unique qualities and all of whom share common traits: They are strong and independent, and they exude entrepreneurial spirit. This display of 50 life-size portraits will fill an entire hallway at Martha's Vineyard Hospital, which houses the largest collection of art on the Island. The Tough Chicks portraits will be part of the Hospital's Permanent Art Collection.

The Collection will be seen by thousands of people – staff, visitors, and patients, who hopefully might be cheered up and perhaps even inspired by these images of bright, strong women.

The hospital does not pay for its art.  Artists donate their work and finance their own production and installation.  My costs will be $6,000.

If we don't reach my goal of $6,000, I will continue my efforts to raise the money required to execute the work. If I exceed my goal, I will put the funds toward publication of a book of the images.

If you cannot afford to contribute to this campaign, please share this with anyone you know who might be interested in contributing.

Many thanks,

Paul Lazes

story:
We are now past the halfway point in our filming and are asking for private donations to help us get acrross the finish line.  All donations will go entirely into the production of this film and the more we raise the higher our quality and capabilities to traveling to distant locations to capture this man's incredible life story. Donations will go directly towards: 

 

 

Production: video, audio, lighting, actors for re-enactments, props, makeup, costumes, and locations.  

Travel, lodging, & food for the crew

Post production: editing, color correction, CGI, & sound design 

Insurance, licensing, stock free music rights & footage & legal fees

Film festival submission fees

 

 

​About filmmaker David Yuzuk

 

For the last 18 years, I’ve worked as a police officer and detective in Miami. I have always attempted to get to know many of the homeless and down on their luck individuals I encounter in my daily shift.

I immediately took a liking to Richard and for over a decade we were friends making small talk about world politics and movies. I never pressed Richard on his past due respecting his right to privacy. 

It's my intention to finish the journey we started together in detailing Richard’s complex life. Interviews of his family, friends, and military comrades along with photo’s, video's, and re-enactments will help to paint that picture. My plan is not to twist his life’s story into some Hollywood hero propaganda film but to tell his life story as accurately as I can.

 

Co-Producer/Co-DirectorJEREMY MCDERMOTT 

Jeremy McDermott is a South Florida filmmaker that takes a cinematic approach to any project he's involved in. His body of work entails commercial/corporate accounts to feature and short films. His approach to the documentary is to investigate all the open questions left in Richard's wake then let the chips lie where they fall. 

 

Co-Producer Peter Spirer

 

Peter Spirer is an Academy Award and Emmy Award nominated film director. Many of his films are documentaries. Spirer is the founder of the film and media production company Rugged Entertainment.  

 

WRITER/EDITOR NEIL L. YUZUK

In 2008, After 22 years, he retired as a New York City Substance Abuse Prevention and Intervention Counselor. First at Kings County Hospital and then for the SPARK Program at Canarsie and Franklin K. Lane High Schools.

Since then, Neil and his son David have co-authored five books in the Beachside PD series and Neil has written seven screenplays. Since moving to Los Angeles, Neil has been working with Ken Rotcop, an award-winning writer who, before he retired, was the former head of four major film studios.

"I am very proud to work on this project, helping to uncover the mystery wrapped in an enigma—the incredible life of Richard J. Flaherty."

 

Our Final Goal

Once completed, the documentary will be submitted to numerous film festivals. Our goal is to create a buzz in the industry so "Chasing Shadows" will be  chosen for world wide distribution. 

 

The Impact

By contributing to the project you help keep Richard's memory alive and honor his service to his country. It also further educates the public of the plight of many of our war veterans who not only suffer from PTSD but ultimately become homeless.

 

 

Risks & Challenges

Filming a full feature documentary while we all continue to work our "day jobs" can be a daunting task. Working on weekends and being away from our families is always difficult however our team 100% believes in the project. 

After Richard's tragic death David Yuzuk felt even more compelled in making sure the project is completed but that it also maintains highest level of quality.  

 

What’s in it for you?

As well as that indescribable feeling you get when you know you’ve done something good – really good – Besides the listed perks if you donate $100 or more ve’ll give you a FREE copy of the Chasing Shadow's DVD.

But more than anything, you could be part of raising awareness of our countries most priceless of treasures our returning military vets . That’s priceless. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute that doesn't mean you can't help:

Please get the word out and make some noise about this project. Tell some friends, neighbors, or co-workers.  

By just using Indiegogo's sharing tools (links) on your social media and email it will greatly help us to get this project properly funded. 

 

​

​

​

​

​

 

​

 

 

​

​

​

​

​

​

​

​

​

​

​

​

​

​

story:
Short Summary

We are the YorkSLAM Poetry team of 2015! Formed in the Season 4 Finals in May of 2015 the team has become the focus of our fundraising efforts to get them to the Canadian Festival of Spoken Word (NATIONALS) held in Saskatoon this year. Each member brings a special skill to the team and together they form the MEGAZORD of Slam Poetry.

Comprised of Wes Ryan, Shawna Dimitry, Aria "Ambrosia" Tesolin, and 3 am (aka Edward Martin)

There are only 14 days left before CFSW, and our fundraising efforts have not quite yet achieved our goals. Going to Saskatoon means paying for the hotel, and a lot of gas as the majority of our team is driving all the way out! This festival is the ultimate goal for all Canadian poetry slam teams, and helping us in this campaign will help us achieve our goal of presenting our work on a national stage, giving us the ability to perform the pieces we've worked so hard to create.

What We Need & What You Get

All the money raised in this fund will be going towards paying for the hotel room for CFSW's host hotel, and paying for gas for the drive there and back. The hotel is $189 per night plus tax, a total of $1190.70 and approximate gas cost is $200 each way, for a grand total of $1590.70

We have already raised some funds, but we need $1000 more to reach our goals.

In terms of perks, you could receive a sample of our work by owning your very own, once in a lifetime chapbook filled with poetry from our current team. Or we could even write you a personal poem! Just for you!

The Impact

Poetry, and especially slam poetry, is important to the world we live in. The poets are the people that speak out against social justice issues, make people laugh, cry, and feel. Unfortunately, being a poet is not the highest paying job, and there is not always enough funding in poetry communities to provide for extensive travel. Contribute to this campaign and you will be giving your poets a voice.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the means to contribute to this campaign, you can still help us by getting the word out! Share our campaign on social media, tell your friends, use the Indiegogo share tools. 

You could also attend our fundraiser at the Central on October 7th, or share it:

https://www.facebook.com/events/1035576393129873/

story:
Recréer La croix du mont Royal de Pierre Ayot
(en collaboration avec Denis Forcier)

Dans le cadre d'une rétrospective majeure sur Pierre Ayot (1943-1995) orchestrée par le commissaire et critique d’art Nicolas Mavrikakis réunissant plusieurs lieux de diffusion dont la BAnQ, la Fondation Guido Molinari, la Galerie Graff, la Galerie Joyce Yahouda, le Musée d'art de Joliette et le Musée des Beaux-Arts de Montréal, la Galerie B-312 présente deux projets autour de la croix : sa recréation* et Res Ipsa Loquitur, une exposition autour de l’événement Corridart. 

Rappelons que le maire de Montréal, Jean Drapeau, fit détruire, quelques heures avant l'ouverture des Jeux olympiques de 1976, les œuvres de Corridart, une exposition d’art public qui s'étalait sur plusieurs kilomètres de la rue Sherbrooke. Pourtant cette exposition avait été commandée par le Comité d'organisation des Jeux olympiques....

L'œuvre La croix du mont Royal était une réplique à échelle réduite (44 pieds de long par 20 pieds de haut et 4 pieds de large) de la structure de la croix qui surplombe le mont Royal. Cette œuvre, initialement présentée sur le terrain de l’Université McGill, sera cette fois-ci installée au pied du mont Royal, au coin de l'avenue du Parc et de l'avenue des Pins. Comme le voulait Ayot, la croix semblera être venue se reposer quelques moments au bas de la montagne…

Nous avons aussi choisi cet endroit car il permettra certainement de réfléchir à l'avenir des bâtiments de l'Hôtel-Dieu alors que l'hôpital qu'il hébergeait est en processus de délocalisation. Quel destin sera réservé à cet héritage, à ce patrimoine religieux et architectural?

Cette recréation de l’œuvre de Pierre Ayot (en collaboration avec Denis Forcier) sera exposée pour une durée de deux mois, de la fin septembre à la fin novembre 2016. L’exposition s’y rattachant sera présentée à la Galerie B-312 du 15 octobre au 12 novembre 2016.

Nous avons déjà reçu l’appui du Bureau d’art public de la Ville de Montréal, de l'Arrondissement Plateau-Mont-Royal, du Conseil des Arts de Montréal et de la Caisse populaire du Plateau-Mont-Royal (10 000 $, 10 000 $, 5 000 $ et près de 3000 $ respectivement). Il nous reste un peu moins de 13 000 $** à trouver. 

Nous avons besoin de vous !

Joignez-vous à nous pour ce projet fabuleux : Voir la croix dont tout le monde a entendu parler mais que personne n’a vue !
Rendez hommage à un artiste majeur de l’histoire de l’art au Québec.
Participez concrètement à la réalisation d’une œuvre d’envergure.

N’oubliez pas : toute donation de plus de 25 $ sera accompagnée d’un reçu pour déduction fiscale. Celui-ci vous sera envoyé à la fin du mois d'octobre.

* La recréation de la croix est une idée originale de Nicolas Mavrikakis.

** Il est impossible de modifier le montant de l'objectif dans les campagnes de financement sur la plate-forme Indiegogo, c'est pourquoi nous vous informons de la diminution de cet objectif dans le texte. Il passe donc de 16 000$ à 13 000$ à la suite de la réception d'une nouvelle subvention.
Nous vous informerons lorsque les sacs seront disponibles.


Biographie 
Pierre Ayot est né à Montréal en 1943. Diplômé de l’École des beaux-arts de Montréal, il y a enseigné de 1964 à 1972, puis, jusqu’en 1995 à l’Université du Québec à Montréal. En 1966, il fonde « l’Atelier Libre 848 », un atelier collectif, qui deviendra « Graff » par la suite. Il fut également un des membres fondateurs du groupe « Média, gravures et multiples ». Ses œuvres, d’abord reliées à la pratique de l’estampe, sont issues du Pop art et de l’animation d’Albert Dumouchel, deux phénomènes dont il a tiré le meilleur parti avant de les déborder de toutes parts en réalisant autant de la sculpture, de la peinture que des installations sonores et visuelles. Il a tenu plus de trente expositions personnelles de 1965 à 1995 au Canada et à l’étranger en plus de participer à de nombreuses expositions collectives. Ses oeuvres font partie de la plupart des grandes collections publiques et corporatives canadiennes et de quelques collections à l’étranger dont celles du Musée d’art moderne de New York et du Tate Gallery de Londres. Le Musée des beaux-arts de Montréal a présenté une importante rétrospective de son travail en 2001 sous le titre de « Pierre Ayot hors-cadre ». Pierre Ayot est décédé le 2 mai 1995.
(Source : Galerie Graff)

Ses œuvres, d’abord reliées à la pratique de l’estampe, sont issues du Pop art et de l’animation d’Albert Dumouchel, deux phénomènes dont il a tiré le meilleur parti avant de les déborder de toutes parts en réalisant autant de la sculpture, de la peinture que des installations sonores et visuelles. Il a tenu plus de trente expositions personnelles de 1965 à 1995 au Canada et à l’étranger en plus de participer à de nombreuses expositions collectives. Ses oeuvres font partie de la plupart des grandes collections publiques et corporatives canadiennes et de quelques collections à l’étranger dont celles du Musée d’art moderne de New York et du Tate Gallery de Londres. Le Musée des beaux-arts de Montréal a présenté une importante rétrospective de son travail en 2001 sous le titre de « Pierre Ayot hors-cadre ». Pierre Ayot est décédé le 2 mai 1995.(Source : Galerie Graff)

story:
Summary: Who I Am

Claire Lorenzo is visual artist living and working in Brooklyn, NY.  She has been creating hand-cut collage art for nearly a decade.  Her material draws on old, yellowing pages from paperback books, vintage maps, Life magazines, black and white photographs, found postcards, and forgotten letters.

In late 2015, Claire launched In Pieces, a collage-design inspired line of screen-printed clothing (denim jackets, sweatshirts, tees) and recycled homeware (flower vases, jewelry boxes, ornaments) featuring her original analog collages.  She successfully sold a portion of these items in the Williamsburg Artist & Fleas art market, the ADC Holiday Bazaar, and through her Etsy Shop, In Pieces Art.

Her work, July 1981, was awarded Runner-Up in Greenpoint Gallery’s November 2015 Salon Exhibition.

What I Want to Do Now

Her latest collage endeavor will take Claire outside of the city and to upstate New York, to the The Art Students League of New York’s May 2016 Artist Residency Program. During the short but sweet 28-day program, Claire will return to the traditional fine art medium, creating a large scale (49 sq. ft.) collage, which will attempt to explore the theme of rampant misogyny in popular American magazines. 

Drawing on vintage Life and National Geographic magazines from the 1950s-1980s, Claire’s art isolates various traditional highly-misogynist American advertisements, and them reinvents them—turning them on their heads, and eliciting new meanings.  By removing these advertisements from their original pages, and then transforming them into something different, Claire hopes to call attention to how deeply engrained misogyny was, and still is, in our visual American consumer culture.

Why This Residency

The Art Students League of New York’s residency program will provide me the opportunity to explore my art in a fresh context.  I’ll be able to gather feedback from likeminded artists and advisers in a new and supportive environment.  Simply put, I have not been able to create any large-scale work like the 6 foot pieces I created for my thesis at Fordham University in 2013.  My apartment is simply too small, and it isn’t financially possible to afford another art studio in Brooklyn, NY.

Someone once explained a residency like going camping: “you venture out of your usual environment to experience the wild and unknown, knowing you will come back home.

Impact: Where Your Donations Will Go

By contributing to this campaign, your donations will enable me to participate in the May 2016 Vytacil Art Students League Residency.  If met, the $3000 goal will cover my costs to enroll in the program: residency deposit, housing, art materials, as well as transportation to the location. 

With your contribution, I will be able to work day and night for 28 days in order to create this work.  Your dollars will literally go towards lighting my studio, and paying for the canvas and supplies needed to fulfill project.

The Vytacil Residency program is highly selective, only accepting less than 10% of applicants.  I was selected as one of six candidates out of over a hundred applicants for the May 2016 residency.  If I am unable to meet the program costs, my spot will be immediately forfeited to someone else and I will not be able to attend the program.

What You Get in Return

Contributions of $100 or more will entitle you to an original, limited-edition, signed art print by the artist, featuring an original Claire Lorenzo collage.

A donation of any amount will entitle you to an invitation to the end of program exhibition at the Art Students League of New York’s Vytacil estate in Sparkill, NY on the evening of May 27th 2016.

Thank you for your time and generous donations.  I could not do any of this without your support!


-Claire Lorenzo

story:
MEXICO WANTS US

A group of Canadian artists - Basil AlZeri, Golboo Amani, Francisco Fernando Granados, Manolo Lugo, Naufus Ramirez-Figueroa, Maryam Taghavi and guest curator Maggie Flynn - have been invited to participate in the TRANSMUTED  International Performance Festival at Ex Teresa Arte Actual, curated by Pancho Lopez, in Mexico City from April 26-27th.

WE WANT MEXICO

As a group of performance artists, we are thrilled at the opportunity to represent the Toronto & Vancouver performance art scenes internationally. Since the brutality of colonisation, Mexico City has been the cultural centre for Latin America, turning its tumultuous history into raw material for artistic expression. Today, the sheer volume of people and activity encompasses its arts community with an energy unparalleled elsewhere. We're thrilled at the opportunity to present work in this context. That is why we need to go. 

GIVE US TO MEXICO

The organizers of the TRANSMUTED International Performance Festival have generously provided us with accommodation, food and materials for our performances. However, we need your help to pay for our travel. Your donations will go directly to covering the costs of our plane tickets. We've worked hard to get to this point, now we need your help to get us there. Any donation you can make is extremely appreciated. 

WE'LL GIVE YOU OUR BODIES

In addition to limited edition artist multiples, rectified readymades, and a hand-printed publication, we're offering skype and live private performances. Take a moment to take in the options. 

SEE US IN TORONTO

If you're in Toronto, we've organized a performance event, TO | DF,  at The White House, March 24, 2012, 8pm. We'll be warming up for our performances in Mexico. Performances by: Basil AlZeri, Golboo Amani, Francisco Fernando Granados, Manolo Lugo, and Maryam Taghavi. Guest Curator: Maggie Flynn
Full info here: http://todftransmuted.wordpress.com/
 
THANK YOU FOR YOUR TIME AND ATTENTION!

story:
Hello, we are Applepond - a group of 3 tenacious BA(Hons) Contemporary Media Practice students on a quest to raise enough funds to make our final major project a reality!

 

So, let us give you the rundown: our project is a ‘knockoff’ ( or simulacrum if you’re fancy) of the American infomercial. Now you might be thinking - ‘Hey, aren’t infomercials those really corny adverts that try sell people magic mops and stuff?’ Well, we can reassure you that you are exactly right! However our art piece is far more than just an advert you might see between the hours of 2 am - 5 am on your TV. No no no, we thought why not take the bad taste of infomercials to the next level and create a physical space for everyone to be a part of.

 

Basically, we have decided to create our own make-believe country to reflect the delightful cheesiness of infomercials and the consumeristic values they represent within western culture today. Sound exciting? We sure hope so!

 

Now, in order to create our own make-believe country and make it the best make-believe country we know it can be, we need a little bit of cash for the necessities. Things such as: wooden boards, wallpaper, printing ink, swimming pool, and a remote-controlled cruise ship. You know, everything you’d expect would be needed in order to create your own make-believe country!

 

Our degree show will be on the 4th - 8th of June at the Ambika P3 gallery space in Baker Street.

All are invited to experience our installation for themselves, as well as enjoy the other art pieces that will be at the show!

 

Any contributions would be much appreciated and really help us take our project off the ground. Thank you for taking the time to have a cheeky look at our funding page, and we hope to see you at the show!

 

Much love, Applepond

story:
Imagine a 600,000 square mile patch of the Pacific ocean (twice the size of Texas) made up of trash; large, small and even minute pieces of plastic. Fish and other marine life are consuming this passtic and dying. 

We are raising money to build an Art Sculpture for Burning Man 2020 to call attention to this trajedy.  The 70,000 Burning Man participants who will see Diner with a Whale and learn about the effect of our trash on marine animals and then be able to be part of the change that needs to take place. 

The focus of the art piece will be a dining room table with four marine animals sitting down to eat a meal of plastics and trash.  There will be interactive sound and visuals to draw people to the piece and engage them in the experience. 

All labor is volunteer and many materials are recycled or reused. We need donations for materials that must be purchased new, for the cost of transportation to and from Burning Man and a few other needs.

We appreciate donations of any amount. Your donation will enable us to make the art piece to share the often fatal damage that trash generated by humans is causing to marine life.

story:
Story behind the exhibition  

My name is Dandi Gu, an M.A. Candidate majoring in Business Design and Arts Leadership at Savannah College of Art and Design (SCAD). To fulfill the final project of my M.A. program, I will curate a Folk Art Exhibition titled “Secrets Behind Closed Doors” from March 2nd to 4th at Sulfur Studio, 2301 Bull Street in Savannah, Georgia. The opening reception will be on March 2nd, from 6 pm to 9 pm. This is my first time to curate and conduct an art exhibition. I am so excited about the following happenings. And I will be responsible for all the details to secure the success of the exhibition.

I am so grateful that I have always been able to follow my heart and continue to peruse my art dreams in the United States. The more I explore, the more motivated I become. I realize I am so attracted to raw art because the people known as folk artists or self-taught artists are sincerely passionate about their work. For my perspectives, folk artists are serious about using art as a tool to tell their stories. Their artworks are pure, organic and full of direct feelings. Their perspectives are not perspectives but attitudes about love, life, and society. Their artwork tells the truth and reflects the culture and life of their world.

When it came to my final project, I decided to offer something inspiring, showing the work of artists that I am passionate about. Coincidentally, I met Sue Martinez. She is a Savannah-based emerging artist. She is good at making crafts, design playing board games, and paintings. When I looked at her artworks, I was surprised. How did she make it with a tiny brush, what’s in her mind, and I wondered what happened to her during her life?

 

Exhibition Value

Sue’s paintings can be read as a version of American cultural life and a working notebook that uses art as an expressive tool to tell the hidden stories of family struggle, ordinary life, landscapes, and folkways. The paintings present a way to rise from sorrow to joy. I believe there are many artists, like Sue, who are talented and passionate about the art; they need our support, and in turn, their artwork can brighten the community, where we live. I hope the exhibition serves as an inspiration for everyone engagement and connect art lovers and community. I am looking forward to your support.

 

What will we need?

This IndieGoGo online crowdfunding campaign will support the exhibition to raise money and cover the exhibition budget. All of the funds raised by IndieGoGo crowdfunding campaign will be applied entirely to the expenditures of the exhibition. Of course, I will search the best deals and manage my expenses, including a likely venue to exhibit artworks, efficient marketing materials prints, and food and drinks for the opening reception. The budget of “Secrets Behind Closed Doors” is $1552, the details below:

Exhibition Expenditures

  • $500 for 4 days Sulfur Studios Rental Fee
  • $250 for Food and Beverage
  • $60 for Installation Materials
  • $50 for Art Labels
  • $150 for Unknown Risks

Marketing Promotional Materials

  • $200 for 60 Posters Prints
  • $160 for Flyers+ Exhibition Catalogues
  • $182 for 500 Postcards Prints

 

Perks

  • BRONZE ($5- $49): A thank you letter via email.
  • SILVER ($50- $99): Name displayed in the social media campaign and thank you note via email.
  • GOLD ($100-199): Social media mention, thank you note via email, and a studio visit;
  • PLATINUM ($200 +): All the above, plus your name displayed in the exhibition catalog and one customized tote bag.

 

Other Ways to Help

  • Join and share the “Secrets”  Facebook Event Page 
  • Share and support this “Secrets”  Indiegogo Crowdfunding Campaign with your family and your friends.

 

I appreciate your support and your concern. Your support will make this exhibition happen. If you have any questions, please contact me at email  gudandi1014@gmail.com

 

Best wishes,

Dandi Gu

Curator and manager of the exhibition “Secrets Behind Closed Doors”

story:
ABANDONED AMERICA - PART 01 - NORTHEAST

  • An Expansion Of The Forgotten Iowa Photography Project
  • I have developed a deep love for old buildings and the historical significance of them.  After exploring Pennsylvania a handful of times, I became absolutely fascinated at the architecture.  Some buildings were older than the state of Iowa. 

The first town I photographed in Pennsylvania was a town called West Alexander.  Though not exactly a ghost town, per say, there was indeed a wealth of amazing buildings and I spent a long time there photographing them all.  I snagged images like this:

And I momentarily lamented the fact that I only had a few days there to explore.  I made it as far east as the now infamous ghost town Centrailia and spent my evening walking their spray-painted, dead roads and marveling at the town that used to be:

What We Need & What You Get

There are a few major places of interest that I'd like to photograph.  They include:

  • Frick's Lock Abandoned Village, Pennsylvania
  • Pithole, Pennsylvania
  • Conashaugh, Pennsylvania
  • Petroleum Center, Pennsylvania
  • Whitewash Village, Pennsylvania
  • Fire Creek, West Virginia
  • Alum Springs, West Virginia
  • Lignite, Virginia
  • Warwick, Virginia
  • Doodletown, New York
  • Shavertown, New York
  • Flagstaff, Maine
  • Glenville, Delaware
  • Woodland Beach, Delaware
  • Carrigain, New Hampshire
  • Zealand, New Hampsire
  • Kilkenny, New Hampsire
  • Catamount, Massachusetts
  • Dogtown, Massachusetts

The plan is to stay at cheap fleabag motels and spend entire days in or near the ghost towns mentioned above.  These aren't the only stops along the way, but they are the main ones.

The Impact

All photos and videos will be posted here.  The journey will be documented and published as I make my way through and you'll be able to track the progress in real-time.  Updates will be posted on the blog, on instagram, and on Snapchat.

Risks & Challenges

As a mixed-media artist living in Nowhere, USA, I tend to live hand-to-mouth and this idea simply isn't feasible without the help of the fans and supporters of FORGOTTEN IOWA.  There is two years and thousands of photos to showcase the kind of work I do and I think that the best is really yet to come.

  • Really, it all boils down to capital.  With the proper investment, I can take two months of my life and dedicate it solely to this.  I can think of no better way to spend my early-winter than exploring the ghost towns and abandoned communities of Northeast America.  
  • Luck is on our side when it comes to finding places to sleep.  Hotels in small towns tend to be much, much, much cheaper than the hotels you'd find in major metropolitan areas.  The goal is modest and I think it's totally doable.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help financially but live in the area and have a couch to crash on, that would be wonderful!  If not that, just spread this link around and try to help me build some momentum as the next 30 days unfold!

story:
You've had a dream... so why supporting an emerging artist?

Since I'm a little kid, I've loved drawing, painting and doing all sorts of art but as I grew up, adults confronted me with their view of reality: go study civil engineering because anyway you'll never make a living being an artist. And that's when all my dreams of being an artist faded away. I launched myself in a career of training and coaching, gave 2 TED talks and I started a non profit to help others fulfill their dreams. 

In 2011, I was given a 10 years old camera to have fun with and posted a few photos on Facebook. Fast forward two years and I've got over 700 High Dynamic Range photos on Facebook, I've organized an exhibition in London, I've been selected for the Brussels Art Fair and I've published two photo books. 

Since I've had the camera it's been a little temperamental but it is only during my last photo shoot in the Bronx, New York, I realized my camera didn't save almost 50% of the photos taken and I had to stop taking photos because it was giving me too many error messages. 

Unfortunately, the adults were right up about the beginning of this journey: none of these exciting things has brought enough money to buy a new camera. 

I love taking photos because it is a way to show the world under a different lens. People often tell me that I make places look more beautiful than the way they saw it before. I like to believe that with my photography, I can make people smile and have a better day. You can help me continue taking photos by supporting me here. 

What I Need

Every little helps: even if you can contribute only $1, please do it because the value of this $1 to my motivation will be 100 folds! Knowing that you support me and believe in my art is the most important. 

I'm not being very fancy: all I need is a new camera to continue sharing my photos on Facebook and build a career as a photographer. What can be more rewarding than sponsoring an emerging artist before he's been successful? It is now that I'm struggling with finances that I need your help :)

  • $1,199 will get me this new camera, which has 24MP (versus my current 6MP) and takes 5 photos with different exposures so that my photos will look even more beautiful: all cheaper models (like mine) only takes 3 photos with different exposures
  • For every other $1,000 - $2,000 and I can take photos of the city of your choice: all I need is to cover flights, food and for accommodation I'm sure CouchSurfing will make it easier to reduce costs :)
  • Is there anything else you'd like me to do with my photography?

What You Get

  • Every supporter will get a big thank you on the website
  • For $25, I will also thank you in my next photo book
  • For $60, I will send you a 12x8 inch print of your choice
  • For $100, I will send you a 24x15 inch poster of your choice 
  • For $200, I will send you a 33x21 inch poster of your choice
  • For $600, I will send you an 18x12 inch canvas of your choice or a copy of the book "Beauty Lies in the Eyes of the Observer"
  • For $900, I will send you a 30x20 inch canvas of your choice
  • For $1,300, I will send you a 30x20 inch canvas of your choice and a copy of "Beauty Lies in the Eyes of the Observer"
  • For $2,000, you can commission the photo of your choice: tell me what you like and what you want, I will take and produce this photo exclusively for you. You will receive it in a 40x30 inch canvas and a copy of "Beauty Lies in the Eyes of the Observer"

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help in other ways, you can:

  • Sharing this link with your network on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Pinterest and other social networks
  • Introduce me to people who may be interested in exhibiting my photos
  • Introduce me to people who may be interested in buying some photos
  • Tell art magazines or websites about my photos so that I get more professional reviews
  • Any other ideas on how you can help will be highly appreciated :)

story:
Description

"Soul Trap" is an interactive art project based on the visual communication of the viewer and the installation. Upon entering a confined dark space, the visitor encounters a rather eerie setting with his reflection trapped in a glass cube, mirroring his actions. While leaving, he realizes that he has left a part of him behind, his reflection remaining there, as if the soul has been trapped inside the cube.


Who we are

We are a team of young creators coming from the fields of architecture & informatics. Our base is the city of Thessaloniki, Greece.


Why to contribute

This installation is a personal inspiration that came up through a period of changes. Every cent is gonna be a real boost in our effort to bring the idea to life. More specific, we try to raise funds in order to cover the cost of our materials:

  • projector
  • camera
  • smoke machine
  • plexiglass cube
  • curtain
  • cables
  • timer


Plan

Everything has to be ready up to January, when "Soul Trap" will be revealed in an exhibition curated by DynamoProjectSpace (http://dynamoprojectspace.blogspot.gr/).

story:
Hey!

I’m Obui, a 23 year old Creative Director with a few other titles that come with unpaid work that's worth a lot and does a lot but doesn't seem to pay the bills.

The journal came from an obsessive-compulsive tendency to collect critique and create publications, 

 

Oi! was created to serves as a consciousness raising bedrock for creatives like myself who are talented intelligent, intellectual, culturally enlightened, with a good sense of humour. A place to collaborate, share ideas, creatively critique and enhance society as a whole whilst simultaneously establishing a space for promotion where others can find artists, writers and inventive specialists to collaborate with, hire, commission, endorse, or fund.

The journal’s first issue was launched in February from my bedroom (using my smashed Macbook screen to navigate the internet) after 3 months with the help of some fantastically passionate contributors who put their best forward at no cost.

Initially published online, I realised there was a bigger demand to obtain the journal in print than I had imagined; after 17 days it received 1452 hits with an average of 4 minutes spent reading and numerous emails asking how and where it can be purchased.

As I began planning the Autumn Winter Issue I realised I’d need a budget to help future contributors exercise their skills accordingly.

Reality Check, tangible resources…

And after a month of extensive additional research into printing, (as mentioned before, yuh, bit OCD with publications) I realised the best way to physically bring this publication to life, each journal hand to be individually handcrafted, like an Art sketchbook.

Not just that, it would need a small team of knowledgeable, resourceful Marketers, PR, Online Content producers and Event Managers to bring the Journal to complete fruition, spreading awareness, and also organizing the distribution and launch event in September. Things I tried to do alone and realised was almost practically impossible and needed to be done right, in order to be done well.

So, what are the costs you say?

  • 5 months Creative Consultancy – PR/ Marketing/ Event Management - £1000

I mentioned before, I’m just a Curator/ Creative Director, I can put ideas together and bring out the best in people, that’s my strength, but with the help of professional business team Oi! can get the help it needs to actualize its potential.

  • Contributors Travel and Creative Equipment expenses - £250

Although we do not have a budget for this journal, we can help our creative contributors help us by paying for travel expenses, studio time and any equipment needed to create decent content.

  • Printing and Packaging Expenses £900

Feedback and analysis show that although we are a very tech savvy generation we still desire the tangible and the physical pleasures, so to keep a fair balance we have decided to print and handcraft 500 copies;

125 of each edition for schools, Universities, charities, and youth clubs.  

Free education is vital to the success and enlightenment of our peers, younger and old. And we want to be able to reach them no matter where they are like a light in a dark tunnel.

The Impact

Because of the privatisation of creativity and creative institutions, someone somewhere owns our right to express ourselves as Creatives. Someone somewhere dictates our future as Creatives, teaching us to conform to a more logical and subservient working life that benefits them and leaves us broken, confused and robotic. With cuts to funding for the arts, a prodigious rise in tuition fees, and a lack of jobs for graduates, undergraduates and Creatives alike. What are we expected to do?

Well we can start by sharing ideas, collaborating and keeping a fluid evolving journal on our experiences in, and thoughts on, society and hopefully find ways to stay productive, building a foundation of sustainability and future security using our talents and knowledge.

And what do you get in return for your special contribution?

2 Print copies of Oi! Issue 1 SS14 & AW14 + Manifesto & Launch Party ticket - £20

Well we’ve curated this really cool Exclusive Manifesto Time Capsule that creatively critiques a future after the demise of print publications by creating an art piece that looks back to 2014 ‘unearthing’ a capsule, which has stored the precious creating tools we used to use to create ideas by hand during a transitional era from paper to digital; and these packages are attainable versions of this installation which will be exhibited live at the Launch Party in September.

25 x Exclusive Manifesto (Time Capsule) Package £25 - £80 includes:

·  2 Print copies of Oi! SS14 and AW14.

·  Oi! Manifesto

·  A7 drawing sketchpad

·  1 Fine liner

·  1 Pencil

·  1 USB 

·  Eraser

·  Oi! Mood Mix

·  Clippings from newspaper articles with a4 sheet for ideas

·  1 ticket to OI! Manifesto Time Capsule Installation /Launch Party

·  1 Secret gift up to the value of £10 - £65


Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone will be able to contribute and know what it feels like to be passionate about something but not have enough to fund it, but contribution comes in many shapes and forms; even spreading the news to others who might be interested in reading or contributing to the journal.

Helping us to make as many people aware as much as possible would be very much appreciated and crucial to Oi!‘s campaign success. I only have 40 days to raise the funds, and get the major work for the Autumn Winter content ready for release for the event in September.

Tweet it, Blog it, Facebook it, Reblog on Tumblr, and don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!


Oi!?  This is for us!


Much thanks, love and Creativity from,

Obuineke

: meaning - ‘it is you who creates’

Thanks mum! No pressure at all!

xx

story:
Hey there, lovelies. MC Sunflower Jones is a kitschy-chic production consisting of the of us, two lovebird zinesters, Deirdree Prudence & Steven Hughes Purkey, making zines non-stop ‘cause zines are our lives & we adore it. We make zines for us & we make zines for you. With you. For us & for you.

We started this campaign because we’re the epitome of starving artists – what we lack in funds we make up for in an inspiring creativity that overflows with motivation & non-stop love. We want to make the greatest zine ever & have it in the hands of as many people as possible – a grand adventure but we need your help! Join us on this ride & we will show you a crazy artistic blast like no other!

This zine, What’s Your Damage? – Mental Illness & Shit!, will be the talk of the town. There have been other mental health zines out there, there will be more, but this, dear reader, will be “it”. A pop-culture bonanza of psychotropic drugs, interviews from shrinks, profiles on the insane, reviews of other mental health zines, hilarious tales of depression, personality disorders, you name it, if it pops it’s in. The cherry on the top, however, will be the companion microzines detailing each of the most popular disorders from Schizoaffective to Borderline Personality. A glorious comp zine filled with international contributors straight outta the psych ward accompanied by microzines that will only make you smile. A demented smile. A smile shared from us to you.

We love zines. We love you. We want to share our love with you. But, dear reader, it’s expensive. It takes money & we need your help! Take a peek into the backstage creative monster of a madhouse, of the zinester creator:

MC Sunflower Jones is the name of our copy machine. Every true zinester needs one to call their own. Fuck Kinko’s. But we need toner. Lots of toner. Toner to print this batty gem of a project!

We need paper. Lots & lots of paper. White paper galore. & for the cover? Here’s a sneaky peek: a dream would come true with you help – cardstock the color of psych ward walls. This zine deserves only the best, the contributors deserve only the best, the readers deserve only the best & a heavy cardstock cover is where it’s at.

Staples. Metallic blue staples. Only the best for this zine.

Buttons. We need buttons & they’re cheap to make but remember, dear reader, the starving part of ‘starving artist’. Buttons would be awesome. We want the stark raving mad smiles of What’s Your Damage? to be carried around on your lapel even after the brilliantly cracked pages are put down.

Stickers. See above & replace buttons with stickers.

Once the zine is done, hot off the press, distribution is insanity. It takes cold hard cash but those smiles, smiles from contributors & readers & you, those smiles are needed in this world. Postage & postal supplies. We want them everywhere. We want the post office gang to hate us. Or love us. We want to know them by name.

With every donation there comes a present from us to you. Every single donor will get a smile in return. We have gifts! They will be in the form of some of these things: a copy of the zine & microzines, a button, a hand-painted postcard from Deirdree, MC Sunflower Jones zines aplenty, handwritten love letters, stickers, & your name in print within the zine!

We want the world to enjoy the madness that is What’s Your Damage? – Mental Illness & Shit! Because people need to feel the love & comfort of flashy solidarity in what can be a lonely existence when coping with psychological issues. We want people to laugh at depression. Smile at the silliness of their anxiety. We want you to enjoy the lunacy that is you you you.

We want the zine at every zine library. Every retailer that carries zines. Across the world. The contributors deserve it - & you deserve the thrill that comes with their words & art.

MC Sunflower Jones has been called prolific & inspiring & all that jazz. We really live the life of the hardcore zinester. We have sold our zines at large zine fests. We have sold our zines at smaller events. Shops that don’t even carry zines display MC Sunflower Jones’ shit with pride. We can do this. It’s a magical adventure & we want you to tag along. With your help we can make this happen.

We def understand that not everyone can donate cold hard cash (or numbers on a computer screen). If you can’t, don’t fret ‘cause your anxiety is our anxiety in this rode paved with Prozac. We still need your support! Contribute some art! Tell us a tale of your love affair with your therapist! Rip out your journal pages from Cognitive Behavior Therapy daze & send them to us!

We also need your support by sharing this campaign with your friends…if you know of anyone who might need the light-hearted security blanket of this zine, send them our way & we’ll make new friends. Sharing is caring, said the Care Bears in the ‘8Os. Sharing is caring & we care a lot.

 Join us on this escapade – we’ll have a good time.

story:
The Play:

The Tired Sounds of Fallen Angels is a new play written and directed by Jelani Cornick. This plays explores the true meaning of perfection by creating two worlds that parallel each other; one that tells the famous story of The Fall of Lucifer and another that tells the story of five individuals, stuck in the North Tower of the World Trade Center before it falls to the ground.

Cast:

  • Kamal Bassma - Mr. Mahoney / Lucifer
  • Azario Mastrangelo - Mr. Eckna / God
  • Erick Issacson - Mr. Nedd / Angel / Ensemble
  • Francesca Litz - Ms. Eagan / Angel / Ensemble 
  • Lauren Varner Timothy - Ms. Ellis / Angel / Ensemble 

Crew:

  • Jelani Cornick - Director 
  • Assistant Director - Azario Mastrangelo 
  • Stage Manager: Jessica Yost
  • Assistant Stage Manager:  Tara Goodman 
  • Assistant Stage Manager: Bria Murry 
  • Dramaturge: Leyla Gentil 
  • Technical Director: Kevin Downing
  • Sound Designer: Zachary Dobryn 
  • Stage Combat - Anthony Mita  

What is this all about?

Hello, my name is Jelani Cornick, and I am a sophomore Theatre and Performance major at Purchase College. I am the creator of Anima Vox, a theatre company that inspires collaborative creation of stories in order to affect a community. The goal is to create epic, dynamic theatre that both excites and informs audience members about the complexities of society and life. 

Each member of Anima Vox is a student enrolled in Purchase College that is inspired and driven to make theatre. Although Vox is a small and new theatre company, everyday we see more growth and understanding in each other as company members and as artist, and this is what the goal of the company is, and will always be.

The Tired Sounds of Fallen Angels will be Anima Vox's first official performance as a theatre company. We are looking to start the company off with a high note; a show that will allow the cast, crew, and artistic team to shine brightly. Please help us breathe life into this show and further our goals to touch anyone who comes to see it.

What we need:

Our prospective budget for the show is relatively small. We are only in need of $1,500 in order to pay for:

  • 50%: Set Design of Show ($750)
  • 22%: Props ($330)
  • 12%: Marketing ($180)
  • 12%: Costumes ($180)
  • 4%: Indiegogo Royalty ($60)

Any surplus money that is received will be kept and used for upcoming projects in the company. 

Please help and support us. Another way to help is by getting the word out there! Share this page with your family and friends. Make people aware of our project. The more people we have on our team, the better chance we can see this project come alive.
story_txt:
The Play:The Tired Sounds of Fallen Angels is a new play written and directed by Jelani Cornick. This plays explores the true meaning of perfection by creating two worlds that parallel each other; one that tells the famous story of The Fall of Lucifer and another that tells the story of five individuals, stuck in the North Tower of the World Trade Center before it falls to the ground.Cast:

Kamal Bassma - Mr. Mahoney / Lucifer


Azario Mastrangelo - Mr. Eckna / God


Erick Issacson - Mr. Nedd / Angel / Ensemble


Francesca Litz - Ms. Eagan / Angel / Ensemble 


Lauren Varner Timothy - Ms. Ellis / Angel / Ensemble 

Crew:

Jelani Cornick - Director

Stage Manager: Jessica Yost


Assistant Stage Manager:  Tara Goodman

story:
scroll down for english version 


www.altrovefestival.it

Here it is the confirmed line up. Just looking forward to see these amazing artists!
But stay updated, surprises are coming!


(IT)

Cos'è ALT!rove?

ALT!rove è un festival di street art che si svolgerà a Catanzaro dal 1 al 10 maggio 2014.

Artisti del calibro di 2501, Moneyless, Run, Tellas, Ciredz, Sbagliato, Domenico Romeo, Martina Merlini, Bue2530, GLoois, DMS e possibili guests, reinventeranno simboli cardine della città, ormai logorati dal tempo. 

Un raggio d'azione che interesserà l'intero territorio urbano: dall'ospedale civile vecchio, in pieno centro ed abbandonato a sé stesso da più di mezzo secolo, all'ex mercato di Catanzaro Lido, segno di un'attività economica fiorente ormai abbandonata, passando per i punti di riferimento dei quartieri in periferia, come il Palacorvo a sud della città.

Per riqualificare attraverso la diffusione su scala urbana dell'arte e della cultura, proponendo un nuovo punto di vista sulla città e della città, un’immagine nuova che crei la sensazione di vivere in un altro luogo. Altrove.


Perché il crowdfunding?

Perché offre a tutti la possibilità di partecipare attivamente al finanziamento del festival. Chiunque può mettere la firma ed essere ricompensato simbolicamente o materialmente in funzione della donazione.

Il raggiungimento del target ci permetterà di coprire le spese vive per la realizzazione delle opere: vernici e materiale tecnico, strutture di supporto, spese di trasporto, vitto e alloggio degli artisti. 

In caso di superamento del target, tutto verrà reinvestito per aumentare la qualità del festival, proponendo diversi eventi collaterali, quali: 

• dibattiti sulla fruizione dell'arte nello spazio pubblico e sulla trasformazione degli edifici interessati in spazi sociali e culturali; 

• una mostra indoor realizzata dagli stessi artisti;

• una pubblicazione iconografica che racconti la realizzazione delle grandi opere murarie;

• eventi musicali di presentazione e chiusura del festival.

Ricompense

10 € • Grazie! -  Siamo lieti che il progetto ti piaccia. Grazie per il tuo supporto. Sei la radice che permetterà al festival di crescere. Sii orgoglioso.

30 € • Il tuo nome sulla lista dedicata - Il tuo nome uscirà sulla lista dedicata, in ordine alfabetico. + Personale lettera di ringraziamento con la foto del tuo muro preferito. + Sticker.

50 € • Il tuo nome sul MURO dedicato! - Dedicheremo un muro di ringraziamento, in pieno centro storico, per voi donatori! Il tuo nome verrà scritto con la tecnica dello stencil, ed essere tu stesso un opera d'arte urbana.

60 € • G Loois, serigrafia 21x29,7 [cm] - Serigrafia di G Loois in edizione limitata, in formato A4, numerata e firmata dall'artista. Tiratura di 50 copie. + Personale lettera di ringraziamento con la foto del tuo muro preferito. + Sticker. http://www.altrovefestival.it/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/G-Loois-artwork.jpg

150 € • Claudio Jaccarino, dipinto 35x40 [cm] - Acquerello in scala di grigi di Claudio Jaccarino. Opera gentilmente offerta dalla collezione privata di Franco Daddo di Artinflat. + Personale lettera di ringraziamento con la foto del tuo muro preferito. + Sticker. http://www.altrovefestival.it/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Jaccarino1.jpeg

150 € • Claudio Jaccarino, dipinto 35x40 [cm] - Acquerello a colori di Claudio Jaccarino. Opera gentilmente offerta dalla collezione privata di Franco Daddo di Artinflat. + Personale lettera di ringraziamento con la foto del tuo muro preferito. + Sticker. http://www.altrovefestival.it/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Jaccarino2.jpeg

200 € • G Loois, serigrafia 29,7x42 [cm] - Serigrafia di G Loois in edizione limitata, in formato A3, numerata e firmata dall'artista. Tiratura di 20 copie. + Personale lettera di ringraziamento con la foto del tuo muro preferito. + Sticker. http://www.altrovefestival.it/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/G-Loois-artwork-29.7x42-cm.jpg


(EN)

What's ALT!rove?

ALT!rove is a street art festival that will take place in Catanzaro from 1st to 10th May 2014.

Artists of the likes of 2501, Moneyless, Run, Tellas, Ciredz, Sbagliato, Domenico Romeo, Martina Merlini, Bue2530, GLoois, DMS and possible guest artists will reinterpret the key symbols of the city, that have been worn out by time.

The festival's action range will interest the whole urban area: from the old civil hospital, located in the heart of the town and that has been deserted for the past 50 years, to the old borough market of the Catanzaro shore, proof of a former fluorishing trade activity that is no longer such, going through suburban landmarks such as Palacorvo situated in the southern part of the city.

To redevelop through spreading arts and culture round the city, suggesting a new point of view on the city and of the city, a new image that can evoke the feeling of living somewhere else. Altrove.

Why crowdfunding?

Because it offers everyone the possibility to actively participate in financing the festival. Anyone can sign and symbolically be rewarded, depending on the amount of their contribution.

Achieving our goal will allow us to cover eligible costs for the realisation of the works: paints and technical material, supporting structures, transport expenses, board and lodging for the artists.

Tiratura di 20 copie. + Personale lettera di ringraziamento con la foto del tuo muro preferito. + Sticker. http://www.altrovefestival.it/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/G-Loois-artwork-29.7x42-cm.jpg(EN)
