story:
VISION: Our Project is Your Project

Vivant Art Collection is the art gallery of the 21st century, the ultimate social enteprise. From its inception—Vivant has bought art from developing countries and bringing it to U.S. markets, as effort for economic develpoment and awareness in these underrepresented countires. Vivant has never been dictated by what is selling in the art world but focused on presenting cultural diverse art. It was our mission is to make art accessible and affordable for the public in US by exhibiting art that tells historic stories, celebrates cultural, and foster dialogues, which we all have done successful.

Now as a growing gallery, it is our goal and vision to offer free monthly community art programs, which includes paint days, film nights, diverse art exhibits and entrepreneurial workshops. Vivant sees itself as part of a larger movement to be the change it wants to see. 

SEASON OF THE ARTS PROGRAMS:
Events occur monthly spanning from May 2013 - end of August 2013

Community & Social Programs

  • Film night screen artistic film for month
  • Paint Night for children and adult
  • Panel Discussions
  • Artist career development workshop series

Summer Art Exhibition

  • Art Enology Philadelphia Curated by Souleo, May 2013
  • Title by international renowned artist Danny Simmons*, June 2013 *postponed
  • Chad Cortez Everett, July 2013
  •  TBA, August 2013

First Friday Weekends

  • First Friday Art Gallery Crawl
  • Drop-in Saturdays - Educational Programs & Panel discussion
  • Buy, Browse and Brunch Sundays

HOW WE'LL DO IT: Why Crowdfund this Effort

The programs offered will be free to the public. For this effort to be sustainable it will need broad support from individuals like you. As a for-profit entity, we are ineligible for many grants even though our work is free and for the community, your donation to this campaign will help continue Vivant’s community education and empowerment work.

Financial Breakdown

  • $2500 for each month for total of 4 months will help cover:
    • Shipping and delivering art
    • Marketing and advertising
    • Reception (wine and cheese)
    • Honorariums (panelist, speakers, facilitators, and musicians) 
    • General overhead costs

Social & Community Impact

  • Vivant is a cultural hub (last remaining minority-owned gallery in Olde City, Philadelphia)
  • Hosted over 60 cultural art exhibitions and 250 receptions in its 5-year run.
  • Creative director & founder, Florcy Morisset is a Cultural Arts Ambassador for the City of Philadelphia - Philly 360

OTHER WAYS TO HELP:

If you can not financial help at this time... it is ok. Please share this campaign with your friends via email or facebook. Most importantly, we invite you to attend one of the events... it is not an art viewing paint party or reception without the art lovers!

ABOUT THE CREATIVE DIRECTOR:

Florcy Morisset, founder and creative director of VIVANT, is a business leader, advocate, and community organizer, working at the intersection of culture and business. She builds bridges between the art world and the community by using her space as a hub for artists, art lovers, professionals and the community.

Active in the civic and cultural sphere, Florcy serves on several boards and holding leadership positions, within organizations such as of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Haitian Professionals of Philadelphia, the African American Museum in Philadelphia, the National Coalition of 100 Black Women Pennsylvania Chapter, and the Richard Allen Museum at the Mother Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church.

Florcy has been recognized and honored by several media outlets, politicians and community leaders for her work in the arts, business sector, and on the behalf of Haiti. Florcy is a Haitian-American, raised in New York currently residing on Philadelphia.

story:
History and Mission of the Morean Arts Center

With our roots dating back to 1917 as the Art Club of S. Petersburg, the Morean Arts Center focuses on our mission to connect people with art through innovative, community-oriented art and art education and to contribute to the economic development of the region.  Our classes and outreach programs are designed to bring out the artist in all of us. We offer adult programs, kids programs, family programs, early childhood programs, and summer camp programs, attracting beginners and advanced students alike.

We offer more than 350 different classes in 15 different mediums.  We have over 1,700 individuals who have attended our educational programs, and more than 900 campers participate in our summer art camp program.  We have provided over $25,000 in educational assistance through scholarships to qualified individuals.

Campers will enjoy a week of art-filled experiences using selected weekly themes, including stories, songs, and games in the self-contained Bank of America Children’s Learning Center. Children will explore various art mediums, such as watercolor, oil pastels, tempera paints, collage, and sculpture in both guided and self-guided experiences.

Campers will travel through a wide range of media, rotating between two different classrooms and two different teaching artists. Children will learn art processes, explore basic art concepts and skills, and learn the proper care for art tools and materials. Our summer camp art teachers use selected weekly themes to create hands-on art experiences that focus on the learning process as well as the final works of art. While final works of art will head home on Fridays, each group will complete a collaborative piece of art that will be displayed in our summer camp exhibition in the Risser Gallery.

 

Sessions include a diverse array of transformational art experiences. Coming up in summer 2014:

Charmed Life

Learn the basics to start stamping on metal and make beautiful jewelry for yourself and friends. This class covers the necessary tools and materials needed for this fun and easy to do at home technique. In addition, you’ll learn how to make a pendant by stamping on a metal blank, punching a hole, and oxidizing and polishing the metal.

Paper Mache

Paper mache is an artistic medium made from a combination of paper and paste or glue. When many people think of paper mache, they probably think of small-scale projects such as dolls, puppets, masks and figurines. However, paper mache is also useful for large-scale projects such as gallery-worthy sculptures.

World Rhythms...Art & Movement

This class is an integrated art & dance experience. Students will explore the relationship between the sound, visual art and creative movement. Music & art connects us to the earth, to each other and to our very souls. By making their own percussive instruments and painting and dancing to music students will blend the energies of both art and music. Students will be exposed to world dance, hip hop and make at least 3 percussive instruments, including a rain stick.

Steampunk Art Jewelry

Mixing modern ideas and technology with those from the past, Steampunk will influence the jewelry the students create. Students will be exposed to the basics of jewelry fabrication; including using a torch to solder as well as learning how to connect metal cold. Chain-making and chainmail will be an integrated into their final projects.

Altered Books

An altered book is a form of mixed media artwork that changes a book from its original form into a different form, altering its appearance and/or meaning.

Make Art Not Trash

With recycling becoming so important to the survival of our planet this course will help children learn about their impact on the environment as well as create fun works of art from the trash they collect. Students will make all sorts of things for themselves as well as their home. There is no end to the imaginative and whimsical possibilities.

Graffiti: Tag it Your Way!

Design your own clothes, shoes, canvas and belongings with graffiti art.

Glassblowing

Campers will learn basic vocabulary, scientific principles, hot shop safety, and will either sculpt a solid form or blow an air-filled glass ornament.

Fused Glass

Campers will learn the art of fused glass and create one-of-a-kind pieces.

Lampworking

Campers will create round beads, stringers and lots more!

Playing with Fire

Texturing metals makes metal projects come to life! During this week projects will include a simple tile bracelet. Students will also learn how to cut metal, make jump rings and a toggle clasp, use a torch, hammer and file. They will learn three-dimensional forming techniques; folding, shaping and texturing metal to create unique jewelry. Students will be exposed to basic soldering technique with use of a torch.

Wearable Art Jewelry...Making a miniature frame pendant and much more

Using your favorite images, embellishments and words, you will create a metal framed pendant. You will learn to rivet, stamp, saw, texture metal and combine these skills to make a uniquely beautiful personalized pendant. Students will be exposed to basic soldering technique with use of a torch.

In a Land Far, Far Away

You will have FUN while creating a miniature land of your own invention.

Lions and Tigers and Bears

Create the beasts of your imagination. Oh my!

Portraits in Clay

Create your Mom or Dad or maybe even yourself.

Lizards Need a Home!

This week make art for your garden and a wonderful home for the lizards.

Wonderful Whimsical Figures

Figures can be inspired by history or a product of your imagination.

Mask Making

Create a silly mask of yourself or maybe your best friend.

 

 

Outer Space

Night skies from your imagination.

Happy Birthday America

Create a patriotic flag & holiday finger puppets!

Clay Portraits

Create people showing lots and lots of emotion (not cartoon characters).

Buildings

From barns and silos to lizard houses.

Sounds Fishy

Just think of all the great things that live in the Sea.

Caterpillars and Other Insects

Make super cool creations for your garden.

Coffee or Tea Cups

Cups Galore!

School’s Out…Get Creative!

Build a sculpture showing your favorite moment of summer.

Art Focus

Art Focus time is teacher guided. Campers will focus on the theme of the week, making connections to the elements of art through process-based art activities that build throughout the week.

Hot Shop Demo

Each Friday, all 5 & 6 year old campers will have the opportunity to view a glassblowing demonstration in our very own Hot Shop.

Superheroes

Who’s your hero? This week our artists in training will visit their imaginary and real life heroes.

Yellow Submarine

Hop into our Yellow Submarine and submerge yourself as we explore the depths of the sea.

World Passport

Grab your passports and travel with us as we celebrate the unique cultures of the world, both past and present, with art projects inspired by the people and places on this big blue marble.

Dear America

America! A land where eagles soar! Since history began, its people have celebrated the magnificence of this land. This week we celebrate America; a land of many people. A country that continues to grow. A nation of courage and independence. America, the beautiful!

One’s Trash…Another’s Treasure

Discover the creative potential of recyclables. Let’s make something beautiful out of trash!

Across the Universe

Space, the final frontier. These are the voyages of the Starship Morean. Let’s boldly go where no one has gone before!

It’s a Bug’s Life

Get ready to “bug out” as we examine what’s crawling, flying, wiggling in your backyard.

Once Upon a Time

It’s a magical world this week as we create new artwork for old classics such as the Snow Queen and Jack and the Beanstalk.

Planes, Trains and Automobiles

Zoom Zoom! Vroom Vroom! Toot Toot! All aboard! Gear up for this exciting week of all “things that go!”

All Creatures Great and Small

It’s a zoo at the Morean! If you love wildlife, you will love this wild week of animal fun.

 

 

The Glass Lab

All 7-10 year old campers will have the opportunity to work with a glass artist during their week at camp. Campers will learn the art of fused glass and create a one-of-a-kind piece to take home at the end of each week.

The Pollyzoom Experience

Each Friday, all 7-10 year old campers will be lead in a special, unique art experience called Pollyzoom. Pollyzoom is a creative experience comprised of artists, musicians, choreographers and designers who work together to create live art through fashion, international art projects, live art events, sound, visual and performing arts.

How you can help:

The Morean Arts Center Summer Camp attracts aspiring youths from all walks of life! Your contribution will go directly towards scholarships.  It only takes your support to change the way a child sees the world!

 You can also help us by sharing this campaign on social media and with your family and friends.

Thank you for your support!
story_txt:
History
and Mission of the Morean Arts Center

With our
roots dating back to 1917 as the Art Club of S. Petersburg, the Morean Arts
Center focuses on our mission to connect people with art through innovative, community-oriented
art and art education and to contribute to the economic development of the
region.  Our classes and outreach programs are designed to bring out the
artist in all of us. We offer adult programs, kids programs, family programs,
early childhood programs, and summer camp programs, attracting beginners and
advanced students alike.
We offer more than 350 different classes in 15 different mediums.  We have over 1,700 individuals who have attended
our educational programs, and more than 900 campers participate in our summer art
camp program.  We have provided over $25,000
in educational assistance through scholarships to qualified individuals.Campers will enjoy a week
of art-filled experiences using selected weekly themes, including stories,
songs, and games in the self-contained Bank of America Children’s Learning
Center. Children will explore various art mediums, such as watercolor, oil
pastels, tempera paints, collage, and sculpture in both guided and self-guided
experiences.

Campers will travel
through a wide range of media, rotating between two different classrooms and
two different teaching artists. Children will learn art processes, explore
basic art concepts and skills, and learn the proper care for art tools and
materials. Our summer camp art teachers use selected weekly themes to create
hands-on art experiences that focus on the learning process as well as the
final works of art. While final works of art will head home on Fridays, each
group will complete a collaborative piece of art that will be displayed in our
summer camp exhibition in the Risser Gallery. Sessions include a diverse array of transformational art experiences. Coming up in summer 2014:Charmed
Life
Learn the basics
to start stamping on metal and make beautiful jewelry for yourself and friends.
This class covers the necessary tools and materials needed for this fun and
easy to do at home technique. In addition, you’ll learn how to make a pendant
by stamping on a metal blank, punching a hole, and oxidizing and polishing the metal.
Paper
Mache
Paper
mache is an artistic medium made from a combination of paper and paste or glue.
When many people think of paper mache, they probably think of small-scale
projects such as dolls, puppets, masks and figurines. However, paper mache is
also useful for large-scale projects such as gallery-worthy sculptures.

World
Rhythms...Art & Movement
This class is an integrated art
& dance experience. Students will explore the relationship between the
sound, visual art and creative movement. Music & art connects us to the
earth, to each other and to our very souls. By making their own percussive
instruments and painting and dancing to music students will blend the energies
of both art and music. Students will be exposed to world dance, hip hop and
make at least 3 percussive instruments, including a rain stick.

Steampunk Art Jewelry
Mixing modern ideas and technology
with those from the past, Steampunk will influence the jewelry the students
create. Students will be exposed to the basics of jewelry fabrication;
including using a torch to solder as well as learning how to connect metal
cold. Chain-making and chainmail will be an integrated into their final
projects.
Altered Books
An altered book is a form of mixed
media artwork that changes a book from its original form into a different form,
altering its appearance and/or meaning.
Make Art Not Trash
With recycling becoming so
important to the survival of our planet this course will help children learn
about their impact on the environment as well as create fun works of art from
the trash they collect. Students will make all sorts of things for themselves
as well as their home. There is no end to the imaginative and whimsical
possibilities.
Graffiti: Tag it Your Way!
Design your own clothes, shoes,
canvas and belongings with graffiti art.Glassblowing
Campers will learn basic
vocabulary, scientific principles, hot shop safety, and will either sculpt a
solid form or blow an air-filled glass ornament.
Fused Glass
Campers will learn the art of fused
glass and create one-of-a-kind pieces.
Lampworking
Campers will create round beads,
stringers and lots more!
Playing with Fire
Texturing metals makes metal
projects come to life! During this week projects will include a simple tile
bracelet. Students will also learn how to cut metal, make jump rings and a
toggle clasp, use a torch, hammer and file. They will learn three-dimensional
forming techniques; folding, shaping and texturing metal to create unique
jewelry. Students will be exposed to basic soldering technique with use of a
torch.
Wearable Art Jewelry...Making a
miniature frame pendant and much more
Using your favorite images,
embellishments and words, you will create a metal framed pendant. You will
learn to rivet, stamp, saw, texture metal and combine these skills to make a
uniquely beautiful personalized pendant. Students will be exposed to basic
soldering technique with use of a torch.
In a Land Far, Far Away
You will have FUN while creating a
miniature land of your own invention.
Lions and Tigers and Bears
Create the beasts of your
imagination. Oh my! 
Portraits in Clay
Create your Mom or Dad or maybe
even yourself. 
Lizards Need a Home!
This week make art for your garden
and a wonderful home for the lizards.
Wonderful Whimsical Figures
Figures can be inspired by history
or a product of your imagination.
Mask Making
Create a silly mask of yourself or
maybe your best friend.  Outer Space
Night skies from your imagination.
Happy Birthday America
Create a patriotic flag &
holiday finger puppets!
Clay Portraits
Create people showing lots and lots
of emotion (not cartoon characters).
Buildings
From barns and silos to lizard
houses.
Sounds Fishy
Just think of all the great things
that live in the Sea.
Caterpillars and Other Insects
Make super cool creations for your
garden.
Coffee or Tea Cups
Cups Galore!
School’s Out…Get Creative!
Build a sculpture showing your
favorite moment of summer.Art Focus
Art Focus time is teacher guided.
Campers will focus on the theme of the week, making connections to the elements
of art through process-based art activities that build throughout the week. 
Hot Shop Demo
Each Friday, all 5 & 6 year old
campers will have the opportunity to view a glassblowing demonstration in our
very own Hot Shop.
Superheroes
Who’s your hero? This week our
artists in training will visit their imaginary and real life heroes.
Yellow Submarine
Hop into our Yellow Submarine and
submerge yourself as we explore the depths of the sea.
World Passport
Grab your passports and travel with
us as we celebrate the unique cultures of the world, both past and present,
with art projects inspired by the people and places on this big blue marble.
Dear America
America! A land where eagles soar!
Since history began, its people have celebrated the magnificence of this land.
This week we celebrate America; a land of many people. A country that continues
to grow. A nation of courage and independence. America, the beautiful! 
One’s Trash…Another’s Treasure
Discover the creative potential of
recyclables. Let’s make something beautiful out of trash!
Across the Universe
Space, the final frontier. These
are the voyages of the Starship Morean. Let’s boldly go where no one has gone
before!
It’s a Bug’s Life
Get ready to “bug out” as we
examine what’s crawling, flying, wiggling in your backyard.
Once Upon a Time
It’s a magical world this week as
we create new artwork for old classics such as the Snow Queen and Jack and the
Beanstalk.
Planes, Trains and Automobiles
Zoom Zoom! Vroom Vroom! Toot Toot!
All aboard! Gear up for this exciting week of all “things that go!”
All Creatures Great and Small
It’s a zoo at the Morean! If you
love wildlife, you will love this wild week of animal fun.
  The Glass Lab

All 7-10 year old campers will have
the opportunity to work with a glass artist during their week at camp. Campers
will learn the art of fused glass and create a one-of-a-kind piece to take home
at the end of each week.
The Pollyzoom Experience
Each Friday, all 7-10 year old
campers will be lead in a special, unique art experience called Pollyzoom.
Pollyzoom is a creative experience comprised of artists, musicians,
choreographers and designers who work together to create live art through
fashion, international art projects, live art events, sound, visual and
performing arts. 
How you can help: 
The Morean Arts Center Summer Camp attracts aspiring youths from all walks
of life! Your contribution will go directly towards scholarships.  It only takes your support to change the way
a child sees the world!
 You can also help us by sharing this campaign on social media and with
your family and friends. 
Thank you for your support!

story:
In 2012, the Whysman Festival celebrated the life and work of one of Scotland’s most exciting and influential artists, George Wyllie.  

The festival attracted and inspired thousands of people of all ages and from all walks of life — it really did prove that ‘art is for everyone’.

In Inverclyde, an artist, former shipyard workers and community groups worked together to create large sculptures inspired by Wyllie’s trade-mark ‘Question Mark’. These sculptures are installed along the banks of the Clyde creating a seascape of question marks appearing and disappearing on the tidal flow. 

Here is a little film about making the sculptures...


Visible from major transport routes running from Greenock to Glasgow, these artworks have attracted a lot of positive public attention as they prompt passers-by to pose the question “what are question marks for?”.

Now, two years on, the ‘Question Marks’ are still there but need restoration. 




Funds raised from this campaign will help replace and repair the sculptures before the opening of the forthcoming exhibition of works by George Wyllie “Why is there a ? in Scul?ture” at The Beacon, Greenock.

You can help us restore these artworks so they continue to intrigue and inspire all who see them.

Donate now!

Please tell your friends about this campaign by sharing on social media.

Exhibition: 

Why is there a ? in Scul?ture? – works by George Wyllie

Saturday 28th June – Wednesday 16th July 2014

The Beacon, Custom Quay, Greenock
This exhibition will focus on enduring themes found in Wyllie’s art and will consider why a ? should be at the centre of everything.This exhibition is presented by the George Wyllie Foundation. 

www.georgewyllie.com

story:
Manifesto-ish.com:

Artists are confronted with the need to keep a website.  It expands our reach to new audiences and allows us to communicate with our fans.  But what else can the internet do for artists?  What can be created from it?  If the internet was a medium, what would the brushes, chisels, paints, chalks, etc. be?  This is the mission of a new type of artist website, by artists, for artists.  Manifesto-ish.com is:

  • Part virtual gallery where scale and physical location have no meaning.
  • Part Online Artist in Residence program, where artists gain access to space, publicity, collaboration tolls and feedback on projects that explore the capacity of the internet as an art making medium.
  • Part artist network where artists can connect to share ideas, give feedback and collaborate.

Manifesto-ish is dedicated to the idea that art can push boundaries while still being accessible; collaborative while also personal.

What we need your support for:

This campaign will fund the following needs:

  • Advertising for our live, real-time openings of exhibitions in our virtual gallery.
  • Fees for online services like our virtual gallery from 3dVAS.com.
  • Funds to offer support to our online artists' in residence.
  • Your support can earn you membership in the site with special opportunities to participate in events and projects, special recognition on our site, and fun products made by Manifesto-ish's own member artists.

What your support means:

Manifesto-ish is a new venture by a group of artists who are used to making much out of little.  There are many tools available on the internet for free, but to truly be successful with our goal we can't avoid some fund raising.  Your contribution will go a long way to covering our annual expenses.

  • As the art market becomes more specialized and overpriced, we need opportunites for everyone to experience interesting and thought provoking art.
  • The four founders of Manifesto-ish have all curated real world gallery shows, built and maintained websites and collaborated with each other for years.  They know how to acheive great results on small budgets.

Can't contribute funds this time?  You can:

Go to www.manifesto-ish.com and click join to become a part of our network.  You can like our page on facebook and share with your friends.

Thank you so much for your time an interest, and here's to an interesting time!

story:
Short Summary

Hello everyone, my name is Cliff and I am an artist with a focus on digital painting though I also  work in acrylic, graphite, charcoal, marker and colored pencil. 


You might know me from Google Plus where I have become known for my Speedpaint Hangouts in which I paint people digitally in G+ video calls while they watch. Perhaps you know me thorugh YouTube where I post videos of me creating artwork Perhaps we know each other through FB or MySpace or various other forums. Maybe you know me in person or maybe you don't know me at all.  If the latter, I hope you introduce yourself to me on G+, FB or Twitter (links below), or just on the street if you happen to see me. 

Earlier in the year we ran into some major car trouble and had to replace our car. Since then things have snowballed and our finances got way out of whack. They are just about inline now with one exception......rent. 

I am asking for $5000 which will go towards paying the back rent we owe in addition to December's and keep us from being evicted. Any additional money will be used to pay off other bills (we are on a payment plan for the electric bill etc) and start building a financial cushion.  I have plans in place to stabilize our budget but that requires first returning to a base state. 

In return for helping out you get some great artwork. In most cases original artwork created just for you. 

I realize not everyone is in much better position than I am. You can still help out by sharing and spreading the word!

story:
Short Summary

Tim Duax and Frank Gess would like to continue to produce a photography book which shows the negative impact of thoughtlessly placed utility lines and poles.  Two examples - In Ohio recent efforts brought before the Ohio Supreme Court sought to relocate proposed power lines away from unspoiled farm fields in an established Amish farming community.  In Wisconsin a third of a billion dollars is currently proposed to create three new high tension lines running through forest and glacial landscape.

What We Need

Funding will simply continue to support our photography efforts to produce a montage of natural and architectural beauty diminished by poorly placed utility lines and poles.  Gas money, sub sandwiches, coffee, cheese curds, etc... did I mention gas money?  We donate our time and equipment.

Please see our video as example: http://youtu.be/Z5CsKaXiDzo

The Impact

Every little bit helps.  We are not "against" electrical power, rather we see greater utilization of green power and local production of power as increasingly feasible options.

Other Ways You Can Help

Across this country are local groups that recognize how utility lines impact the quality of life of those near them.  Obviously, it is a matter of self-education and connecting with local groups.

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
UPDATE! New Campaign Goal!


Hello everyone! Just a quick update:

If I am able to reach at least $1500 in contributions for the campaign, I will GUARANTEE a $500 donation to United Way of Greater St. Louis and world missions. That way, even if I don't reach my goal, I will still give and support the things that matter more than a few art supplies and a nice printer.

Let's do it!


The Vision

Hello, my name is Anthony L. Fowler Jr., and I love comics.

I am an aspiring comic book inker based in the St. Louis, MO area. An inker has a job unique to American comics; an inker lays down the black lines over penciled comic art, adding depth and weight to the page, as well as making coloring easier. I have been drawing since I was about 13, and I have come to respect the artistry and challenge that comic book inking supplies. It is my desire to become a professional comic book inker, and I'm driven to make that happen. I currently work on several small inking projects, do character commissions, share inked samples over other artists' pencils via Facebook and DeviantArt, and I have also published stories with St. Louis-based comics collective Ink & Drink Comics. Here's a sample page I inked over Robert Atkins:

More examples of my work can be found at my DeviantArt page and my Facebook page.

I have found that to get work in this industry, it is necessary to visit comic conventions and show your portfolio to editors and artists who may want to work with you. I've been to one particular convention twice before, and got some positive feedback. I was figuring out plans to hit four conventions this year, showing my inking portfolio to editors present and selling prints, commissions, and other knick-knacks from my own table. I was excited for next year. Whooo!

Then...then the math happened.

The Challenge

Adding up costs for table rent for each show, travel expenses, art materials, printing, etc.; things added up quickly. Throw in the fact that I need to purchase a large format printer (for printing and scanning 11 x 17" comic pages), new art materials, a replacement for my rickety old drawing desk, and fees for establishing my LLC (to afford me certain protections and benefits when doing freelance art contracts), and next year's plans all of a sudden seem impossible. 

This is where I need you. 

To accomplish all of my goals next year, just $40 from 100 people would complete my funding request. Your contributions will assist me in becoming a professional inker and living my dream!

In addition, I am committed to donating all additional funds to United Way of Greater St. Louis and missions around the world if contributions exceed the initial goal. Find out more about United Way and the charities they support here:

http://www.stl.unitedway.org

Your contribution will be applied to many areas, including but not limited to:

  • Fees for establishing an LLC (InkWise Studios, LLC) in the state of Missouri,
  • Artist Alley table fees for Wizard World St. Louis, Wizard World Nashville, Planet Comic Con (Kansas City, MO), and Project: Comic Con (St. Louis, MO)*,
  • Travel expenses (hotel, food, etc.) 
  • Promotional materials, such as a banner, flyers, and business cards 
  • Art materials, such as inks (of course), brushes, nibs, bristol board, and others as needed,
  • Necessary accessories, such as a large format all-in-one printer and a new art desk
  • Miscellaneous costs, such as printing costs, gifts for contributors, taxes, fees, and shipping and handling costs. 
*-Based on current Artists' Alley table rates for these shows. Subject to change before each respective show per their discretion. 

The Perks!

In return for your contributions, I am offering prints, gift cards, and original art commissions. You can find examples of commissions and a preview of the prints on this campaigns' gallery page. If you're unsure of how commissions work, click here.

Also, based on a good suggestion from a buddy of mine, I'm offering a printed paperback compilation of all of the commissions I will do, exclusively for contributors of this campaign. If you request a commission, your commission will be in the book. If you request the book as well, you get to see everyone else's commissions, including yours! Isn't that cool? 

The Expectations

As far as delivery of perks, certain things can be sent out quickly. Once funds are received, the prints, both digital and physical, will be the first things sent out. Commissions will obviously take up most of the time, and the commission book will be the last thing to be ready to go. Just for organization's sake, I want to make an effort to ensure that you get all of your promised perks all at once (i.e., if you contribute $100, you get your commissions, the commission book, the prints, and the gift card all at once). I'm estimating about four months max for 100% fulfillment, but if anything changes, I'll update you guys as soon as I possibly can.

Also, if you're planning on being at one of the shows I plan on being at, you may elect to pick up your perks there. Just shoot me an email, and I'll move your stuff to the front of the line (if it isn't done already), and have it ready for you at the show. 

For your email-related perks (which pretty much includes most of the perks), if the site don't have a space to put your email address when you contribute, email me at afowlerart@gmail.com and I'll get you set up. 

The Impact

Every dollar makes a difference. It shows that you care about comic arts enough to help a kid from the Midwest with a dream. If I go over my funding goal, we can also fight homelessness and socioeconomic disparity. Awesome!

I am more than happy to answer any questions you have. Please email questions, comments, or otherwise to afowlerart@gmail.com. I can also be found on Facebook at facebook.com/afowlerart.

The Conclusion

Thank you for stopping by this page. Even if you're unable to contribute, I appreciate your thought. Please share this page to your social network flavor of choice (Facebook, Twitter, etc.) And don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Much appreciated.

Miscellaneous costs, such as printing costs, gifts for contributors, taxes, fees, and shipping and handling costs. 
*-Based on current Artists' Alley table rates for these shows. Subject to change before each respective show per their discretion. The Perks!In return for your contributions, I am offering prints, gift cards, and original art commissions. You can find examples of commissions and a preview of the prints on this campaigns' gallery page. If you're unsure of how commissions work, click here. Also, based on a good suggestion from a buddy of mine, I'm offering a printed paperback compilation of all of the commissions I will do, exclusively for contributors of this campaign. If you request a commission, your commission will be in the book. If you request the book as well, you get to see everyone else's commissions, including yours! Isn't that cool? The ExpectationsAs far as delivery of perks, certain things can be sent out quickly. Once funds are received, the prints, both digital and physical, will be the first things sent out. Commissions will obviously take up most of the time, and the commission book will be the last thing to be ready to go. Just for organization's sake, I want to make an effort to ensure that you get all of your promised perks all at once (i.e., if you contribute $100, you get your commissions, the commission book, the prints, and the gift card all at once). I'm estimating about four months max for 100% fulfillment, but if anything changes, I'll update you guys as soon as I possibly can.Also, if you're planning on being at one of the shows I plan on being at, you may elect to pick up your perks there. Just shoot me an email, and I'll move your stuff to the front of the line (if it isn't done already), and have it ready for you at the show. For your email-related perks (which pretty much includes most of the perks), if the site don't have a space to put your email address when you contribute, email me at afowlerart@gmail.com and I'll get you set up. The ImpactEvery dollar makes a difference. It shows that you care about comic arts enough to help a kid from the Midwest with a dream. If I go over my funding goal, we can also fight homelessness and socioeconomic disparity. Awesome!I am more than happy to answer any questions you have. Please email questions, comments, or otherwise to afowlerart@gmail.com. I can also be found on Facebook at facebook.com/afowlerart.The ConclusionThank you for stopping by this page. Even if you're unable to contribute, I appreciate your thought. Please share this page to your social network flavor of choice (Facebook, Twitter, etc.) And don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!Much appreciated.

story:
Writing is my livelihood. Though I buffer my income with earnings from publishing services such as copyediting and interior book formatting, the majority of my income comes from the fiction I write. Due to recent illness, and the varying hurdles I have to overcome medically to treat my mental health, my ability to promote (or even write) my work has become increasingly difficult, and as such, my income has suffered.

The Idea:

This August, I have been invited to attend as a guest author at Houston Con in Houston, Texas, from the 8th to the 10th. While promoters at the con have graciously provided me with my hotel and allocated space for my table, I am in need of promotional materials (books, bookmarks, a promotional banner, etc.) as well as funds that can help pay for food and gasoline to the event. I would also hope to stretch the funds provided from this campaign (as well as the fruits that come from attending this convention) to help me in the months to come.

    How You Can Help

    Detailed below are a number of perks that you can receive if you choose to help out. From eBooks, to signed paperbacks, to promotional benefits at the con itself, I strive to offer whatever I can with the budget I can provided.

    If You Can't Donate

    That's ok! There are still ways you can help promote my work (and even get free eBooks in the process.)

    You can find my free eBooks on Amazon and other online stores

    You can subscribe to my mailing list

    Or you can add me as a friend on any of the various social networks below

       

    In the end, everything helps, even if it's just spreading the word about the campaign or offering a word of encouragement.

story:
Hello! I’m Kirarts, a poliedric italian artist about multimedial communications. 
Some time ago, I was looking for an idea for a new product that approaches the work of illustrators to the world of web. When I stay in front of the big monitor of my iMac, surfing the Internet, I often see large unused white spaces on either side of a website. In fact, every time I create a website I always wonder : "How do I fill the white background on either side of my template?" So I created a blog and I enjoyed to drawing a background and a mascot, that you can see below:

In that moment I had the idea to create a web shop to sale illustrated backgrounds for websites: Website-Background.com.

Website-Background.com offers backgrounds grouped by theme, illustrated with traditional or digital mediums, and with original ideas to make a memorable website!

About 40 Italian artists help me to build Website-Background.com
and every week I get requests for collaborations from new artists. 
I hope they will always increase and that this project will guarantee them a satisfactory self-employment. This is also my desire and it's the reason why I’m trying to start this business!

What We Need & What You Get

The StartUp project, the first and only, needs your help to grow up!
A budget of 3000€ would give the first necessary boost for advertising through Google and Facebook. Advertising for 10€ per day distribuited between Google and Facebook → about 300 € per month.

A minimum budget of € 3,000* would cover about 9 months.

Even if the budget is not reached, the money would be spent on advertising anyway.
*Including Indiegogo's fees the amount would be € 2,790.

We have illustrators with different skills, so we can offer attractive services to compensate your appreciated contribution ! Take a look at the Perks!


Stretch Goals (In case of exceeding Goal)

€ 6,000
Of this budget would be invested €3,000 for other 10 months of advertising on Google and Facebook, the main Goal would be to recruit more professional artists in order to expand and improve the services offered. Website Background wants to aim at the quality of the illustrations! There would be funds to purchase more server space in order to expand with many new illustrations and pages such as Wallpapers , Mascot, Banner and Artists Area.

If this Stretch Goal is reached, the contributors have access to the following Perk :

- In the Partner page of Website- Background will be added logo, link and short description of your company.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

€ 12,000
Of this budget would be invested € 6,000 for other 20 Months of Advertising,
I could afford professionals and employees who help me in the management of this activity. The main Goal would be recruit artists from all over the world and, therefore, the other part of this budget would be invested to human resources (translators) for manage the relationships with artists/clients abroad.

If this Stretch Goal is reached, it means that the site is going great and receives a good number of views! The contributors will be so excited to access to this Perk:

- 1 Month of Free advertising of your company on the homepage of Website- Background.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Why a background?

• Provide a distinctiveness to corporate websites , blogs and forums.
• Visitors will remember easier your site, thanks to its innovation!
• It's an alternative to an expensive and sophisticated web graphics.
• Navigate through large monitors of PC and Smart TV will be more fun!

Backgrounds Features

My job for this project, as well as take care of website's implementation,
is also Art Director. This because not all illustrations are accepted.
Sometimes I collaborate with illustrators in order to present a better product. 

My aim is give an image that only an illustrator can give, I want give you ideas,
unusual characters, messages and amazement!

The backgrounds have different size but no one exceed 1900 x 1200px.

Every Background is available in 3 different widths, depends on how many pixels
your website is wide: 800px - 1000px - 1200px. 

And in each tab of product you can download 3 test images for free,
so you can see if the background it's suitable for your website!

You can try before buy!

Other ways to help!

If you are owner of a blog, website or forum and want to help, I offer you a free copy of a background of your choice in exchange for an article or a review!

I believe so much in this idea. Every kind of comment and review are welcome! 

Use the sharing tools of Indiegogo to spread the word about this campaign!

I'm italian, and maybe my English is not perfect I'm sorry!
Thank you so much!

Kirarts

story:
Greetings! Thanks for stopping by our page.

All we want for Christmas is reproductive choice! Help us raise 500GBP before the end of the year. 

Abortion Rights is the national pro-choice campaign. We defend and extend women’s rights and access to safe, legal abortion. Women should be able to make their own reproductive decisions without the current unfair legal barriers, obstructions and delays.

It's been a very busy year……We’ve been working hard campaigning, lobbying & influencing but there still is much to do.

We need your help to continue our important work. We run our efforts through the generous support of our volunteer base and membership. It’s becoming harder for us to defend and extend choice on our dwindling resources.

How you can help? Pledge us some dosh or become an Abortion Rights member today! We are asking as many people as possible to chip into our fighting fund to defend and extend choice -- and really, every little bit helps.  

                                             Happy Pro-Choice Holidays




Talk to us, find us, Follow Us!

· You can always become a member to support our work to defend and extend choice

· Follow us @Abortion_Rights and on Facebook

· Contact us at choice@abortionrights.org.uk or 020 7923 9792

           


Credits                                                                                                                    

Video & Design: Our Design Works                                                                                 

Music: Bensoud

Photos: Alyssa Erspamer  &  Jade Jackman                                                                  

Misc Design: JoHarrison  &  Mulberry Design

story:
Our Story

Last fall, we had an amazing day of celebration centered around the Occupy Movement. The event took place at Pritchard Park and was inspirational to those already involved while encouraging others to become more involved.  We had amplified sound and many musicians and speakers had a chance to have their voices heard.  We had an extremely smooth General Assembly which introduced those unfamiliar with GAs to an often times difficult, yet truly democratic, process.  We had food; we had soap box; we had information booths.  We had celebration! It was a chance for all of us to feel inspired and reenergize for the long road ahead.

We are looking forward to another similar event on Saturday, April 14-- "tax day" falls on the 17th this year.  We aim to make this next event even bigger and broader.  We are encouraging all artists, musicians, and theatrical persons to come out and share the beauty that comprises Occupy Asheville. 

What We Need 

The costs for having amplified sound is $200 for 6 hours.  We are asking for $500 because that is the minimum we can ask for on this site.  Any extra money will be deposited directly into the the Occupy Asheville account.  Thank you for your donations!

story:
Our Story

The Viscera Organization is a non profit organization that aims to assist female filmmakers and artists get their work exposed and celebrated and is trying to shed a little light on the challenges women face in the industry. I will be directing two commercials for the organization to help get the word out about the film festival and the organization as a whole and I hope you'll help me too. 

I will be directing the ads and will be working with some great talent including the Viscera ladies themselves, Heidi Martinuzzi, Shannon Lark and Stacy Pippi Hammon to take the amazing artwork of Irene Langholm and bring it to life.  The video ads will make it quicker and easier for people to spread using social network marketing and the like.

The Impact

While the word about Viscera is spreading fast and the organization has already helped so many talented women, it's time to really get the word out there to the masses through one of the most popular mediums today, video.  The creation of the ads will expand the knowledge and awareness of the organization and it's filmmakers and contributors (artists, indie artists, etc.).  Every person involved with Viscera deserves the exposure and that is my goal. 


What We Need & What You Get

While the majority of those involved with the project are donating their time, there are certain things we do need hard cash for such as equipment, special fx, the green screen and more.  Because of that I'm looking for a very nominal amount to make sure that this is done right.  We only have a few days left since we've all put in what we can so I'm asking for your help now.  

Each person that donates at least $20 will receive a tangible thank you card signed by everyone that participated in the shoot/production.  Those who donate $100 or more will receive a personalized thank you video from us ladies working on it. $1000 or more gets you a DVD with the finalized videos and your personalized thank you video in addition to all of the above. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word about this fundraising campaign and please spread the word for

story:
Hello Friends and Family and people I probably don't know yet! 

This is Kira here. I'm a 28 year old artist from New York City who'll be moving by myself to New Orleans in exactly two weeks. I'm coming to you today on the interwebs to tell you why I'm moving there, what's happened to me lately, and how you could maybe help. 

In May of 2011 I took an epic road trip with my dear friend Liz, and we spent 2 days in New Orleans. I've never been anywhere like it. There is music in the streets everywhere you go. The air smells like the most delicious of food. The people are so unbelieveably welcoming and enthusiastic about where they live, it's shocking compared to what I feel in New York City. Most importantly (for me anyways) is the art. There is art EVERYWHERE. Jackson Square is a park in the middle of the French Quarter where people go just to sit and paint and create things all day and put what they've done on display so passers-by can look and hopefully purchse. Not to mention the fact the the city is litterally filled with local artist based galleries and co-ops, not to be found in nyc. Being an artist is a legitamite JOB there. People go to New Orleans to BUY art. And listen to amazing music. And eat incredible food... I wanted to be a part of it.

Needless to say, I fell in love with that place. As soon as I returned with the notion that it was really time to leave new york, I met a man, fell in love, and ended up staying in nyc. Without getting too much into that, for now let's just mention that he and I went to New Orleans for my 2nd trip this past May only a few months ago. Everything was as I remembered it only better. I felt so overwhelemingly inspired there. All of the houses are painted different colors, and that means a lot to someone who's soul uses colors to express herself. There are huge twisty trees up and down the avenues that look like they've been there for 300 years. Needless to say, I had another amazing time - and actually upon driving away from the city I wept for a good hour. My time in new york, a city of grays and browns - was over. All I wanted was to be in the city with colors. 

Shortly after returning home from our trip, the man I love kind of unravelled mentally and lost his job. I did the silly thing you do when you're in love and started supporting us both financially. Things kept getting worse and worse and then on fourth of july he snapped and somehow decided to kick me out of our house. For nothing. Which screwed me out of my $600 security deposit . Meanwhile he had wiped out my savings, and currently still owes me minimially $500. Which of course he's refusing to pay. 

This brings me to where I stand now. I have been working my butt off trying to save as much money as I can, but I really could you any and all help from all of the wonderful people in my life. And as you can read over on the "perks" part of this site, I'm not just looking for handouts. Not only will anyone who donates ALWAYS have a place to stay in new orleans (of course) if they want to come visit me ;) ... but  I will be all too grateful to show my gratitude artistically in any way I can. Paintings, sketches, doodles, tell me to draw something and I WILL. 

In conclusion, I hope you are all well and happy in your lives. I hope you continue to follow your heart and fufill your dreams. Please, if you can - help me follow and fufill mine. I want to be a successful artist, and I believe I can do that in New Orleans. I just gotta get there.

story:
Genre Bender returns March 6–7 with 10 of Seattle's most inventive artists, unleashing five totally new, category-defying performances. 

For the uninitiated, each year our editorial staff gets together with Genre Bender creative director Jennifer Zeyl to come up with five intriguing pairs. The twosomes each come from different creative spheres and backgrounds. Some of them have never met before. City Arts commissions each pair to make a new hybrid work. 

You can bear witness to their imaginative cross-pollination Friday, March 6 or Saturday, March 7 at the Cornish Playhouse at Seattle Center.  

The 2015 Artist Duos 
Conceptual artist C. Davida Ingram  & composer/performer Hanna Benn 
Rapper Raz Simone  & multimedia artist Justin Roberts
Photographer Steven Miller  & theatrical superpower Sarah Rudinoff
Vocalist okanamodé SoulChilde  & aerialist Lara Paxton
Poet Sarah Galvin  & musician/philosopher David Nixon

The alchemy is already underway with each of these special collaborations.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $7,500 to help underwrite the collaborative new works of 10 local artists. All funds support the commissioned pieces presented during Genre Bender 2015.

You'll get a unique cross section of perks and the satisfaction that you are making Seattle a better place by supporting the arts and artists.

story:
I have been accepted to a six week summer artist residency (Grin City Artist Residency)  in Grinnell, Iowa,  as a painter, from July 20th through August 29th.  

Artist residencies are very important to working artists such as myself, because the residency allows for me to paint almost exclusively, and create new bodies of work. By contributing to this campaign you will not only help me offset the costs of this endeavor, but also provide me time, and thus opportunity, for technical and creative  expression, and the ability to pursue, realize and manifest new ideas. This is the life-blood of an artist.

The total calculated cost of the residency is $3,500 US, and I am inviting each of you to contribute towards that end. I ask that you contribute either $50 US, $150 US, or $250 US towards this "art campaign". That money will offset costs related to travel, art supplies, my studio, sleeping quarters, and food. In return for your donation you will receive gratification, 2 published accounts during my residency of my experiences and observations at Grin City,  and images of some of the work I have created, once in the middle of the residency and once towards the end, which I will publish on my website blog nicholasemeryart.com.  

In addition, here are the three tiers of contributions (named Perks on this website) and what you will receive in return

At the $50 dollar US contribution level you will receive a hi-resolution digital photograph taken by a professional photographer of a painting I select from one of the pieces of original work I complete at the Grin City Residency, delivered to you electronically via e-mail. You can then have the digital image printed at a print shop.

At the $150 dollar US contribution level you will  receive a signed print of an original painting I select from one of the pieces of original work I complete at the Grin City Residency, delivered to you either in person or via air-mail.

At the $250 dollar US contribution level you will  receive a signed original painting done on canvas paper selected from one of the pieces of original work I complete at the Grin City Residency, delivered to you either in person or via air-mail. 

I began attending artist residencies in 2011, and this will be my third one in 4 years. To be forthright, an artist residency is a real challenge; the outcome is unknown, and success is not guaranteed. Artists have their own version of the risk to reward ratio, in that artistic risk does not guarantee artistic success, but without risk there does not even exist the possibility of success. Therefore,  your contribution is, in effect, and in my view, in support of this adventurous paradox - 

                   

This photograph was taken of me in my studio at a residency at Vermont Studio Center, in Johnson Vt. USA, in 2011. The painting, and several others painted at VSC, were later exhibited in my one man show at Soft Box Studios in Port of Spain,Trinidad in 2012.

Like the previous painting, this piece was painted at Vermont Studio Center in 2011 and became the centerpiece painting in my one man show at Soft Box Studios in 2012, where it was purchased by a collector.

                  

Painted at Sans Souci Residency located in the village of Sans Souci, Trinidad in 2014. This painting was part of a series of work (33 pieces) that were  later shown at my one man show at Medulla Gallery in November of 2014, where it  was purchased by a collector.

story:
Why build Marissa's Dream Car?

Last year, Marissa Shaw was a Burning Man virgin.

Marissa is an inspiring woman, living with Cerebral Palsy.  Despite her disability, she bravely attended Burning Man and had an AMAZING adventure.  She can't wait to return to the playa this August.

Burning Man is all about RADICAL SELF RELIANCE.  

In the default world (everyday life), Marissa is very independent in her motorized wheelchair.  This chair probably costs more than your car, so Marissa dare not destroy it in the harsh playa dust.

So, Marissa brought her manual chair to Burning Man (which she can not push herself).  Her personal transportation was completely at the mercy of others.   

Marissa is a gracious and appreciative soul, and never complained.  

This year, we can help Marissa.  We can give her the opportunity to be independent on the playa, and to express herself through a functional piece of art.   She would never feel comfortable asking for herself, so I am doing it for her.

LETS BUILD MARISSA'S DREAM CAR!

What's the Plan?

We have plans to create an amazing mobility vehicle from a Gas-Powered Golf Cart. 

Jason Anderholm has generously offered to donate his expertise and labor to build the car, and to transport it from the bay area to Black Rock City.

Our bare bones budget is $3000, but if you see that we have already rasied that amount PLEASE KEEP GIVING.  

Here is our plan:

$3000 TOTAL makes Marissa's Dream Car a reality - including:

- $1000 - base vehicle - used gas-powered golf cart

- $250 - adaptive hand controls

- $250 - fuel for entire event

- $150 - hydraulic captains chair

- $150 - headlights & taillights

- $400 - LED lights

- $800 - tickets to burning man for Marissa & an attendant

IF WE RAISE $4000

- we will TRICK OUT the art car decorations and add a propane "poofer" that launches balls of flame into the air

IF WE RAISE $5000

- we will also build a handicap accessible shower for the entire "Dimensions of Accessiblity" camp, and purchase kits to make other camp vehicles drivable by hand controls

IF WE RAISE $6000 or more

- we will make multiple AWESOME accessible art-cars so that other burners with disabilities can be independent on the playa.

story:
Pictured above:  Lady Pink, LADY OF THE LEAF redux, WT 2013, with children from the El Camino neighborhood. Photo by Jason Wilder for WALL\THERAPY.

UPDATE JULY6, 2015:

THANK YOU ALL FOR YOUR SUPPORT! Thanks to all of you we hit our mark, and we've already installed the first mural by Handiedan at 880 S. Clinton St.!

Because we hit our goal, we are now in "InDemand," which means we can keep accepting donations beyond our deadline! If there was a perk that you thought got away, you may still have a chance to pick it up!

See you July 17!

- Ian, Erich, and the WT crew!


++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++


What is WALL\THERAPY?

WALL\THERAPY is an art and community intervention project, using public murals as a means to transform the urban landscape, inspire, and build community.


What has WALL\THERAPY done so far?

2500 cans of spray paint and 300 gallons of paint later, over 60 of the most talented and recognized artists from the region, the nation, and the world have shared their talents to create over 100 murals throughout the city of Rochester since this “Visual Intervention” project began in 2011.

These murals have transformed walls, buildings, and neighborhoods. This transformation has sparked inspiration in individuals and communities alike.
The murals have become part of the local conversation, the local identity, and the fabric of the city. Local art classes and schools tour the murals as part of the curriculum. Local professionals change their route to the murals part of their drive home. Local artists, young and old, find inspiration in the works.

WALL\THERAPY mural project is now recognized worldwide. People from 2000+ cities in 104+ countries have visited the WALL\THERAPY site to learn more. New mural artists from around the world ask about painting Rochester, for the first time or for another time.

The project has gained steady media attention, and media coverage has included 100+ articles, blogs, and videos about the project from a variety of media outlets including NPR and Huffington Post.

Earlier in 2015, WALL\THERAPY was selected to partner with the Google Cultural Institute Street Art Project to insure that all murals would be accessible through capturing the imagery of the work and through interactive access via Google Maps.


Click to visit out Cultural Institute site, where we have all of our murals archived in high resolution: https://walltherapyny.culturalspot.org

What is happening this year?

WALL\THERAPY and URBAN NATION are excited to launch the International exchange program between Rochester and Berlin this year. Artists curated by the UN Director Yasha Young have been invited to participate and contribute to the program of WALL\THERAPY 2015 curated by Ian Wilson (founder, co-curator) and Erich Lehman (co-curator, lead organizer). WALL\THERAPY 2015 will kick off on July 17, 2015. Our theme for this year is surrealism and the fantastic.


UN Exchange artists 2015 include:
Andreas Englund
Onur and Wes21
NEVERCREW
Vexta
Li Hill
Handiedan (joining us in Late June)
SellFable City  (Participating in the IMPACT! show)

WT artists 2015 include:
Daze
Jeff Soto
Maxx242
Nate Hodge
Eder Muniz
Brittany Williams
Matthew Roberts and Joe Guy Allard

Brooklyn Street Art founders Jaime Rojo and Steve Harrington will be contributing with a very exciting special talk on Friday of WALL\THERAPY week.

To start things off right this year, we will be holding our first proper art exhibition kickoff titled IMPACT! This exhibition will take place at 1975 Gallery (89 Charlotte St.) and will showcase artwork from all the 2015 participating WALL\THERAPY artists in support of IMPACT! – IMProving Access to Care by Teleradiology – www.impactrad.org. IMPACT seeks to provide easier access to better care in underdeveloped and underserved regions through cloud-based x-ray services and a network of volunteer radiologists supporting IMPACT sites. Both WALL\THERAPY and IMPACT! are projects of The Synthesis Collaborative.
Why does WALL\THERAPY need your help?

Making all of this happen year after year takes a lot. With a core team of 13 members, our 50+ expanded team that makes this project happen are all volunteer, but the materials, equipment, and artists to make it all happen require financial support. You donations go towards the paint for many large-scale walls, renting construction lifts to safely access and paint those same large-scale walls, and the travel expenses, hospitality and a very modest honorarium for the 15 professional artists that will share their talent with the project this Summer.

WALL\THERAPY was created thanks entirely to financial and volunteer donations from its many supporters. We are asking again for assistance to continuing this forward momentum, to continue to bring unique artists to our city to help inspire and to heal.

Your continued support will allow us to support the local and international artists as they produce visually compelling murals in the Rochester cityscape, in turn improving and strengthening our thriving community. 

___________________________________________________


What your donation means directly to the cause: 

For every $15 you donate, we can provide an artist with about 3 cans of spray paint. 

For every $25 you donate the money goes for 4-5 cans of spray paint or a gallon bucket of primer 

For every $50 that means we can purchase paint brushes, rollers, buckets and cover other supply expenses. 

Donations of $150 or more helps the team supply the artist with food and water as they paint their murals.

Donations of $500 or more helps us rent a mechanical lift for the week, and our artists don’t have to stand precariously on a ladder to paint their work.

Should you donate $1000, that money goes directly to plane tickets and any sort of car rental needed for the artists

If you donate $5000, you are not just solidifying WALL\THERAPY this year and becoming a producer of this event, but you will be instrumental in helping us start focusing on the humanitarian endeavor and sister initiative known as IMPACT! 

___________________________________________________

THE PERKS

This year, we have been so fortunate to have many of our previous participants offer artwork and prints from their own private stock to help us reach out goal. We've got a few more on the way (we can only load 20 at a time), but don't delay, as we only have as few as one of some of these perks!


WALL\THERAPY "TOOLS OF THE TRADE" Market Bag - $25

Since the beginning, WALL\THERAPY has been rooted in/near Rochester’s Public Market. So we’re bringing you this sturdy tote to carry around paint supplies, fresh vegetables, or whatever else you can fit!  (Mockup shown)
(Made to order)



WALL\THERAPY "OG logo" T-shirt - $25
The classic shirt is back! Two color print (white and blue) of the WALL\THERAPY logo on premium cotton t-shirt. Will be printed to order and available after the end of the fundraiser.
(open edition)




WALL\THERAPY "TOOLS OF THE TRADE" shirt - $30
New for this year, we bring two-sided "Tools of the Trade" design on a white premium cotton tshirt with a two-sided, two-color print (black and blue) with the WALL\THERAPY logo on the front and a graphic listing of the tools of our craft on the back. Available in Men's and Women's sizes. We will follow up after the fundraiser ends to get your shirt size.
(Made to order, Mockup shown above)



WALL\THERAPY "TOOLS OF THE TRADE" letterpress print - $50

Featuring a graphic listing of the tools of our craft, the 20" x 10.5" letterpress print features silver ink on top of blue spray paint so each one is unique. Hand-sprayed by members of the WT team and letterpress printed by our friends at Pistachio Press, this signed/numbered print has a total edition of 100 on 100# Midnight Black Strathmore Premium Cambric paper, with 50 available through this fundraiser. Image size is 18.5" x 9" with a 1/2" border that enables easy matting and framing.
(Actual shown)
(50 available)


Mike Ming  "Dirty Devil in Rochester" screenprint - $100
Our 2013 muralist Mike Ming has donated this edition of 6 screen prints. Each one of these single-colored prints is unique. Signed & Numbered. 18"x24" on heavyweight watercolor paper.
(6 Available)  
(Please contact us if interested, we are currently at our max perks.)


Omen "There Was a Time" Etching - $100
Our Northern neighbor OMEN donated 10 of his etchings entitled "There Was A Time."  stamped and embossed on heavyweight stock. Signed/Numbered  by the artist,  9.5 x 4.125” 

In Omen’s own words: “Classy, Subtle, Zombies.”

(10 available)


Peeta "UnReliable" print - $200
Donated by our friends at 1xRun, this gorgeous print is by our 2014 WRITES OF SPRING muralist and longtime friend Peeta. 20 x 15 Inches Archival Pigment Print on 310gsm Bright White Fine Art Paper

(1 available)


John Perry "Flavor Flav" - $250
Original artwork by 2014 Rochester muralist John Perry! John has donated a portrait of one of his early influences, Flavor Flav. Acrylic on wood, 15.5" x 24" x 1.75" 

( 1 available, please contact us if interested.)


RANGE "Anonymous" Artwork - $300
A true Rochester Legend, RANGE FUA has donated an original artwork - acrylic and Airbrush on a NYC MTA map. Will ship folded. 23.75 x 32.25”unfolded size. Range painted with us during July 2013 and his mural can be found on the El Camino Trail.
(1 Available)


Oh Rochester! Sweet Meat Co. edition
Lea Rizzo - $325

Co-curator Erich Lehman teamed up with the other members of the Sweet Meat Co. to create a special edition of his "Oh Rochester!" project. Using float-mounted, reclaimed skateboards ridden in Rochester, these 17" birch panel pieces were given the rest of the Sweet Meat Co (all previous muralists) to customize just for this fundraiser. Each one is one of a kind. This edition features artwork by Lea Rizzo, 2013 Muralist.

(1 available)





Addison Karl: Hands artwork - $350
Original Artwork by Addison Karl entitled "Hands", 2014, Pen & Ink on white 190g/m2, 16.53 x 11.69" (A3) size matt paper. Addision's July 2014 mural can be seen gracing the Eastern side of the Fedder Industrial Complex, towering 4 stories as our largest mural to date!
(1 Available,  please contact us if interested.)


LNY Original Artwork - $400
LNY's "Bolivia 1967" - Original artwork, acrylic on double sided matte Dura-Lar film, Signed and Dated, 2015. Donated by the artist. 14" x 17"

LNY joined us in July of 2013 and left a striking mural on the corner of Avenue D and Joseph Ave, entitled "I AM, YO SOY," depicting a young boy who lives in the building, Trayvon Martin, and both young and older versions of Frederick Douglass to remind us of the potential we have inside us all.
(1 available) 


Addison Karl: King Saxony Roller artwork - $575
Original Artwork by Addison Karl entitled "Hands", 2014, Pen & Ink on white 190g/m2, 16.53 x 11.69" (A3) size matt paper. Addision's July 2014 mural can be seen gracing the Eastern side of the Fedder Industrial Complex, towering 4 stories as our largest mural to date!
(1 Available, please contact us if interested.)




Know Hope - The Letting Go - Photographic Print - $1100
2013 muralist KNOW HOPE has donated one of his photographic prints from an edition of 5, of his Rochester mural "The Letting Go," from his recent Truth and Method exhibition in Tel Aviv, Israel. It is 27.5" x 19.5" (70x50cm) and will be framed.




For companies or benefactors interested in playing a larger role in the success of WALL\THERAPY:

SPONSOR  - $1000
Donors at the SPONSOR level will  have their name/company logo added to the WALL\THERAPY website, receive a copy of each of the WALL\THERAPY, die-cut logo stickers, a WALL\THEARPY t-shirt featuring the logo, and tickets for two to join us at our wrap-up dinner in July.
(10 Available)


SPONSOR A WALL - $5000
New this year, we are offering the opportunity to support the creation of one of the murals directly. We will place a signpost at the wall stating your sponsorship, you will receive acknowledgements on our site and you will be listed as patron in the mural's forthcoming entry into our Google Cultural Institute site. You will receive a framed  11x17" photo print of the finished mural, and a small original by the artist courtesy of WALL\THERAPY. We will make sure you are adorned with a complement of WALL\THERAPY gear.
(2 available)


___________________________________________________

SOLD OUT PERKS!

These great perks have already sold out, don't miss your opportunity to get great art and gear while supporting a far-reaching community project!

Rochester Sticker Pack - $25
Each pack includes a minimum of 1 sticker from the following Rochester Graffiti writers and Street Artists curated by The Lobby (@Lobbyist): THIEVIN' STEPHEN (2012 and 2013 muralist), CHANGEROUS 63 (2013 muralist), RANGE FUA (2013 muralist), BONES FUA (2014 muralist), Spaceman, Ax, Yews HFK, Frank Bacon, Shootyerface, Downer, Nova FUA, FUA Krew, and others!  

Plus free admission to this year's FLOOR/THERAPY- the third annual dance party for the visiting W/T artists on Thursday July 23.

(10 packs available, sold out)



WALL\THERAPY Brass bracelet - $40
A custom made, solid brass bracelet with WALL THERAPY and ROC punched into each side to show your Rochester pride. Custom made by Rochester's own Interstellar Love Craft at her home base in The Yards, our own home base during WALL\THERAPY week. 
( 10 available)


Icy & Sot FLOWER POWER tshirt - $35
We have teamed up with Icy and Sot to produce an open edition of dark gray t-shirts featuring the FLOWER POWER artwork they painted at 50 Anderson Ave during October of 2013.  The artwork will be on the front with a WALL\THERAPY logo on the back of the neck. Sizes from Women's Small to Men's XXXL. These will only be available to order through this year's fundraiser. We will follow up after the fundraiser ends to get your shirt size.(Made to order, only available through this fundraiser)



Icy & Sot FLOWER POWER Hoodie - $50
We have teamed up with artist brother duo Icy and Sot to produce a limited run of 30 black hooded pullover Sweatshirts featuring the FLOWER POWER artwork they painted at 50 Anderson Ave during October of 2013 on the back and a WALL\THERAPY logo on the front left chest. 

Sizes from Women's Small to Men's XXL are available on a first come, first serve basis to the first 30 supporters and will be printed according to your size. We will follow up after the fundraiser ends to get your sweatshirt size.
(Only 30 available through this fundraiser)


Faring Purth Print - $75
Frequent muralist Faring Purth, who has brought two murals, Etty and Anabel, to Rochester, has donated  "Ella II," one of her Eleanora series of prints. Hand-pulled by the artist here in Rochester, 2013,  Screenprint, Black ink on white paper, 14x20in.  These prints were her first print edition, and has a special tie to Rochester!(1 Available, unframed, rocks and artist's feet not included)

Cern - "Fooshy and Friends" mono print  $75
Monotype AP edition of 1 from 2012, signed but not numbered print by Cern, donated by friend of WALL\THERAPY Dan "HALOPIGG" Wientraub 

(1 available)


Above FUNNY FARM print - $100
ABOVE joined us in August 2014 to adorn a wall with his DIAMONDS mural just on the edge of the Rochester Public Market off Railroad St.  5 of these prints were donated by the artist himself from his sold out 1xRun edition.  Giclee on 310gsm Fine Art Paper, Signed & Numbered. (Shown framed, but comes unframed)
(5 Available)



Sam Rodriguez "Hybrid Vision" Print - $125
"Hybrid Vision" Print - Donated by ourJuly 2014 artist Sam Rodriguez, this print comes from a limited edition of 25 fine art giclee prints on 100% archival velvet fine art paper. Includes embossed Certificate of Authenticity. It is the first in his series of "TYPE FACES" prints.
(2 Available, both sold out)


Shawnee Hill Artwork - $150
Donated by one of our Rochester Locals from WT July 2014,  ‘White out #3” is an original work by Shawnee Hill - 11.25"x15'' gouache wash and white ink on paper and comes in simple black frame (frame not pictured)
(1 Available, sold out)


35 years of Shoe print - $175
Our 2014 WRITES OF SPRING muralist Niels "Shoe" Meulman has donated one of his "35 Years of Shoe" prints to the cause! From late 2014, silver and black silkscreen print, signed and numbered by the artist. Just over 19"  x 27", it is being personalized by Shoe just for the campaign.
(1 Available, sold out)



Alexis Diaz "Jibarito" silkscreen print - $150
Donated by the artist, this 12" x 16" silkscreen is printed on acid free paper and is hand finished from an edition of 50. From 2014. Print shown is a sample from the original gallery website.
(1 available, sold out) 


Icy and Sot "Rebellion" screenprint - $150
Icy and Sot generously donated one of their REBELLION  7-color screen print on 300 gsm Somerset paper, signed and numbered by the artists. From an edition of 115. 60x60 cm  (23.6" x 23.6") - $150
(3 available, Sold Out)



CASE "Power of Movement" print - $200

Donated by our friends at 1xRun, this gorgeous print is by our multiple muralist Case.  18 x 15 Inches Archival Pigment Print on 310gsm Fine Art Paper. Signed and Numbered with COA.

Edition Size 50, Number 5/50 for sale. (1 available, sold out)


Oh Rochester! Sweet Meat Co. edition
St. Monci. - $350

Co-curator Erich Lehman teamed up with the other members of the Sweet Meat Co. to create a special edition of his "Oh Rochester!" project. Using float-mounted, reclaimed skateboards ridden in Rochester, these 17" Birch panel pieces were given the rest of the Sweet Meat Co (all previous muralists) to customize just for this fundraiser. Each one is one of a kind.
